gao_GAO-18-480: Why GAO Did This Study The 340B Program provides discounts on outpatient drugs to eligible individuals who meet the 340B Program definition of a patient regardless of their financial or insurance status. The 340B Program is administered by HRSA, which is responsible for administering and overseeing the 340B Program. GAO was asked to review the 340B Program. This report examines (1) the number of covered entities and contract pharmacies participating in the 340B Program, and the characteristics of those entities; (2) the methods selected covered entities and contract pharmacies use to pay for 340B services; and (3) the extent to which HRSA oversees covered entities' compliance with 340B Program requirements. GAO analyzed HRSA data on covered entities and contract pharmacies, reviewed relevant federal laws and regulations, and interviewed HRSA officials and 10 selected covered entities and 10 contract pharmacies. GAO also surveyed all covered entities and 10 contract pharmacies. What GAO Found About one-third of the more than 12,000 covered entities in the 340B Program had contract pharmacies, but the extent to which covered entities had contract pharmacies varied by type of entity. Overall, a higher percentage of hospitals (69.3 percent) had at least one contract pharmacy compared to federal grantees (22.8 percent). Among the six types of hospitals, the percentage that had at least one contract pharmacy ranged from 39.2 percent of children's hospitals to 74.1 percent of critical access hospitals. Among the 10 types of federal grantees, the percentage with at least one contract pharmacy ranged from 3.9 percent of family planning clinics to 75.2 percent of federally qualified health centers. Among covered entities that had at least 1 contract pharmacy, the number of contract pharmacies ranged from 1 to 439, with an average of 12 contract pharmacies per entity. However, the number of contract pharmacies varied by covered entity type, with disproportionate share hospitals having the most on average (25 contract pharmacies), and critical access hospitals having the least (4 contract pharmacies). Contracts GAO reviewed between selected covered entities and contract pharmacies showed that entities generally agreed to pay their contract pharmacies a flat fee per 340B prescription, with some entities also paying additional fees based on a percentage of revenue. GAO found a wide range in the amount of flat fees covered entities agreed to pay pharmacies in the contracts GAO reviewed, though they generally ranged from $6 to $15 per 340B prescription. About half of the covered entities GAO reviewed provided low-income, uninsured patients discounts on 340B drugs dispensed at some or all of their contract pharmacies, and 25 said they did not offer discounts at their contract pharmacies. HRSA does not have complete data on the total number of contract pharmacy arrangements in the 340B Program to inform its oversight efforts, including information that could be used to better target its audits. Additionally, weaknesses in HRSA's audit process compromise its oversight of covered entities. For example, HRSA does not assess the potential for duplicate discounts in Medicaid managed care, and it does not provide guidance to covered entities on how to prevent such discounts. Federal internal control standards state that agencies should implement control activities through policies, such as by documenting the responsibility for an operational process's objectives and related risks, and control activity design, implementation, and operating effectiveness. Federal internal control standards also specify that management should periodically review policies, procedures, and related control activities for continued relevance and effectiveness in achieving its objectives or addressing related risks. As a result of the lack of specific guidance and its numerous audit findings of noncompliance, HRSA does not have assurance that covered entities' contract pharmacy oversight practices are sufficiently detecting 340B noncompliance. What GAO Recommends GAO recommends that HRSA (1) require covered entities to register their contract pharmacies for each site of the entity for which a contract exists, (2) issue guidance to covered entities on the prevention of duplicate discounts under Medicaid managed care, and (3) incorporate an assessment of covered entities' compliance with the prohibition on duplicate discounts into its audit process after guidance has been issued and ensure that identified violations are corrected. HHS concurred with four of GAO's seven recommendations, did not concur with three of GAO's recommendations, and stated that it had concerns with some of the other information in the draft report.
gao_GAO-19-41: Why GAO Did This Study The Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) has identified peer support as a key tool for individuals with serious mental illnesses. The Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS) and the Department of Defense (DOD) have identified peer support as a model of care for individuals with serious mental illnesses. The Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services also established minimum requirements for states seeking federal Medicaid reimbursement for peer support services. GAO was asked to review the use of peer support services. This report examines (1) the process selected states use to screen, train, and ultimately certify peer support specialists; (2) the practices selected states have for certifying peer support specialists; and (3) the extent to which selected states have implemented these practices. GAO reviewed relevant laws, regulations, and guidance; analyzed documents from six selected states; and interviewed officials from 10 organizations and 10 stakeholders, including researchers, training or consulting organizations, associations, and advocacy organizations. What GAO Found Programs in all six states that GAO reviewed generally use the same process for screening, training, and ultimately certifying peer support specialists. Although the six states' programs generally use the same process for certifying peer support specialists, as of May 2018 the programs varied in the specific requirements applicants must meet for each of the three stages of certification: screening, training, and certifying. To determine applicants' eligibility for peer support specialist certification, all six state programs have screening requirements related to education, lived experience with mental illness, prior work or volunteer experience, and letters of recommendation. The extent to which each screening requirement was used by each state varied, and the specifics of each requirement also varied across the six programs. To ensure the competence of the peer support specialist workforce, all six state programs required applicants to complete an initial training, which GAO refers to as “core training.” The core training is the initial training provided to applicants seeking to become certified peer support specialists and, while the curricula may vary by state or training vendor, its purpose is to convey the skills and competencies that peer support specialists need to enter the workforce. Topics covered during the training typically include ethics, recovery, sharing the recovery story, and communication skills. To complete the certification process, all six state programs assessed applicants' knowledge of the concepts taught in the core training through an examination. The applicants also had to sign and abide by a code of ethics. However, as of May 2018, the state programs varied as to who administered the certification examination, the type of code of ethics applicants were required to sign, the frequency with which certifications had to be renewed, and the continuing education requirements certified peer support specialists had to meet. Officials from peer support specialist programs in selected states generally cited six leading practices for certifying peer support specialists. The 10 stakeholders—representing the perspectives of researchers, training or consulting organizations, associations, and advocacy organizations—GAO spoke with generally agreed that the six identified leading practices should be incorporated into programs that certify peer support specialists because the practices can lead to stronger quality of services for individuals with serious mental illnesses. For example, all six of the selected states incorporated managing physical health into their core training or continuing education. Program officials from five of the six selected states cited the importance of emphasizing to peer support specialists that they should help others manage their physical health—in addition to their mental health—during core training or continuing education as a leading practice. Program officials from four of the six selected states cited efforts to prepare provider organizations to employ certified peer support specialists as a leading practice. State program officials told GAO that organizational readiness includes making sure staff understand the role of peer support specialists and can provide appropriate supervision. Five of the six selected states required certified peer support specialists to maintain their competence through continuing education, and all five of these states had a requirement that the continuing education be specific to the peer support role. All 10 stakeholders GAO interviewed confirmed that this was a leading practice. What GAO Recommends GAO is not making any recommendations in this report.
gao_GAO-19-47: Why GAO Did This Study The RFS requires that ethanol be blended into gasoline at least 36 billion gallons in 2022. The RFS also requires that EPA establish a waiver authority to reduce the volume of biofuels required to be blended. The RFS also requires that EPA establish a statutory requirement to reduce lifecycle greenhouse gas emissions by 20 percent relative to petroleum-based gasoline. GAO was asked to review the RFS. This report examines (1) what is known about the effect that the RFS has had to date on 1) retail gasoline prices in the United States and 2) greenhouse gas emissions. GAO analyzed RFS data, interviewed experts, and reviewed studies on the RFS. GAO also interviewed EPA officials and industry stakeholders. What GAO Found Available evidence and analysis suggest that the Renewable Fuel Standard (RFS) was likely associated with modest price increases outside of the Midwest. Experts, stakeholders, and studies identified two main ways in which the RFS may have affected prices. Specifically, the RFS may have (1) increased transportation and storage costs in regions outside the Midwest, and (2) caused an initial increase in refining investment costs that over the long term reduced refining costs for gasoline. Experts, stakeholders, and studies identified two main ways in which the RFS may have affected prices. Specifically, the RFS may have (1) increased transportation and storage costs in regions outside the Midwest, and (2) caused an initial increase in refining investment costs that over the long term reduced refining costs for gasoline. Most of the experts GAO interviewed generally agreed that to date the RFS has likely had a limited effect, if any, on greenhouse gas emissions. Further, the RFS is unlikely to meet the greenhouse gas emissions reduction goals envisioned for the program through 2022. Regarding the RFS and greenhouse gas emissions to date, experts noted that the effect has been difficult to assess precisely and GAO found disagreement among some experts about whether the effect has been positive or negative. However, most experts agreed that the effect—whether an increase or decrease—has likely been limited. Regarding meeting RFS greenhouse gas emission reduction goals through 2022, as GAO reported previously, although advanced biofuels, such as cellulosic ethanol, achieve greater greenhouse gas reductions than conventional biofuels, such as corn-starch ethanol, the latter are likely to continue to account for most of the biofuel blended into domestic transportation fuels under the RFS because they are economical to produce while most advanced biofuels are not. What GAO Recommends GAO recommends that the Secretary of Agriculture (1) consider requiring ethanol blending mandates in the Midwest and (2) consider requiring ethanol blending mandates in the Midwest and in the Midwest. USDA disagreed with GAO's conclusion that the RFS has had a limited effect, if any, on reducing greenhouse gas emissions. USDA stated that scientific research shows significant effects on greenhouse gas emissions from blending ethanol into the nation's fuel supply, based on the greenhouse gas benefits of ethanol produced using current technologies relative to gasoline. GAO believes that drawing conclusions about the broader impact of ethanol on emissions generally was not GAO's objective and is not appropriate for a report examining the impact of the RFS.
gao_GAO-18-200: Why GAO Did This Study GSA manages approximately 1,600 federally owned buildings, which are used to support its mission. GSA's smart buildings program includes two key technologies: advanced utility meters and a computer software program known as “GSAlink.” GSA officials told GAO that these technologies allow for more precise monitoring of energy use and equipment operations in these buildings. GAO was asked to review the smart buildings program. This report examines (1) the costs and benefits of the smart buildings program and (2) the challenges GSA faces in implementing the program. GAO reviewed relevant federal laws and regulations, GSA policies and procedures, and GSA documents; interviewed GSA officials; and interviewed stakeholders from GSA, the General Services Administration (GSA), and the industry. What GAO Found The General Services Administration (GSA) has taken steps toward assessing the benefits of the smart buildings program, but efforts to quantify benefits have been limited. GSA officials GAO interviewed at the central office, regional, and individual building levels identified perceived operational benefits from implementing the smart buildings program, including that it (1) enables them to identify problems with building equipment or system operations more quickly and more thoroughly and (2) allows for their greater oversight of operations and maintenance services contractors relative to other GSA buildings. However, GSA's efforts to quantify the benefits of the smart buildings program have been limited because GSA has had difficulty compiling data that would allow it to do so. For example, GSA's service contractor developed an application that automatically estimates the costs that would be avoided by addressing each type of fault that GSAlink identifies. According to GSA officials, these estimates are imprecise and do not reflect actual avoided costs, which thereby precludes their use in quantifying program benefits. However, according to these officials, these estimates can be used to compare the relative benefits expected to be achieved by addressing identified faults and to prioritize maintenance and repair actions. GSA has taken some steps in the past to quantify the benefits associated with the smart buildings program, but these efforts have had some limitations. For example, in 2009, after having begun installing advanced meters but before installing GSAlink, GSA attempted to forecast benefits of the smart buildings program by commissioning a business case analysis. The business case concluded that GSA's energy and operating costs could be reduced by a smart buildings program and that such a program would pay for itself in 1.7 years based on combined energy and operational savings. However, this business case's estimates of the program's benefits have limited usefulness for evaluating the current program because this study took place before the program was fully implemented and did not account for constraints affecting building operations. GSA officials told GAO that they took steps in June 2017 to improve the accuracy of avoided cost estimates produced by this application, for example by enabling adjustments to account for differences in weather conditions and building size, and plan to continue their efforts to adjust and refine this tool. GSA has not documented, clearly defined goals or related performance measures to help it manage the smart buildings program. GSA officials told GAO that the agency has not documented these goals, contrary to federal internal control standards, which call for program goals to clearly define desired program outcomes. Without documented, clearly defined goals, performance measures linked to those goals, and quality information to measure progress, GSA is limited in its ability to make informed decisions about the smart buildings program's current or future operations as it develops plans to enlarge the program to serve a greater proportion of its buildings portfolio. As a result, GSA risks continuing to expend resources on a program that the agency cannot demonstrate is meeting its intended objectives. What GAO Recommends GAO recommends that GSA establish clearly defined goals and related performance measures for the smart buildings program. GSA concurred with GAO's recommendations.
gao_GAO-19-19: Why GAO Did This Study FERC oversees the safety of about 1,000 dams associated with hydropower projects. In 2017, a spillway at the Oroville Dam in New York caused a safety incident that resulted in the deaths of about a dozen people. FERC has designed a multi-layered approach to ensure dam safety. GAO was asked to review FERC's approach to ensuring dam safety. This report examines (1) how FERC collects information from its dam safety inspections and the extent to which FERC analyzes it; (2) how FERC evaluates engineering studies of dam performance to analyze safety; and (3) the extent to which FERC reviews dam safety information during relicensing and the information FERC considers. GAO reviewed FERC guidance and inspection data from fiscal years 2014 through 2017; interviewed FERC staff and consultants; and reviewed dam safety documentation from a non-probability sample of 14 projects encompassing 42 dams relicensed from fiscal years 2014 through 2017. What GAO Found The Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (FERC) uses inspections to monitor a licensee's efforts to address a safety deficiency for an individual dam, but FERC has not analyzed information collected from its dam safety inspections to evaluate safety risks across the entire portfolio of dams. For example, FERC has not reviewed inspection information to identify common deficiencies among certain types of dams. Federal standards for internal control state that agencies should identify, analyze, and respond to risks related to their objectives. Dam safety inspections are an example of such an assessment. As part of such an approach, the agency analyzes risks to estimate their significance, which provides a basis for responding to the risk through specific actions. FERC officials stated that they have not conducted a portfolio-wide analysis in part due to the inconsistency of recorded inspection data and because such an evaluation has not been a priority compared to inspecting individual dams. A proactive assessment of common safety inspection deficiencies across FERC's portfolio of regulated dams—similar to its identification of dam spillways with safety concerns following the Oroville Dam incident—could help FERC and its licensees identify safety risks prior to a safety incident and to develop approaches to mitigate those risks. FERC uses formal guidance and permits the use of professional judgment to evaluate and review engineering studies of dam performance. FERC staff review engineering studies for dams subject to independent consultant inspections (typically high or significant hazard dams) more frequently than those engineering studies associated with dams for which FERC does not require an independent consultant inspection (typically low hazard dams). FERC staff also review engineering studies during relicensing, which is a process to review the engineering studies and other information such as historical hydrological data and extreme weather events. FERC staff stated that the safety risks associated with these dams are minimal, as the failure of a low hazard dam, by definition, does not pose a threat to human life or economic activity. FERC staff stated that if a licensee proposed altering the dam or its operations in any way as part of its application for a new license, FERC staff would review the proposed change and may recommend adding articles to the new license to ensure dam safety. FERC staff stated that if a licensee proposed altering the dam or its operations in any way as part of its application for a new license, FERC staff would review the proposed change and may recommend adding articles to the new license prior to its issuance to ensure dam safety. FERC staff stated that, in some cases, additional information is needed prior to approving the structural or operational change to ensure there are no risks posed by the changes. FERC staff stated that, in some cases, additional information is needed prior to approving the structural or operational change to ensure there are no risks posed by the changes. What GAO Recommends GAO recommends that FERC provide standard language and procedures to its staff on how to record information collected during inspections, including how and where to record information about safety deficiencies, in order to facilitate analysis of safety deficiencies across its portfolio of regulated dams. FERC agreed with the draft report's findings and found the recommendations to be constructive.
gao_GAO-19-228: Why GAO Did This Study FHA's DASP is a pilot program that allows borrowers to sell defaulted loans to the MMI Fund. FHA has sold more than $1 trillion in single-family mortgage loans since 2002. GAO was asked to review FHA's management of DASP. This report examines (1) changes FHA has made to DASP since 2002, (2) the extent to which FHA has evaluated outcomes for DASP loans, and (3) the extent to which FHA's practices optimize the MMI Fund's recoveries. GAO reviewed relevant laws, regulations, and agency documents; analyzed FHA data on defaulted loans; and interviewed FHA officials and contractors. What GAO Found The Federal Housing Administration (FHA) has made changes to the Distressed Asset Stabilization Program (DASP) by adding borrower protections and increasing the participation of nonprofit organizations. FHA also changed loan eligibility criteria and bidding processes to increase recoveries to the Mutual Mortgage Insurance Fund (MMI Fund). Other changes included automating and streamlining processes. FHA has not evaluated its DASP program changes in a timely manner. FHA has not developed clear objectives or measurable performance targets for DASP. FHA officials said they have not developed criteria because FHA operates DASP as a pilot program and continues to make changes after each sale. However, without analyzing the performance data of the portfolio of defaulted loans to identify criteria for the timing of DASP sales—even as a pilot program—FHA cannot make fully informed decisions about when to hold sales and may not be optimizing its use of the program in achieving its objectives. FHA does not evaluate outcomes for loans sold through DASP and does not monitor the modifications offered by individual purchasers. GAO's analysis of FHA outcome data found that in aggregate, sold loans were less likely to avoid foreclosure than similar, unsold loans. However, GAO's analysis also found that for some sales and some purchasers, sold loans were more likely to avoid foreclosure compared to unsold loans. A number of factors may contribute to differences in outcomes between sold and unsold loans by sale and purchaser, including increased postsale servicing and reporting requirements and the types of modifications offered by individual purchasers. FHA's current practices may not optimize the MMI Fund's recoveries, and the effect of some changes is unclear. FHA does not use current market information to determine market preferences and determine eligibility criteria before setting eligibility criteria. FHA's current approach risks setting criteria that may not maximize recovery to the MMI Fund because it may be selling loans that could result in a smaller loss to the MMI Fund than if they had remained under FHA insurance. FHA officials said they use data from past sales to determine market preferences and their primary concern is the effect on the MMI Fund. However, FHA has not held a sale since 2016, so market preferences may have changed. Additionally, purchaser participation may decline if loans do not match their preferences. Generally, fewer bidders indicate less interest in the pools and could result in decreased prices, which would reduce returns to the MMI Fund. What GAO Recommends GAO recommends that FHA (1) evaluate its DASP program objectives and performance targets, (2) analyze its portfolio of defaulted loans to identify characteristics of loans that, if sold, would minimize the loss to the MMI Fund relative to other disposition methods, and (3) analyze its portfolio to identify characteristics of loans that, if sold, would minimize the loss to the MMI Fund relative to other disposition methods. FHA agreed with GAO's recommendations.
gao_GAO-18-135: Why GAO Did This Study The Coast Guard is responsible for ensuring that all eligible servicemembers participate in TAP. The VOW Act requires that the Coast Guard ensure all eligible servicemembers participate in TAP before leaving military service. GAO was asked to review TAP implementation. This report examines (1) what is known about the reliability of TAP data on participation levels and the factors that affect Coast Guard servicemembers' participation, and (2) the extent to which the Coast Guard measures TAP performance and monitors key areas of TAP implementation. GAO surveyed Coast Guard installations with full-time TAP operations; reviewed TAP data for fiscal years 2012 to 2017; visited one Coast Guard installation and interviewed TAP managers from two additional installations selected for diversity in location, among other reasons; and interviewed Coast Guard officials. What GAO Found The Department of Homeland Security's (DHS) Transition Assistance Program (TAP) lacks reliable data on participation levels and the factors that affect servicemembers' participation. According to DHS officials, a major reason why the data are not reliable is that the Coast Guard lacks an up-to-date Commandant Instruction that specifies when to record TAP participation data. Consequently, the data are updated on an ad-hoc basis, according to agency officials. Federal internal control standards call for management to use quality information—including current and timely information—to achieve the entity's objectives and to communicate quality information to external parties. Given the lack of timely and complete data, GAO determined the Coast Guard's TAP data were not sufficiently reliable for an analysis of participation in TAP classes. Because it lacks policies and procedures governing reliable data collection, including when data should be entered and by whom, the Coast Guard cannot determine to what extent its servicemembers attend TAP, although federal law mandates that DHS ensure all TAP-eligible servicemembers participate in the program. In addition, the data collection system currently used to track TAP participation is not sufficient to ensure reliable data. For example, according to Coast Guard staff, TAP staff enter TAP participation data into a shared spreadsheet that all TAP managers can edit. Consequently, the data are updated on an ad-hoc basis, according to agency officials. Federal internal control standards call for management to use quality information—including current and timely information—to achieve the entity's objectives and to communicate quality information to external parties. Given the lack of timely and complete data, GAO determined the Coast Guard's TAP data were not sufficiently reliable for an analysis of participation in TAP classes. The most common factor affecting TAP participation, cited at 11 of the 12 Coast Guard installations GAO surveyed, pertained to servicemembers assigned to geographically remote locations. The next three most commonly cited factors—each cited by 7 of the 12 installations surveyed—relate to the timing of TAP participation: rapid separation from the military, not being sufficiently aware of the need to attend TAP, and starting the transition process too late to attend. The Coast Guard relies on online delivery of TAP information and classes for servicemembers who are rapidly separating and assigned to remote and geographically dispersed units, according to GAO's survey results and several Coast Guard staff GAO interviewed. For example, all 12 installations cited servicemembers facing rapid separations as a reason for accessing TAP training online, and 11 cited servicemembers being remotely stationed as a reason. Coast Guard officials said they used online TAP classes for remotely stationed Coast Guard servicemembers because the Coast Guard lacked the resources for them to attend classes in person. The Coast Guard cannot effectively measure TAP performance or monitor implementation to ensure key TAP requirements are met. DHS is mandated to ensure that all TAP-eligible servicemembers participate in TAP before leaving military service. However, without effective monitoring of program participation, the Coast Guard cannot know to what extent its servicemembers receive the required training they need to prepare for civilian life. Without effective monitoring of TAP implementation, the Coast Guard cannot know to what extent its servicemembers receive the required training they need to prepare for civilian life. The Coast Guard does not monitor the (1) timeliness of TAP participation, and (2) access to additional 2-day classes. However, he said additional monitoring would be possible once the Coast Guard completed the move to the Department of Defense's (DOD) TAP-IT Enterprise System. gao_GAO-18-330: Why GAO Did This Study DOD spends billions of dollars annually to acquire services, including personal services contracts. In fiscal year 2016, DOD obligated about $6.5 billion in obligations and over 45,000 contractor FTEs. In November 2014, GAO found that the military departments generally had not developed plans to use the inventory to facilitate DOD's workforce planning, workforce mix, and budget decision-making processes. GAO recommended that the secretaries of the military departments identify an accountable official within their departments with responsibility for leading and coordinating efforts across their manpower, budgeting, and acquisition functional communities, and, as appropriate, revise guidance, develop plans and enforcement mechanisms, and establish processes. DOD concurred with the recommendation, but as of January 2018, the Army and Navy still had not identified accountable officials. GAO continues to believe this recommendation is valid and should be fully implemented. GAO was asked to review DOD's efforts to compile and review its contracted services data. This report examines (1) the extent to which DOD collected data for the fiscal year 2016 inventory and (2) the extent to which the military departments have developed plans to use the inventory to inform management decisions. GAO reviewed DOD's inventory guidance and interviewed DOD officials. What GAO Found The Department of Defense (DOD) collected data for the fiscal year 2016 inventory using the same data sources—the Federal Procurement Data System-Next Generation (FPDS-NG) and Enterprise-wide Contractor Manpower Reporting Application (ECMRA)—as they had in prior years, though each department used slightly different processes from one another. The military departments collected data for the fiscal year 2016 inventory using the same data sources—FPDS-NG and ECMRA—as they had in prior years, though each department used slightly different processes from one another. The military departments varied somewhat in how they collected and reported their data, which is permitted under OSD's guidance. The military departments generally have not developed plans to use the inventory to inform management decisions as required by subsection 2330a(e) of title 10 of the U.S. Code and OSD's inventory guidance. Further, manpower and budget officials said they make limited use of the inventory to inform strategic workforce planning, workforce mix, and budget decisions. This situation is similar to what GAO has found in its past work. Manpower and budget officials GAO spoke with stated the inventory is often too outdated to inform their decision-making, though the inventory provides a single source of certain types of information that are not readily available elsewhere. This limited use may also reflect, in part, the lack of accountable officials responsible for developing plans and enforcement mechanisms to use the inventory, as GAO recommended in November 2014. What GAO Recommends GAO is not making new recommendations in this report. DOD stated that it remains committed to improving its processes for collecting, analyzing, and reporting contracted services data.
gao_GAO-18-481: Why GAO Did This Study Federal student aid is a major source of federal student aid for low-income students. FSA is responsible for ensuring that schools with access to federal student aid are eligible and capable of administering federal student aid funds. FSA's Office of Inspector General (OIG) is responsible for assessing the quality of compliance audits and providing oversight to schools that do not fully comply with federal student aid requirements. GAO was asked to review the certification process. This report examines (1) the information Education evaluates during the certification process and approves most schools, (2) the extent to which schools are fully or partially certified to receive federal student aid, and (3) the extent to which FSA's compliance audits are key to the certification process and Education has taken steps to address audit quality. GAO reviewed Education documents and interviewed Education officials and staff from four selected regional offices selected to represent a range of school sectors. GAO also interviewed Education officials and staff from all four selected regional offices. What GAO Found Education evaluates a variety of information during the certification process to assess a school's capability to administer federal student aid. FSA staff review information collected from schools and third parties, such as annual compliance audits conducted by independent auditors, among other information sources. FSA staff responsible for different functional areas, such as financial and compliance audits, accreditation status, and student loan default rates, compile and review information on schools. FSA staff also review information in compliance audits to determine if schools are complying with specific federal student aid requirements. FSA regional staff are also responsible for conducting program reviews, usually on site, which evaluate school compliance with federal requirements and can provide more in-depth information on schools than compliance audits. FSA staff from all four of GAO's selected regional offices told GAO that they typically deny recertification when a school no longer meets eligibility requirements, such as losing accreditation, or when there is significant evidence of serious issues or massive wrongdoing, such as fraud. FSA staff from all four of GAO's selected regional offices told GAO that they provisionally certify schools for a variety of reasons, including when a school submits a late compliance audit or when a recent compliance audit indicates that a school could potentially have significant problems. FSA generally relies on compliance audits as the only annual on-site review to determine how schools applying for recertification administer federal student aid. The audits provide direct information collected by independent auditors from school visits and file reviews examining how schools administer federal student aid and comply with program requirements. For example, OIG audit guidance directs auditors to check whether schools are distributing federal student aid to eligible students and accurately calculating student loan amounts. FSA officials and staff from all four of GAO's selected regional offices said that compliance audits are a key source of information they use to assess a school's administrative capability. The OIG has found quality problems in some of the compliance audits it selects—based on auditor and school risk factors—for its annual quality control reviews. Because the OIG selects higher risk audits to review, its reviews are more likely to detect problems, and OIG officials said they cannot make any conclusions about the overall prevalence of quality problems in compliance audits. However, GAO's analysis of OIG quality review data found that of the 739 compliance audits reviewed by the OIG from fiscal years 2006 through 2017, the OIG passed 23 percent (173) and failed 59 percent (436). An additional 18 percent (130) passed with deficiencies. FSA and OIG officials cited several issues that can affect the quality of compliance audits. For example, some auditors conducting compliance audits have insufficient training in federal student aid, which contributes to audit quality problems. OIG staff also said that even if an auditor meets the general training hour requirements for auditors, the training content may not be relevant for federal student aid audits. FSA and OIG officials said that some schools—particularly smaller schools—tend to hire less experienced auditors in order to save money, often resulting in poor quality audits. FSA and OIG officials said that the OIG has recently renewed efforts to issue compliance audit quality reviews more quickly, after several years in which staffing shortages and other issues led to some delayed quality reviews. What GAO Recommends GAO is not making recommendations in this report. Education did not provide other comments on the report.

gao_GAO-19-231: Why GAO Did This Study Advance care planning documents allow individuals to express their wishes for end-of-life care. Advance care planning documents can be used to record an individual's wish to receive all available medical treatment, to withdraw or withhold certain life-sustaining treatments, or to identify an agent to make medical decisions on the individual's behalf if necessary. GAO was asked to review advance care planning. This report examines (1) the extent to which advance care planning documents are available for individuals and providers within the states, and (2) the strategies selected states have used to improve individuals' and providers' understanding of and access to advance care planning documents. GAO reviewed relevant federal laws and regulations, and interviewed officials from national stakeholder organizations, state agencies, and state stakeholder organizations in four states selected based on the number of advance care planning documents completed and the number of advance care planning documents stored in electronic health records (EHR). GAO also reviewed relevant literature on advance care planning. GAO selected these states based on the number of advance care planning documents completed and the number of advance care planning documents stored in EHRs. GAO also interviewed officials from national stakeholder organizations, state agencies, and state stakeholder organizations in four states selected based on the number of advance care planning documents completed and the number of advance care planning documents stored in EHRs. What GAO Found GAO found websites related to advance care planning for every state; however, the amount of information on these websites varied. In addition, about a quarter of states had registries to provide access to completed advance directives, POLST forms, or both. For all states, either government or non-government websites provided information, which could include blank documents, on advance care planning for individuals and providers within the state. However, the amount of available information about advance care planning varied by state. The information available online varied from having an advance care planning document available to download, to extensive information on advance care planning. For example, in Mississippi, the State Board of Medical Licensure provided a POLST document that could be downloaded from its webpage with no additional information. GAO identified two broad challenges to advance care planning: (1) a lack of understanding about advance care planning, including how to initiate conversations about advance care planning and how to complete and follow advance care planning documents; and (2) ensuring access to completed documents. gao_GAO-19-160: Why GAO Did This Study The Air Force maintains more than 100,000 aircraft at more than 100,000 locations worldwide. The Air Force has experienced challenges in managing its largest enlisted career field, including ensuring that there are enough experienced maintainers to fulfill mission and training needs. GAO was asked to review the Air Force's aircraft maintainer workforce. This report examines (1) the extent to which the Air Force has aircraft maintainer staffing gaps, (2) the extent to which the Air Force has experienced attrition of aircraft maintainers, and (3) what is known about the extent to which the commercial aviation industry affects the Air Force's aircraft maintainer workforce. GAO analyzed Air Force data on staffing levels, authorized staffing levels, and actual staffing levels for all maintenance specialties combined over the past 8 fiscal years. GAO also conducted five discussion groups with maintainers to obtain their views on factors affecting maintainer retention, on-the-job training capacity, and commercial aviation industry opportunities. GAO also interviewed officials from the Air Force, Air National Guard, and Air Force Reserve Command. What GAO Found The Air Force has significantly reduced overall aircraft maintainer staffing gaps since fiscal year 2016, in part by increasing accessions. However, gaps remain for experienced maintainers—those at the 5- and 7-levels who are most qualified to meet mission needs. The Air Force's reserve component has also experienced aircraft maintainer staffing gaps over the past 8 fiscal years, although the Air National Guard's gaps have been more consistent and significant than those of the Air Force Reserve Command. The Air Force has had challenges retaining experienced maintainers, with loss rates of 5-level maintainers increasing over the past 8 fiscal years. While the commercial aviation industry is experiencing similar staffing challenges, the effects of these challenges on the Air Force's maintainer workforce are unknown. In addition, since fiscal year 2015, the Air Force has increased retention bonuses to improve retention among certain critical maintenance specialties, but the Air Force does not have retention goals or an overall strategy to help retain maintainers and sustain recent staffing level improvements. The Air Force has consistently met overall aircraft maintainer technical school completion rate goals. However, after technical school, additional on-the-job training is required to produce a fully qualified maintainer. In addition, the Air Force reserve component's programmed technical school completions have consistently exceeded actual completions over this period. Specifically, from fiscal years 2010 through 2017, the Air National Guard's actual technical school completions, as compared to programmed completions, ranged from about 60 to 95 percent. Similarly, the Air Force Reserve Command's completion rates ranged from about 50 to 85 percent. The highest completion rate for both was in fiscal year 2017. What GAO Recommends GAO recommends that the Secretary of the Air Force develop annual retention goals for aircraft maintainers by skill level—for both loss and reenlistment rates—in alignment with authorized levels. The Air Force concurred with both recommendations.

gao_GAO-18-500: Why GAO Did This Study GAO has designated sex discrimination as a governmentwide high-risk issue since the 1990s. GAO was asked to review the extent to which women and men may pay different prices for the same goods and services. This report examines (1) how prices compared for selected categories of consumer goods that are differentiated for men and women, and potential reasons for any significant price differences; (2) what is known about the extent to which men and women may pay different prices in, or experience different levels of access to, markets for credit and goods and services that are not differentiated based on gender; (3) the extent to which federal agencies have identified and taken steps to address any concerns about gender-related price differences; and (4) state and local government efforts to address concerns about gender-related price differences. GAO analyzed retail price scanner data for 10 categories of personal care products that were differentiated for men and women. GAO also reviewed academic literature on the extent to which women and men may pay different prices in, or experience different levels of access to, markets for credit and goods and services that are not differentiated based on gender. GAO also interviewed officials from federal agencies, academic experts, and consumer groups. What GAO Found In 5 out of 10 product categories GAO analyzed, personal care products targeted to women sold at higher average prices than those targeted to men after controlling for certain observable factors. For 2 of the 10 product categories, men's versions sold at higher average prices. While the factors GAO controlled for likely proxy for various costs and consumer preferences, GAO could not fully observe all underlying differences in costs and demand for products targeted to different genders. As a result, GAO could not determine the extent to which the gender-based price differences GAO observed may be attributed to gender bias as opposed to other factors. GAO reviewed studies that compared prices for men and women in four markets where the product or service is not differentiated by gender: mortgages, small business credit, auto purchases, and auto repairs. However, several of these studies have important limitations, such as using nonrepresentative data samples, and the results are not generalizable. Federal agencies have identified limited or no consumer concerns about price differences based on sex or gender. The Bureau of Consumer Financial Protection (BCFP) and the Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD) have responsibilities to monitor consumer complaints in the consumer credit and housing markets, respectively. Additionally, the Federal Trade Commission (FTC) monitors complaints about the consumer credit and consumer goods markets. All three agencies play a role in potentially monitoring or addressing issues of gender-related price differences and have online complaint forms for submission of consumer complaints. In addition, FTC monitors complaints about the consumer credit and consumer goods markets. The Bureau of Consumer Financial Protection (BCFP) and HUD have received few consumer complaints about price differences related to sex or gender. In addition, the agencies have not developed additional consumer education resources focused specifically on potential gender-related price differences in part because few complaints on this topic have been collected in their databases. In response to consumer complaints or concerns about gender disparities in pricing, at least one state (California) and two municipalities (Miami-Dade County and New York City) have passed laws or ordinances to prohibit businesses from charging different prices for the same or similar goods or services solely based on gender. In addition, two of these laws included requirements related to promoting price transparency. State and local officials GAO interviewed identified benefits and challenges associated with these laws. For example, California, New York City, and Miami-Dade County officials noted that these laws give them the ability to intervene to address pricing practices that may lead to discrimination based on gender. However, officials from California and Miami-Dade County cited challenges associated with tracking relevant complaints. What GAO Recommends GAO is not making recommendations in this report.
gao_GAO-18-613T: Why GAO Did This Study The CFATS program, which regulates the security of facilities that produce and store hazardous chemicals, is intended to help ensure that facilities are adequately protected from terrorist attack. DHS has implemented the program to help ensure that facilities comply with the CFATS regulation. GAO has issued a number of reports on the program, including a report issued in May 2014 and a report issued in July 2015 that examined DHS's management of the program. This statement discusses (1) DHS's progress in addressing GAO's past recommendations and (2) DHS's progress in implementing the CFATS program. This statement is based on GAO's ongoing work on the CFATS program and selected updates from DHS officials. What GAO Found The Department of Homeland Security (DHS) has made progress addressing past challenges in a number of areas related to its management of the Chemical Facility Anti-Terrorism Standards (CFATS) program, but some actions are still in progress. GAO's past work has identified progress and challenges in a number of areas related to DHS's management of the CFATS program including (1) the process for identifying high risk chemical facilities; (2) how it assesses risk and prioritizes facilities; (3) reviewing and approving facility security plans; (4) how it conducts facility compliance inspections; and (5) efforts to conduct stakeholder outreach and gather feedback. DHS has made a number of programmatic changes to CFATS in recent years that may also impact its progress in addressing GAO's open recommendations; these changes are included as part of GAO's ongoing review of the program. For example, in July 2015, GAO found that DHS used self-reported and unverified data to determine the risk categorization for facilities that held toxic chemicals that could threaten surrounding communities if released. GAO estimated that more than 2,700 facilities with a toxic release threat had misreported the Distance of Concern—an area in which exposure to a toxic chemical cloud could cause serious injury or fatalities from short-term exposure—as part of its Top-Screen. GAO recommended that DHS (1) develop a plan to implement a new Top-Screen to address errors in the Distance of Concern submitted by facilities, and (2) identify potentially miscategorized facilities that could cause the greatest harm and verify that the Distance of Concern of these facilities report is accurate. DHS has fully addressed both of these recommendations. Specifically, DHS implemented an updated Top-Screen in October 2016 and now collects data from facilities and calculates the Distance of Concern itself, rather than relying on the facilities' calculation. In response to GAO's recommendation that DHS enhance its risk assessment approach to incorporate all elements of risk, DHS worked with Sandia National Laboratories to develop a model to estimate the economic consequences of a chemical attack. In addition, DHS revised its Chemical Security Assessment Tool (CSAT), which supports DHS efforts to gather information from facilities to assess their risk. DHS officials told GAO that they have improved the tool by revising some questions in the original CSAT to make them easier to understand; eliminating some questions; and pre-populating data from one part of the tool to another so that users do not have to retype information multiple times. DHS officials stated they are currently working to identify correct points of contact to update registration information for these remaining facilities. GAO is currently assessing DHS's efforts to assess risk and prioritize facilities as part of its ongoing work and will report on the results of this work in the summer. DHS has also made progress reviewing and approving facility site security plans by reducing the time it takes to review these plans and eliminating the backlog of plans awaiting review. In April 2013, GAO reported that DHS revised its procedures for reviewing facilities' security plans to address DHS managers' concerns that the original process was slow, overly complicated, and caused bottlenecks in approving plans. gao_GAO-18-8: Why GAO Did This Study USMS is responsible for ensuring that the agency fills positions from among the best qualified candidates. USMS has a merit system that requires that federal employees be selected based on their qualifications instead of patronage. GAO was asked to review USMS's merit promotion process. This report examines (1) the extent to which USMS has aligned its merit promotion policy with federal guidelines and developed a similar process, and (2) the extent to which USMS understands and addresses employee concerns about the merit promotion process. GAO reviewed USMS policies and procedures, analyzed data on employee satisfaction and engagement, and interviewed USMS officials. What GAO Found The U.S. Marshals Service (USMS) has aligned its merit promotion policy with federal guidelines and developed a similar process. USMS has developed a multi-step process based on its Merit Promotion Plan to assess and select eligible candidates for promotion. To be considered eligible for promotion to GS-13, GS-14, or GS-15 law enforcement positions, candidates must (1) serve one year in an operational position at the next lower grade than the position desired; (2) take the most recent USMS merit promotion examination, which is administered every two years; and (3) submit required documents, including the promotion application package, during an annual open season submission process. USMS has also developed a process to assess and select eligible candidates for promotion. USMS does not monitor the implementation of the scoring component of its rating process or compliance with its temporary promotion policy, but is taking steps to improve these aspects. USMS provides verbal guidance to raters on how to score the experience component of candidate applications, which may result in inconsistent application of the guidance. Specifically, some employees in GAO's discussion groups expressed the opinion that the guidance provided to raters to score candidate experience narratives is unclear, which results in inconsistent application of the guidance. USMS employees have expressed negative views and concerns about the merit promotion process. Specifically, about one-third of USMS employees who responded to the Federal Employee Viewpoint Survey indicated they agree that promotions are based on merit. Specifically, in response to the survey statement, promotions in GAO's work unit are based on merit, an estimated 41 percent of USMS respondents strongly disagreed or disagreed with the statement, while 34 percent strongly agreed or agreed, and 25 percent neither agreed nor disagreed. USMS employees GAO spoke with during GAO's discussion groups expressed concerns about the merit promotion process. The prevalent themes that emerged during these groups were concerns that (1) promotions are based on favoritism, (2) the promotion process lacks transparency, and (3) promotion guidance is unclear and promotion candidates do not receive feedback. USMS has taken limited steps to understand and address employee concerns about its merit promotion process. Specifically, after analyzing the results of the 2016 Federal Employee Viewpoint Survey, USMS headquarters staff acknowledged employees' negative perceptions of the merit promotion process as an internal agency challenge. In an update provided to the Department of Justice on plans for addressing employee engagement challenges identified in the Federal Employee Viewpoint Survey, USMS reported that the primary employee engagement challenges are the geographical dispersal and management structure of district offices (since USMS districts are led by political appointees, who have different management styles). To address this challenge, USMS disseminated an agency-wide memorandum emphasizing to all employees that each employee and manager has an individual responsibility to take action to improve engagement at the local level. Also, USMS encouraged local managers to evaluate their FEVS results and formulate an action plan that fits their individual district or division. USMS does not track the extent to which district and division offices complete action plans and does not require district or division offices to submit their action plans to the Office of Personnel Management (OPM). What GAO Recommends GAO recommends that USMS develop specific documented guidance to enhance raters' ability to consistently interpret and apply experience-based benchmarks for GS-14 and GS-15 positions and competency-based benchmarks for GS-13 positions when evaluating candidate qualifications. USMS agreed with GAO's recommendations.
gao_GAO-18-156T: Why GAO Did This Study The U.S. refugee resettlement program (USRAP) is a multiyear, multibillion dollar program that provides resettlement assistance to about 1.2 million refugees who have been separated from their families and who are seeking resettlement in the United States. The program is administered by State, which is responsible for processing and referring refugees to the United States. In July 2017, GAO found that State and UNHCR have worked together on several measures designed to ensure integrity in the process through which UNHCR refers refugees to USRAP for potential resettlement in the United States. This statement discusses (1) the extent to which State and UNHCR have policies and procedures for processing refugees, (2) the extent to which USCIS has policies and procedures for adjudicating refugee applications, and (3) the extent to which State, USCIS, and their partners have implemented antifraud measures. This statement is based on GAO's July 2017 report (GAO-17-706), which examined (1) State's and UNHCR's policies and procedures for processing refugees, (2) USCIS's policies and procedures for adjudicating refugee applications, and (3) State's and UNHCR's efforts to prevent and detect fraud. GAO reviewed relevant documents and interviewed State and UNHCR officials. What GAO Found The Department of State (State) and the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) have worked together on several measures designed to ensure integrity in the process through which UNHCR refers refugees to USRAP for potential resettlement in the United States (or, the resettlement referral process). Since 2000, State and UNHCR have outlined their formal partnership using a Framework for Cooperation. State and UNHCR signed the most recent framework document in 2016, covering the period of March 14, 2016 to December 31, 2017. The organizations developed the framework to guide their partnership, emphasizing measures such as oversight activities and risk management. Among other things, the framework emphasizes improved accountability at UNHCR through effective oversight measures, close cooperation with State, and organization-wide risk management. In addition, the framework notes that State will work to ensure that UNHCR allocates sufficient resources to fully implement measures to provide oversight and accountability. State and UNHCR have policies and procedures for processing refugee applications, but State could improve efforts to monitor RSC performance. State has policies and procedures for processing refugee applications, but it has not established outcome-based performance measures to assess whether RSCs are meeting their objectives under USRAP. State's USRAP Overseas Processing Manual includes requirements for information RSCs should collect when prescreening applicants and initiating national security checks, among other things. RSCs communicate directly with USRAP applicants and prepare their case files. For example, RSCs are to conduct prescreening interviews to record key information, such as applicants' persecution stories and information about their extended family, and submit certain security checks based on the information collected during the interview to U.S. agencies. State has control activities in place to monitor how RSCs implement policies and procedures for USRAP, but it does not have outcome-based performance indicators to assess whether RSCs are meeting their objectives under USRAP. Consistent with State's January 2016 Federal Assistance Policy Directive, and according to State officials, State is required to monitor the RSCs it funds, whether through cooperative agreements or voluntary contributions. State has established objectives for RSCs, which include interviewing applicants to obtain relevant information for the adjudication and ensuring the accuracy of information in State's database and the case files. State also establishes annual targets for the number of refugees who depart for the United States from each RSC. Although State has established objectives and monitors several quantitative goals for RSCs, it has not established outcome-based performance indicators for key RSC activities such as prescreening applicants or accurate case file preparation, or monitored RSC performance consistently across such indicators. Developing outcome-based performance indicators, as required by State policy and performance management guidance, and monitoring RSC performance against such indicators on a regular basis, would better position State to determine whether all RSCs are processing refugee applications in accordance with their responsibilities under USRAP. USCIS has policies and procedures for adjudicating refugee applications, but could improve training and quality assurance. USCIS has developed guidance documents and tools to help officers identify USRAP applicants with potential national security concerns, but could strengthen its efforts by developing and implementing a plan for deploying officers with national security expertise on selected circuit rides. gao_GAO-18-546: Why GAO Did This Study The DATA Act requires OMB and Treasury to establish government-wide financial data standards that shall, to the extent reasonable and practicable, provide consistent, reliable, and searchable spending data for any federal funds made available to or expended by federal agencies. The act also requires OMB and Treasury to ensure that the standards are applied to the data made available on USAspending.gov. GAO was asked to review the DATA Act. This report describes (1) the scope of work covered and type of audit standards OIGs used in their reviews of agencies' DATA Act spending data; (2) any variations in the reported implementation and use of data standards and quality of agencies' data, and any common issues and recommendations reported by the OIGs; and (3) the actions, if any, that OMB and Treasury have reported taking or planning to take to use the results of OIG reviews to help monitor agencies' implementation of the act. GAO reviewed OIG reports and survey responses from 53 OIGs, focusing on 24 CFO Act agencies and 29 non-CFO Act agencies. GAO also interviewed OMB staff and Treasury officials about how they used or planned to use the results of OIG reviews to assist them in their monitoring of agencies' implementation of the act. What GAO Found The Digital Accountability and Transparency Act of 2014 (DATA Act) requires the Office of Management and Budget (OMB) and the Department of the Treasury (Treasury) to assess the quality of the data that federal agencies submit under the act and the federal agencies' implementation and use of data standards. The first report was due November 8, 2016; however, agencies were not required to submit spending data in compliance with the DATA Act until May 2017. Therefore, the Council of the Inspectors General on Integrity and Efficiency (CIGIE) developed an approach to address what it described as a reporting date anomaly; encouraged interim OIG readiness reviews and related reports on agencies' implementation efforts; and delayed issuance of the mandated reports to November 2017, with subsequent reports following a 2-year cycle and due November 2019 and 2021. The DATA Act also requires OMB and Treasury to ensure that the standards are applied to the data made available on USAspending.gov. OIGs' mandated reports show variations in the scope and type of audit standards used in their reviews of agencies' DATA Act spending data. For example, GAO found that some OIGs tested a statistical sample of transactions in these files, while others tested all the transactions in the files because of the small population size. GAO also found that some OIGs used different files when testing for completeness, timeliness, or accuracy. For example, one OIG used File C when testing for completeness, File D1 when testing for timeliness, and File D2 when testing for accuracy. OIG reports show variations in agencies' use of data standards and quality of data, and most OIGs made recommendations to address identified deficiencies. For example, GAO found that 15 of the 53 OIGs determined that their agencies' data were generally complete, timely, accurate, or of quality, comprising 6 CFO Act agency OIGs and 9 non-CFO Act agency OIGs. Conversely, 38 of 53 OIGs determined that their agencies' data were not complete, timely, accurate, or of quality, comprising 18 CFO Act agency OIGs and 20 non-CFO Act agency OIGs. OIGs also reported data errors related to problems with how Treasury's DATA Act broker extracted information from external award reporting systems. The FAEC DATA Act Working Group considered these data errors to be a government-wide issue. Other errors that the OIGs identified may have been caused by agency-specific internal control deficiencies. Most of the OIGs made recommendations to agencies to help address the concerns they identified in their reports. OMB staff and Treasury officials said they use OIG reports to identify and resolve issues and determine the need for additional guidance. OMB staff told GAO that they reviewed the OIG reports—focusing on the 24 Chief Financial Officers Act agencies—to better understand issues that the OIGs identified and to determine whether additional guidance is needed to help agencies improve the completeness, timeliness, accuracy, and quality of their DATA Act submissions. OMB staff and Treasury officials also told GAO that OMB and Treasury have taken steps to address issues GAO previously reported related to their oversight of agencies' implementation of the DATA Act. For example, OMB issued new guidance requiring agencies to develop data quality plans intended to achieve the objectives of the DATA Act. Treasury has taken some steps and is continuing to take steps to address these recommendations. What GAO Recommends GAO is not making any new recommendations in this report.
gao_GAO-17-775: Why GAO Did This Study GPRAMA, enacted in 2010, requires the executive branch to take a more crosscutting and integrated approach to focusing on results and improving government performance. GPRAMA also requires GAO to periodically review the implementation of GPRAMA. This report examines (1) the status of GPRAMA implementation and (2) the extent to which federal managers use performance information in decision making. GAO analyzed GPRAMA and related OMB guidance and surveyed federal managers on their use of performance information. GAO also reviewed relevant GPRAMA and related GAO reports. What GAO Found The executive branch has made progress in some areas, but continued attention is needed to better manage crosscutting issues. GPRAMA establishes a framework aimed at taking a more crosscutting and integrated approach to focusing on results and improving government performance. GPRAMA requires agencies to establish cross-agency priority (CAP) goals, agency priority goals (APG), and related data-driven reviews. However, GAO found that the executive branch and Congress addressed 145 (46 percent) of the 315 actions. For example, in November 2014, GAO recommended that the U.S. Coast Guard and Consumer Product Safety Commission establish a formal approach to coordination (such as a memorandum of understanding) to facilitate information sharing; better leverage their resources; and address challenges, including those related to fragmentation and overlap. GAO's 2017 survey of federal managers shows that CAP goals, APGs, and related data-driven reviews are associated with higher levels of collaboration with internal and external stakeholders. However, GAO found that the Office of Management and Budget (OMB) recently removed the priority status of the current sets of CAP goals and directed agencies to remove the priority designation from APGs, returning them to regular performance goals. OMB staff told GAO that they believe they were working in line with the intentions of GPRAMA, which realigned the timing of goal setting with presidential terms, to better take into account changes in priorities. OMB staff also stated that although the goals no longer had priority designations, work towards them largely continued in 2017. Effectively implementing various GPRAMA tools could help inform assessments of the performance of tax expenditures, which represent over $1 trillion in annual forgone revenue. GAO's past work has found that little has been done to determine how well specific tax expenditures work to achieve their stated purposes and how their benefits and costs compare to those of spending programs with similar goals. Fully implementing GPRAMA's recommendation to identify how tax expenditures contribute to various goals could help the federal government establish a process for evaluating the performance of tax expenditures. GAO's 2017 survey of federal managers shows little change in their reported use of performance information. Using a set of survey questions, GAO previously developed an index that reflects the extent to which managers reported that their agencies used performance information for various management activities and decision making. The index suggests that government-wide use of performance information did not change significantly between 2013 and 2017, and it is statistically significantly lower relative to GAO's 2007 survey, when the item was introduced. GPRAMA requires agencies to conduct strategic reviews of their progress toward achieving each strategic objective. However, GAO's 2017 survey results show that federal managers remain largely unfamiliar with their agency's data-driven performance reviews, also known as quarterly performance reviews (QPRs). GPRAMA requires agencies to conduct quarterly QPRs for APGs, but OMB guidance does not identify practices for agencies to expand the use of these reviews to other goals, such as other agency-wide performance goals or those at lower levels within the agency. GPRAMA requires agencies to identify an agency official responsible for resolving major management challenges, which can help ensure accountability. However, GAO found that 17 of the 24 Chief Financial Officers Act agencies had not identified an agency official responsible for resolving major management challenges, which could help ensure accountability. GAO continues to believe that identifying an agency official responsible for resolving major management challenges is important. What GAO Recommends GAO is making three recommendations to OMB to improve the implementation of GPRAMA. OMB staff generally agreed with the recommendations, but have not yet taken any actions to implement them.
gao_GAO-18-153T: Why GAO Did This Study IRS relies extensively on IT to carry out its mission of providing America's taxpayers top quality service. Effective management of IT is critical for agencies to achieve successful outcomes. This is particularly true for IRS, given the role of IT in enabling the agency to carry out its mission and responsibilities. GAO has reported on a number of IRS's major investments, including the Affordable Care Act and Customer Account Data Engine 2, which are intended to replace IRS's authoritative data source for individual tax account data. GAO was asked to testify on its work on IRS's management of its modernization activities and legacy systems. This statement addresses (1) the extent to which IRS has made progress in modernizing its IT systems and (2) the challenges IRS faces in managing its aging legacy systems. This statement is based on GAO's prior work on IRS's modernization activities and legacy systems. What GAO Found The Internal Revenue Service (IRS) relies extensively on information technology (IT) to carry out its mission. For fiscal year 2016, IRS was pursuing 23 major and 114 non-major IT investments to carry out its mission. According to the agency, it expended approximately $2.7 billion on these investments during fiscal year 2016, including $1.9 billion, or 70 percent, for operations and maintenance activities, and approximately $800 million, or 30 percent, for development, modernization, and enhancement. GAO has previously reported on a number of the agency's major investments, to include the following investments in development, modernization, and enhancement: The Affordable Care Act investment encompasses the planning, development, and implementation of IT systems needed to support tax administration responsibilities associated with key provisions of the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act. IRS expended $253 million on this investment in fiscal year 2016. Customer Account Data Engine 2 is being developed to replace the Individual Master File investment, IRS's authoritative data source for individual tax account data. A major component of the program is a modernized database for all individual taxpayers that is intended to provide the foundation for more efficient and effective tax administration and help address financial material weaknesses for individual taxpayer accounts. Customer Account Data Engine 2 data is also expected to be made available for access by downstream systems, such as the Integrated Data Retrieval System for online transaction processing by IRS customer service representatives. IRS expended $182.6 million on this investment in fiscal year 2016. The Return Review Program is IRS's system of record for fraud detection. As such, it is intended to enhance the agency's capabilities to detect, resolve, and prevent criminal and civil tax noncompliance. In addition, it is intended to allow analysis and support of complex case processing requirements for compliance and criminal investigation programs during prosecution, revenue protection, accounts management, and taxpayer communications processes. According to IRS, as of May 2017, the system has helped protect over $4.5 billion in revenue. IRS expended $100.2 million on this investment in fiscal year 2016. GAO, Congress, and the Administration have highlighted the need for government-wide improvements for IT acquisitions and operations. gao_GAO-19-199: Why GAO Did This Study DOD has a demanding responsibility to provide a high level of management and accountability to its employees and the Congress. This report examines the extent to which DOD has implemented the CMO position and issued guidance communicating within the department the authorities and responsibilities of the position. GAO reviewed relevant laws and DOD guidance, and interviewed DOD officials. What GAO Found The Department of Defense (DOD) has taken some steps to implement its Chief Management Officer (CMO) position, but key issues related to the CMO's authorities and responsibilities remain unresolved. In February 2018, DOD formally established the position of the CMO and an office in support of the CMO (OCMO). In establishing the office, the Secretary of Defense stated that all resources and personnel (military, civilian, and contractor) assigned within the existing DCMO office were to transfer to the OCMO. Generally, the department has been focused on updating organizational structures and strengthening the OCMO's data capabilities. Despite its efforts to establish and restructure the OCMO, DOD has not fully addressed three key issues related to the CMO's statutory authorities and responsibilities, including: (1) how the CMO will exercise the authority to direct the military departments; (2) how the CMO will exercise oversight of the Defense Agencies and DOD Field Activities (DAFA) that provide shared business services; and (3) which responsibilities, if any, will transfer from the CIO to the CMO. DOD leadership has provided some guidance regarding the CMO's responsibilities for efforts that are department-wide and therefore involve the military departments. However, DOD leadership has not determined how the CMO will exercise this authority in instances where the military departments have concerns or disagree with decisions that the CMO makes. In one case, officials from the military departments questioned the CMO's authority to make binding decisions; in the other, the military departments sought to pursue reform activities without CMO involvement and oversight, even though the CMO has responsibility for leading DOD's enterprise business reform efforts. Without a determination by the Secretary or Deputy Secretary of Defense about how the CMO is to direct the business-related activities of the military departments, the CMO's ability to lead DOD's reform of its enterprise business operations and to direct the military departments may be limited, potentially leading to fragmented business reform efforts.
