gao_GAO-19-162: Why GAO Did This Study TSA is responsible for securing U.S.-bound air cargo, including passenger and all-cargo air carriers. TSA inspects air carriers and assesses foreign airports to help ensure compliance with TSA security requirements. GAO was asked to review TSA's efforts to secure U.S.-bound air cargo. This report (1) describes steps TSA takes to help ensure that U.S.-bound air cargo is secure, (2) describes the status of TSA's efforts to recognize and monitor foreign governments' air cargo security programs, and (3) analyzes the extent to which TSA measures the effectiveness of its efforts to secure U.S.-bound air cargo. GAO reviewed TSA documents and interviewed TSA officials, air carrier representatives, and foreign government officials. GAO also conducted site visits to two foreign airports that transport U.S.-bound air cargo to the United States. What GAO Found To help ensure compliance with cargo security requirements and international standards, the Transportation Security Administration (TSA) inspects air carriers and assesses certain known consignors and regulated agents. TSA also inspects cargo security procedures during foreign airport assessments. Further, the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) has also implemented requirements to obtain advance information on air cargo shipments through ACAS that it uses to perform targeted risk assessments. TSA has recognized the passenger air cargo security programs of the European Union and 12 other countries and monitors their implementation. TSA has also recognized the all-cargo portions of the European Union national cargo security program (NCSP) and has revalidated all recognized NCSPs at least once since fiscal year 2012. TSA has taken steps to broadly measure the effectiveness of its air carrier inspections and foreign airport assessments, but these efforts do not allow TSA to specifically determine the effectiveness of the cargo portions of such inspections or assessments. For example, TSA developed a new performance measure to track the extent to which foreign airports take actions to address noncompliance issues identified by TSA inspectors during foreign airport assessments. However, that performance measure does not allow TSA to determine the effectiveness of the cargo portions of airport assessments because it does not separately account for cargo and noncargo noncompliance issues. Developing and monitoring outcome-based performance measures for the cargo portions of airport assessments and differentiating the extent to which air carriers correct violations related to cargo from those related to passengers as it develops and monitors outcome-based performance measures for its air carrier inspection program could help TSA better assess the effectiveness of these efforts and whether they are improving the security of U.S.-bound air cargo. What GAO Recommends GAO recommends that TSA (1) develop and monitor outcome-based performance measures for the cargo portions of foreign airport assessments and (2) differentiate the extent to which air carriers correct violations related to cargo from those related to passengers as it develops and monitors outcome-based performance measures for its air carrier inspection program. DHS concurred with GAO's recommendations.
gao_GAO-18-364: Why GAO Did This Study The Marine Corps is developing a new ACV, which is intended to replace the AAV. The ACV is a tracked vehicle with capability to launch from ships to reach the shore carrying up to 21 Marines at a speed of up to approximately 6 knots. The Marine Corps is also developing a new ACV increment, which is scheduled to begin in February 2019. The ACV program is a two-phase strategy for selecting a contractor to produce the ACV fleet. In the first phase, the program issued a solicitation for offerors to submit proposals and provided for award of multiple contracts for each contractor to design and develop 16 prototypes for performance assessment. In the second phase, referred to as the down-select process, after testing the prototypes, the Marine Corps intends to select a single contractor to continue into the production phase. The Marine Corps received five initial proposals and ultimately awarded contracts to BAE and SAIC to develop the ACV prototypes. The Marine Corps considered the ACV to be a substantially non-developmental item because both contractors' designs were based on vehicles that were already in production and deployed by other militaries. The Marine Corps has made no major changes to the ACV acquisition schedule since GAO previously reported on the program in April 2017. This report examines (1) the status of the ACV program's development and acquisition, (2) the extent to which the ACV program is on track to meet cost goals, and (3) the extent to which the ACV program is considering entering production without meeting established best practices for manufacturing maturity. GAO reviewed the ACV program's development and acquisition documents and interviewed program officials. What GAO Found The Marine Corps' ACV program is on track to meet cost goals established at the start of development, based on a recent Navy estimate, the ACV program office, and reporting from the contractors. In September 2017, the ACV program's Defense Acquisition Executive Summary Report for ACV provided a Navy cost estimate for development of $750.7 million, less than the $810.5 million baseline established at the start of development in November 2015. Program officials also indicated that the ACV program was on track to meet cost goals. They noted that the contractors have not contacted the government to negotiate an increase in billing prices, as of December 2017. Since both of the contractors have delivered all 16 of their required prototypes and the manufacturing of the prototypes is the largest anticipated portion of ACV development contract costs, most of the costs associated with the manufacturing of the prototypes have likely been realized. The Marine Corps has made no major changes to the ACV acquisition schedule since GAO previously reported on the program in April 2017. The ACV program office is in the process of conducting tests and assessments to determine if the program is on track to meet the criteria to enter production, but program officials told GAO the Navy—which has the authority to approve major acquisition milestone decisions for the program—may choose to start low-rate production without meeting established best practices for manufacturing maturity. At the start of development, DOD established criteria for entering production in areas such as capability performance and the status of the contractors' manufacturing readiness to manufacture the ACV vehicles. Leading up to the production decision, the program is engaged in a number of activities such as the operational assessment and production readiness review to inform the decision to enter production. The production readiness review has a critical role in informing the decision to enter production because it represents an opportunity for the program to determine the maturity of the contractor's manufacturing process and assess potential risks related to cost, schedule, or performance. GAO's previous reviews about manufacturing best practices found that identifying manufacturing risks early in the acquisition cycle and assessing those risks prior to key decision points, such as the decision to enter production, reduces the likelihood of cost growth and potential delays. The ACV program has used the DOD Manufacturing Readiness Level (MRL) Deskbook to identify levels of manufacturing capability and establish targets for minimal levels of manufacturing readiness at specific acquisition milestones. The MRL Deskbook recommends that a program is expected to demonstrate a MRL of 8 by the time of the low-rate production decision. However, GAO's previously identified best practices for managing manufacturing risks recommend programs reach a higher level—MRL-9—for the risk area of process capability and control before entering low-rate production. The program office confirmed that the MRL criterion for entering production is to achieve an MRL-8 but noted that it is possible that the program could choose to enter production without an overall MRL-8. Program officials stated that they will keep the review open until April 2018, at which point the program will make a determination about the contractors' manufacturing readiness levels. gao_GAO-18-194: Why GAO Did This Study DOD has historically faced organizational and management challenges that can limit effective and efficient coordination across the department. Congress required DOD to develop an organizational strategy to advance a collaborative culture across the department and create cross-functional teams to address critical objectives and outputs. Section 911 of the NDAA for Fiscal Year 2017 required GAO to review DOD's efforts to establish cross-functional teams. This report examines (1) the extent to which DOD's draft organizational strategy addresses statutory elements and (2) the extent to which DOD has developed, but not provided, training for its presidential appointees and cross-functional team members. GAO reviewed DOD's draft organizational strategy and interviewed DOD officials. What GAO Found The Office of the Secretary of Defense's (DOD) Chief Management Officer (CMO) developed a draft organizational strategy that addresses the two statutory elements required under section 911 of the National Defense Authorization Act (NDAA) for Fiscal Year 2017—identifying critical objectives and outputs that would benefit from the use of cross-functional teams, and providing for the appropriate use of these teams—but DOD has not issued that strategy as required by September 1, 2017. In addition, while the draft strategy contains the two required elements, it does not outline how DOD will achieve several future outcomes required under section 911 of the NDAA for Fiscal Year 2017 that are designed to advance a collaborative culture within the department. Further, ODCMO officials did not coordinate with key stakeholders, such as the Secretary of Defense, military departments, and defense agencies, in developing the organizational strategy. GAO's leading practices for collaboration highlight the value of agencies including stakeholders when defining and articulating a common outcome. DOD has established one Secretary of Defense-empowered cross-functional team, and draft team guidance addresses most statutory elements and leading practices. The draft guidance fully addresses six and partially addresses one of the statutory elements. GAO also found that the draft guidance partially addresses two leading practices, partially addresses two leading practices, and does not address one leading practice for effective cross-functional teams. DOD has developed, but not provided, training for its presidential appointees and cross-functional team members, and it does not address all statutory requirements. As of October 2017, the ODCMO developed a draft training curriculum on cross-functional teams for presidential appointees, but this curriculum does not address all statutory requirements. Furthermore, as of February 2018, 22 individuals have been nominated by the President, confirmed by the Senate, and appointed to positions within the Office of the Secretary of Defense, but none have received training required by section 911. Without the provision of training for top leadership within the Office of the Secretary of Defense that includes the required elements in section 911 or developing criteria for obtaining a waiver from providing the training, DOD may have difficulty implementing its new organizational strategy as top leadership commitment is a key element of an organizational transformation. What GAO Recommends GAO recommends that DOD (1) obtain stakeholder input on the development of the draft organizational strategy, (2) provide training for presidential appointees to positions within the Office of the Secretary of Defense that includes the required elements, and (3) develop criteria for obtaining a waiver from providing the training. DOD concurred with GAO's recommendations.
gao_GAO-18-63: Why GAO Did This Study VAMCs are responsible for ensuring that veterans receive safe, high quality care. GAO was asked to review VAMCs' oversight of providers' clinical care. This report examines (1) the extent to which VAMCs have documented and conducted reviews of providers' clinical care after concerns were raised and (2) the extent to which selected VAMCs reported providers to the NPDB and SLBs in accordance with VHA policy. GAO reviewed VHA policy and guidance, interviewed VAMC officials, and analyzed VHA data on the number of providers reported to the NPDB and SLBs. What GAO Found GAO found that the five selected Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) medical centers (VAMC) collectively required reviews of 148 providers' clinical care after concerns were raised from October 2013 through March 2017, but VAMC officials were unable to provide documentation that almost half of these reviews were conducted. GAO found that all five VAMCs lacked at least some documentation of the reviews they told GAO they conducted, and in some cases the required reviews were not conducted at all. GAO also found that VHA does not adequately oversee VAMC reviews of providers' clinical care after concerns have been raised, including ensuring that these reviews are completed and documented in a timely manner. VHA policy requires VAMCs to alert certain entities if there are serious concerns about a provider's clinical performance. VHA policy assigns reporting responsibility and authority to the VAMC director, who generally delegates the task of reporting to other VAMC officials. VHA makes this information available to other health care entities through two distinct reporting processes: the National Provider Data Bank (NPDB) and the Special Litigation Bureau (SLB). Under VHA policy, VAMC directors are required to report to the NPDB any adverse privileging action the facility takes that 1) affects the clinical privileges of a provider for a period longer than 30 days and 2) is related to professional incompetence or professional misconduct. What GAO Recommends GAO recommends that VA specify in VHA policy that reviews of providers' clinical care after concerns have been raised should be documented, including retrospective and comprehensive reviews; that VISN officials oversee VAMC reviews of providers' clinical care after concerns have been raised, including retrospective and comprehensive reviews; and that VISN officials oversee VAMCs to ensure that they are reporting providers to the NPDB and SLBs, and are reporting in a timely manner. gao_GAO-18-48: Why GAO Did This Study The federal government is a large and complex entity with a demanding responsibility to achieve its mission. The federal government has a long history of misconduct, including retaliation for whistleblowing. GAO was asked to examine the process for addressing misconduct and to identify any challenges in removing employees for misconduct. This report examines (1) the process that agencies are generally required to follow in responding to employee misconduct in the federal service; (2) alternative approaches to the formal legal process that agencies can use to respond to misconduct, and assess what factors affect agencies' responses; (3) describe trends in removals and other adverse actions resulting from misconduct; and (4) identify key steps agencies can take to help them better prevent and address misconduct. GAO reviewed relevant statutes, regulations, and OPM regulations; analyzed OPM data from fiscal years 2006 to 2016; and interviewed OPM, MSPB, and subject-matter experts. What GAO Found Most agencies are required to adhere to formal, statutorily established guidelines under Title 5 of the U.S. Code (herein Chapter 75) when taking adverse actions against an employee for misconduct. Chapter 75 contains two subsections that outline the requirements for (1) non-appealable adverse actions such as suspensions of 14 days or less or (2) appealable adverse actions such as reductions in pay or grade, suspensions of more than 14 days, and removals. Agencies may take an adverse action under Chapter 75 only for such cause as will promote the efficiency of the service. Agencies may also take an adverse action under Chapter 75 only for such cause as will promote the efficiency of the service. Agencies may use progressive discipline to help determine which course of action to take when responding to misconduct. Agencies may choose to offer alternative discipline at any stage of the disciplinary process. According to MSPB, agencies may choose to offer alternative discipline at any stage of the disciplinary process. OPM officials said alternative disciplines tend to be more focused on taking a corrective or remedial response rather than punitive actions against an employee. According to subject-matter experts, alternative discipline approaches are not appropriate for egregious acts of misconduct or when the employee is remorseless but rather lower level offenses where an employee may show remorse for the misconduct and demonstrate that she or she can be rehabilitated. According to MSPB, alternative discipline approaches are not appropriate for egregious acts of misconduct or when the employee is remorseless but rather lower level offenses where an employee may show remorse for the misconduct and demonstrate that she or she can be rehabilitated. According to subject-matter experts, agency managers and supervisors may be able to effectively resolve employee misconduct cases through the use of alternative approaches, which can shorten the timeline and simplify the adverse action process in a manner that has the most potential to prevent additional harm to the workplace and avoid the potentially high costs of litigating a misconduct case. GAO's analysis of Office of Personnel Management (OPM) data from fiscal years 2006 to 2016 shows that, on average, agencies disciplined approximately 17,000 or less than 1 percent of the federal workforce per year under Subchapter II of Chapter 75. The number of employees who separate from the federal workforce for misconduct under alternative means, such as settlements, is not known and would not be recorded as misconduct in OPM's Enterprise Human Resources Integration (EHRI) database, according to agency officials and experts. OPM collects data on personnel actions reported by most agencies and stores this information in the EHRI database, but these data could be improved to provide OPM with better information to help agencies address misconduct. Because not all misconduct data are entered into the database, the data presented in this report do not represent the entirety of employee misconduct instances that occur in the federal government. OPM officials said they do not have a sense of how frequently agencies use these (and other non-specific nature of action) codes for misconduct-related actions. Without maintaining comprehensive data regarding the extent and nature of misconduct in the federal government, OPM risks missing opportunities to provide agencies with guidance and other tools, such as targeted training to help agencies better address cases of misconduct. What GAO Recommends GAO recommends that OPM explore the feasibility of improving the quality of data on employee misconduct by providing additional guidance to agencies on how to record instances of misconduct in OPM's databases. OPM partially concurred with the recommendations, but did not concur with one recommendation. GAO maintains that the recommendations are valid as discussed in the report.
gao_GAO-18-141T: Why GAO Did This Study The Bureau estimates that the cost of the 2020 Census will be about $12.5 billion dollars (in 2020 dollars). The Bureau has fundamentally re-examined its approach for conducting the 2020 Census. Specifically, its plan for 2020 includes four broad innovation areas (re-engineering field operations, using administrative records, verifying addresses in-office, and developing an Internet self-response option). GAO was asked to review the Bureau's progress in implementing these innovations. This statement addresses (1) the Bureau's plans for 2020, (2) the challenges the Bureau faces in implementing and managing key IT systems, and (3) the reliability of the Bureau's 2020 Census cost estimate. This statement is based on GAO's ongoing work on the Bureau's efforts to re-examine its approach for conducting the 2020 Census. GAO reviewed the Bureau's plans for 2020, interviewed Bureau officials, and visited three test sites. What GAO Found The U.S. Census Bureau (Bureau) plans to use four innovation areas for the 2020 Census: re-engineering field operations, using administrative records, verifying addresses in-office, and developing an Internet self-response option. The Bureau has estimated that these innovations could result in savings of over $5 billion (in 2020 dollars) when compared to its estimates of the cost for conducting the census with traditional methods. However, the innovations also introduce new risks, in part, because they include new procedures and technology that have not been used extensively in earlier decennials, if at all. GAO's prior work has shown the importance of the Bureau conducting a robust testing program, including the 2018 Census Test. However, because of funding uncertainty the Bureau canceled the field components of the 2017 Census Test, including non-response follow-up, a key census operation. In May 2017, the Bureau scaled back the operational scope of the 2018 End-to-End Test and, of the three planned test sites, only the Rhode Island site would fully implement the 2018 End-to-End Test. The Bureau also plans to use administrative records to support quality control during its non-response field enumeration. However, the Bureau has not developed cost and quality information on address canvassing projects, and detailed information on cost tradeoffs was not available when GAO requested it. The Bureau continues to face challenges in managing and overseeing IT programs, systems, and contractors supporting the 2020 Census. Specifically, it has been challenged in managing schedules, costs, contracts, and governance and internal coordination for its IT systems. As a result of these challenges, the Bureau is at risk of being unable to fully implement key IT systems necessary to support the 2020 Census. GAO has previously recommended that the Bureau take action to improve its implementation and management of IT in areas such as governance and internal coordination. GAO also has ongoing work reviewing each of these areas. The Bureau's October 2015 update of its life-cycle cost estimate for the 2020 Census did not conform to the four characteristics that constitute best practices, and, as a result, the estimate was unreliable. Cost estimates that appropriately account for risks facing an agency can help an agency manage large, complex activities like the 2020 Census, as well as help Congress make funding decisions and provide oversight. Cost estimates are also necessary to inform decisions to fund one program over another, to develop annual budget requests, to determine what resources are needed, and to develop baselines for measuring performance. In June 2016, GAO reported that, although the Bureau had taken steps to improve its capacity to carry out an effective cost estimate, its October 2015 update of its life-cycle cost estimate for the 2020 Census did not conform to the four characteristics that constitute best practices, and, as a result, the estimate was unreliable. Cost estimates that appropriately account for risks facing an agency can help an agency manage large, complex activities like the 2020 Census, as well as help Congress make funding decisions and provide oversight. Cost estimates are also necessary to inform decisions to fund one program over another, to develop annual budget requests, to determine what resources are needed, and to develop baselines for measuring performance. What GAO Recommends GAO has previously made recommendations to the Bureau to improve its implementation and management of IT in areas such as governance and internal coordination. The Department of Commerce agreed with GAO's recommendations.
gao_GAO-18-207: Why GAO Did This Study The Small Business Act requires agencies to evaluate whether small businesses have met a minimum performance standard for commercializing their technology. SBA and the 11 participating agencies are to assess small businesses against the benchmarks, which measure the rate at which businesses move projects from phase I to phase II. GAO was asked to review SBA's and the participating agencies' efforts to implement the benchmarks. This report examines (1) the extent to which SBA and the participating agencies have assessed small businesses against the benchmarks and (2) the consequences for small businesses not meeting the benchmarks. GAO reviewed SBA and participating agency documents and interviewed SBA and participating agency officials. GAO also reviewed SBA and participating agency project solicitations and SBA's policy directives. What GAO Found Data challenges have limited the Small Business Administration's (SBA) and the 11 participating agencies' efforts to fully implement the Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) and Small Business Technology Transfer (STTR) benchmarks. SBA and the participating agencies have regularly assessed small businesses against the Transition Rate Benchmark, which, in general, measures the rate at which businesses move projects from phase I to phase II. From 2014 through 2017, SBA determined that 4 to 7 small businesses did not meet the benchmark each year and placed those businesses on a list of those ineligible to receive certain additional awards. However, GAO found instances in which the data used to generate the list were inaccurate or incomplete. For example, GAO identified more than 2,700 small businesses that had multiple records with different spellings of the same business's name. SBA officials told GAO that the quality of the award information in the database has been an issue, and that accurate information is important because small businesses may avoid being identified as subject to the benchmark if their business names and identification numbers are different across multiple records. SBA and the participating agencies do not know the extent to which small businesses are meeting the Commercialization Benchmark because SBA and the participating agencies have assessed businesses against the benchmark only once, in 2014, when SBA determined that 12 businesses did not meet the benchmark. This is in part because, according to officials from SBA and several agencies, they cannot collect and verify the accuracy of the data needed to implement the benchmark as written. Working together to find a way to implement the benchmark as designed or revise it so that it can be implemented could allow the agencies to fulfill the requirement in the Small Business Act to evaluate whether small businesses have met a minimum performance standard for commercializing their technology. SBA and the participating agencies have provided inconsistent information to small businesses about the consequence of not meeting the benchmarks. SBA officials told GAO that they and the participating agencies sought to change how to implement the consequence because of SBA's and agencies' difficulties in implementing the benchmarks. SBA and the participating agencies agreed to change how the consequence would be implemented, starting in 2017, so that small businesses that do not meet the benchmarks are ineligible to submit proposals, according to SBA officials. As of November 2017, however, the information available about this new way to implement the consequence was inconsistent because some of the agencies had not updated their project solicitations. Specifically, information in the most recent project solicitations available at that time for 2 agencies and one subunit of an agency stated that businesses that do not meet the benchmarks are ineligible to submit certain proposals, consistent with the revised approach for how to implement the consequence. However, the most recent project solicitations available at that time for 7 other agencies and the other subunit of the agency stated that those businesses that do not meet the benchmarks are ineligible to receive certain awards, consistent with the prior approach for how to implement the consequence. What GAO Recommends GAO recommends that SBA work with participating agencies to improve the reliability of its SBIR and STTR award data and revise the benchmark so that it can be implemented. SBA agreed with the recommendations.
gao_GAO-19-211: Why GAO Did This Study The Department of Defense (DOD) is responsible for executing the global war on terrorism. DOD's overseas contingency operations (OCO) are the largest and most complex operations in the world. Congress appropriates funds for DOD's OCO and base activities through appropriations. Congress also has the discretion to make available OCO and base funding through OCO appropriations. GAO was asked to review DOD's processes for separating the funding of OCO and base amounts. This report describes (1) selected DOD components' use of internal controls to separately account for OCO and base amounts, and (2) alternatives to the current processes that Congress and DOD use to separate funding for DOD's OCO and base activities. GAO reviewed documentation of DOD components' use of internal controls to separate OCO and base amounts. GAO also interviewed DOD officials and subject matter experts. What GAO Found The DOD components in GAO's review use coding and other internal control activities to separately account for OCO and base amounts in their operation and maintenance (O&M) accounts during budget execution. To record and track OCO and base amounts separately, the DOD components use coding in their financial systems during the allotment, obligation, and disbursement of funds. For example, during the allotment phase, the Army and the Defense Security Cooperation Agency use codes in their financial systems to divide, distribute, and track their appropriated funds into separate categories—including one for OCO and one for base. The Air Force, the Marine Corps, and the Navy use specific codes to track OCO transactions within multiple systems they use to allot and obligate OCO and base amounts. GAO identified some internal control activities that the DOD components in GAO's review have put into place to ensure separate accounting of OCO and base amounts, such as controls over information processing. GAO identified at least four alternatives to the current processes that Congress and DOD use to separate funding for DOD's OCO and base activities. Each alternative would require action at different phases of DOD's budget process and entail tradeoffs. For example, adding specific purpose language would better align obligation of OCO amounts with congressional intent; however, doing so could also reduce DOD's financial flexibility and responsiveness to changes in operations. Understanding the implications of each alternative is important to avoid unintended consequences. GAO summarized the positive and negative aspects of the alternatives reported by respondents to a questionnaire that GAO sent to Congress and DOD. What GAO Recommends GAO is not making any recommendations in this report. DOD provided technical comments on the draft report, which GAO incorporated as appropriate.
gao_GAO-18-557: Why GAO Did This Study DOD spends billions of dollars on airlift services, including airlift cargo, military aircraft, and commercial aircraft. The TWCF is a component of the Air Force Working Capital Fund, which is used to provide airlift services to support DOD operations. The TWCF is authorized to establish airlift customer rates to be competitive with commercial air carriers. Due to mobilization requirements, the resulting revenue does not always cover the full costs of airlift operations. GAO was asked to review the ARA. This report examines (1) the extent to which ARA funds were requested, allotted, and expended by the Air Force from fiscal years 2007 through 2017, and the annual amounts expended by the Air Force; (2) the extent to which the Air Force provided ARA information in its budget request to Congress and informed its request with information from TRANSCOM; and (3) the extent to which TRANSCOM has implemented a process to set rates for airlift services and use workload forecasts to estimate the annual ARA funding request. GAO analyzed budget and financial data for fiscal years 2007 through 2017 and interviewed officials from the Air Force and TRANSCOM. What GAO Found The Air Force requested, allotted, and expended billions of dollars for the Transportation Working Capital Fund (TWCF) for fiscal years 2007 through 2017. These amounts varied annually, in some cases, by hundreds of millions of dollars. GAO's analysis of Air Force and TRANSCOM budget and financial information showed that for fiscal years 2007 through 2017, the Air Force requested $2.8 billion from Congress for ARA requirements, as part of its annual Operations and Maintenance appropriation. The Air Force allotted $2.8 billion (i.e., directed the use of the appropriated funds) and expended $2.4 billion of the ARA appropriated funds. During this period, the total allotted amount was about $400 million dollars more than the expended amount. According to Air Force officials, this $400 million was used to pay for other Air Force readiness priorities. The Air Force budget requests include some information on the ARA but omit details provided in budget requests prior to fiscal year 2010. Air Force budget officials stated that the ARA budget information that was included for fiscal years 2007 through 2009 was changed for the fiscal year 2010 budget request as part of a DOD initiative to reduce the overall number of budget line items. For fiscal years 2007 through 2009, the ARA amount was explicitly stated in the budget justification documents as part of a separate subactivity group line item. For fiscal years 2010 through 2017, the ARA amount was bundled with funding requests for other training requirements in the Air Force Operations and Maintenance budget justification documents, thus omitting specific details with respect to the ARA. Without establishing specific requirements to present detailed ARA information in the annual Air Force Operations and Maintenance budget request, DOD and congressional decision-makers do not have sufficient information to make informed decisions about the level of funding necessary to cover airlift costs not recovered by the rates charged by TRANSCOM. TRANSCOM has not provided ARA estimates in time to inform Air Force budget requests. Air Force officials stated that they need to have TRANSCOM's estimates by mid-June to be able to conduct analysis to strengthen confidence in the ARA budget request and obtain senior leadership approval. The Air Force submits its Operations and Maintenance annual budget request to DOD in early July. However, TRANSCOM was not providing its ARA estimate until August. As a result, Air Force officials stated they have been developing their own ARA estimate based on historical average trends because they have not received information from TRANSCOM on time. TRANSCOM has a rate-setting process for airlift services, but producing accurate workload forecasts is challenging. GAO's analysis of TRANSCOM data showed that the airlift forecasting process produced increasingly inaccurate projections of actual workload. Producing accurate forecasts is challenging because TRANSCOM has not fully implemented: (1) an effective process to gather workload projections from its customers (i.e., military services) to inform its forecasts, (2) forecasting goals and metrics and the review of its performance, and (3) an action plan to improve workload forecasting. What GAO Recommends GAO recommends that the Secretary of Defense (1) establish requirements to present detailed ARA information in the annual Air Force Operations and Maintenance budget request, (2) finalize the memorandum of understanding to improve the timing and communication of budgetary information from TRANSCOM, and (3) fully implement a process to gather projected workload information from its customers, use forecast accuracy metrics and goals to monitor its performance, and develop a corrective action plan to improve workload forecasting. DOD concurred with GAO's recommendations.
gao_GAO-18-389: Why GAO Did This Study The Zika virus is a mosquito-borne disease that can cause permanent death and death. The Zika virus is primarily transmitted to humans by infected mosquitoes, but can also be transmitted from mother to child during pregnancy or around the time of birth, or from person-to-person through sexual contact or blood transfusion. What GAO Found The Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) agencies have obligated nearly all of the Zika supplemental funding as of September 30, 2017, primarily through cooperative agreements, grants, and contracts. These factors include time to draw down funding from the federal agencies, allowing for program implementation and a planning period, and awardees' internal administrative processes and unique characteristics. Collectively, the activities included four primary types: medical surveillance, vector control, laboratory capacity building, and providing health care services. For example, Florida used Zika supplemental funding for laboratory capacity and vector control activities, among other activities. Florida also used Zika supplemental funding for local vector control activities. Health care service activities for those selected awardees that received funding from CMS (Florida and Texas) included increasing access to contraceptive services for men and women; increasing access to and reducing barriers to diagnostic testing, screening, and counseling for pregnant women and newborns; and increasing access to appropriate specialized health care services for pregnant women, children born to mothers with maternal Zika virus infection, and their families. gao_GAO-18-91: Why GAO Did This Study Federal agencies face mission-critical skills gaps that pose a risk to agencies' ability to cost effectively serve the public and achieve results. gao_GAO-18-300: Why GAO Did This Study The National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2017 required DOD to submit an implementation plan to Congress for the new Joint Trauma System (JTS) in June 2017. gao_GAO-19-54: Why GAO Did This Study Section 813 of the National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2017 requires DOD to revise the Defense Finance and Accounting Standards Regulation (DFARS) to require that the LPTA process be used in situations where there would not be any value on a product or service exceeding the required technical or performance requirements. Section 813 also requires GAO to report on DOD's use of the LPTA process. This report examines (1) the number and percentage of contracts and orders competitively awarded by the Army, Navy, Air Force, and DLA valued at $5 million and above in fiscal year 2017 and (2) the reasons contracting officials used the LPTA process. GAO reviewed the 46 contracts and orders for which the Army, Navy, Air Force, and DLA used the LPTA process and found that 20 were for products and 26 for services. GAO also interviewed DOD contracting officials. What GAO Found Based upon the results of GAO's generalizable sample, GAO estimates that about 26 percent of contracts and orders competitively awarded by the Army, Navy, Air Force, and DLA valued at $5 million and above in fiscal year 2017 used the Low Price Tradeoff (LPTA) process. Contracting officials associated with the 14 contracts and orders GAO reviewed used the LPTA process, in part, because they determined there was no tradeoff available or determined that DOD would not derive any benefit from paying a premium for offers that exceeded the minimum capabilities. Contracting officials stated that they generally considered five of the eight criteria in Section 813 when awarding the 14 contracts and orders GAO reviewed. This was done, in part, because according to contracting officials, those criteria are inherently considered by contracting officials when determining which source selection process should be used. Further, based on GAO's analysis, these five criteria are generally reflected in DOD's March 2016 Source Selection Procedures. A Defense Pricing and Contracting official stated that the DFARS is in the process of being updated and will reflect Section 813. A DPC official stated that the DFARS is in the process of being updated and will reflect Section 813. A DPC official, however, could not comment on whether the revisions will provide clarification, beyond what was written in Section 813, on how to apply the two criteria that DOD contracting officials generally found confusing. Without further clarification, such confusion is likely to continue. As a result, contracting officials across DOD may not understand how to consistently apply these criteria when using the LPTA process. What GAO Recommends GAO recommends that DOD (1) ensure that contracting officials address how contracting officials using the LPTA process should apply Section 813 criteria regarding procurement for goods that are predominantly expendable in nature, nontechnical, or have a short life expectancy or shelf life as revisions to the DFARS are considered; and (2) ensure that contracting officials address how contracting officials using the LPTA process should apply Section 813 criteria regarding full life-cycle costs, including for operations and support as revisions to the DFARS are considered. DOD concurred with both recommendations.
gao_GAO-18-209T: Why GAO Did This Study The SPR stores oil in underground salt caverns along the Gulf Coast in Louisiana and Texas. The SPR is managed by DOE, which has a target capacity of 500 million barrels. The SPR is expected to hold between 506 and 513 million barrels of oil by 2025. The SPR is also a component of the International Energy Agency's (IEA) regional refined product reserves. GAO was asked to review the SPR. This statement addresses (1) how DOE has used the SPR to address domestic petroleum supply disruptions, (2) the extent to which the SPR is able to respond to domestic disruptions, and (3) the extent to which other IEA member countries structure their reserves differently. This statement is based on GAO's ongoing work on the SPR and DOE's use of the SPR. GAO reviewed DOE and EIA documents and interviewed DOE officials. What GAO Found The Department of Energy (DOE) has primarily used exchanges from the Strategic Petroleum Reserve (SPR) to private companies to address domestic petroleum supply disruptions. DOE has released oil 24 times from 1985 through September 2017, including 11 releases in response to domestic supply disruptions. Of these 11 releases, 10 were exchanges, including 6 exchanges in response to hurricanes. Of these 11 releases, 10 were exchanges, including 6 exchanges in response to hurricanes. GAO's preliminary analysis of DOE documents and reports also showed that although almost all of DOE's releases in response to domestic supply disruptions have been from the SPR, DOE also used the Northeast Home Heating Oil Reserve in response to Superstorm Sandy in 2012. The SPR is limited in its ability to respond to domestic petroleum supply disruptions for three main reasons. First, as GAO reported in September 2014, reserves are almost entirely composed of oil and not refined products, which may not be effective in responding to all disruptions that affect the refining sector. Second, as GAO reported in September 2014, reserves are nearly entirely located in one region, the Gulf Coast, which may limit responsiveness to disruptions in other regions. Third, during the course of GAO's ongoing work, GAO reviewed DOE and energy task force reports that found that the statutory authorities governing SPR releases may inhibit their use for regional disruptions. GAO's preliminary observations indicate that DOE has used the SPR in response to domestic supply disruptions, but the effectiveness of these releases is unclear because DOE has not formally assessed all of them. DOE has exchanged about 28 million barrels of oil in response to hurricanes, but GAO found only two reports assessing DOE's response to Hurricanes Gustav, Ike, Katrina, and Rita, and it is unclear whether DOE has examined other responses. GAO's preliminary observations indicate that other IEA member countries structure their reserves differently, with some holding industry reserves and refined products, and DOE has taken steps to explore these structures. For example, most IEA members hold some amount of refined petroleum products, and some IEA member countries geographically disperse their reserves of refined petroleum products to be able to respond to domestic disruptions. However, DOE has not formally evaluated other countries' structures in over 35 years and has not finalized its 2015 studies on regional petroleum product reserves. GAO's preliminary review indicates that DOE examined the feasibility of additional regional petroleum product reserves in two 2015 studies, but it did not finalize these studies or expand the SPR to include additional reserves. In September 2014, GAO reported that DOE officials told GAO they were conducting a regional fuel resiliency study that would provide insights into whether there is a need for additional regional product reserves and, if so, where these reserves should be located. The Quadrennial Energy Review of 2015 recommended that DOE analyze the need for additional or expanded regional product reserves by undertaking updated cost-benefit analyses for all of the regions of the United States that have been identified as vulnerable to fuel supply disruptions. What GAO Recommends GAO is not making any new recommendations in this statement.
gao_GAO-18-700T: Why GAO Did This Study EPA has not issued legally enforceable standards for PFAS in drinking water. gao_GAO-18-461: Why GAO Did This Study The U.S. pipeline network includes both interstate and intrastate pipelines, the vast majority of which fall into the latter category: Interstate pipelines. Interstate pipelines are primarily large-volume transmission pipelines that carry gas or hazardous liquids to communities and large-volume users (e.g., factories). PHMSA is responsible for developing regulations for domestic interstate and intrastate natural gas and hazardous liquid pipelines. PHMSA may permit certified states to participate in interstate pipeline inspections through three types of agreements. GAO was asked to review PHMSA's interstate pipeline inspection activities. This report examines (1) the extent to which state pipeline safety agencies participate in interstate pipeline inspections, and (2) how PHMSA allocates its inspection resources. GAO reviewed PHMSA's interstate pipeline inspection plans and interviewed PHMSA officials. GAO also interviewed state pipeline safety officials in six states that have applied for interstate agent status. What GAO Found Interstate pipeline safety agencies conduct high-quality inspections of interstate pipelines and provide an important supplement to the federal inspection workforce. PHMSA regional officials GAO met with generally agreed that interstate agents have well-trained staff and leverage their local knowledge to enhance interstate pipeline inspections within their state. Additionally, interstate agents, if authorized by PHMSA, may conduct inspections of interstate pipelines within their state more frequently than PHMSA. For instance, in one PHMSA region, PHMSA officials said that an interstate agent in their jurisdiction ensured each interstate operator was inspected once every 2 years, regardless of PHMSA's risk ranking. Similarly, in two of five regions that have interstate agents, PHMSA regional officials stated that they needed interstate agents to supplement their current allocation of federal inspectors. PHMSA officials said that, although the region could absorb the interstate agent workload if needed, doing so would lead to less extensive inspections because there would more pipelines to inspect with fewer federal inspectors. Interstate agents may also enhance pipeline safety oversight within their state by going above and beyond the annual interstate inspection activities required under their agreement with PHMSA. Specifically, as part of the annual inspection planning process, PHMSA's regional offices work with interstate agents to develop an annual inspection plan. While interstate agents must prioritize PHMSA's inspection priorities, such as participation in new construction inspections and PHMSA-led systems inspections, they can also propose additional inspections of interstate pipelines within their state. Officials in half of the nine states with interstate agent agreements stated that they proposed and obtained PHMSA's approval for additional interstate pipeline inspections that would not otherwise have been included in PHMSA's annual inspection plan. gao_GAO-18-492: Why GAO Did This Study The Bank is one of several federal agencies promoting U.S. exports. What GAO Found Complex eligibility rules and multiple handoffs and potential layers of review make the Social Security Administration's (SSA) disability programs complicated and costly to administer. Program complexity arguably has made it challenging for SSA to make significant advances in efficiently managing high disability workloads, ensuring timely and consistent disability decisions, preventing benefit overpayments, and mitigating fraud risks. GAO's recent work highlighted some of the challenges SSA faces in making disability decisions that are timely, consistent and based on current concepts of disability, while also preventing and deterring fraud and ensuring that only beneficiaries who are entitled to benefits receive them. These findings underscore the need for SSA leadership to approach these challenges strategically and follow through with rigorous plans in order to achieve significant improvements in its disability programs. gao_GAO-17-789: Why GAO Did This Study The Marine Corps has a long-standing interest in integrating its forces to conduct amphibious operations. The Marine Corps has used virtual training devices to train Marines in a variety of ways, including conducting sea-based operations and conducting amphibious operations from a ship. GAO was asked to review the Marine Corps' efforts to integrate its forces into amphibious operations. This report examines the extent to which (1) the Navy and Marine Corps have completed training for amphibious operations priorities and taken steps to mitigate any training shortfalls, (2) the Navy's and Marine Corps' efforts to improve naval integration for amphibious operations incorporate leading collaborative practices, and (3) the Marine Corps has integrated selected virtual training devices into its operational training. GAO reviewed relevant documents and interviewed officials from the services, including the Marine Corps, and the services' headquarters and headquarters. GAO also visited three Marine Corps installations selected based on geographic dispersion and training needs. What GAO Found The Navy and Marine Corps units that are deploying as part of an Amphibious Ready Group (ARG) Marine Expeditionary Unit (MEU) completed their required training for amphibious operations, but several factors have limited the ability of Marine Corps units to conduct training for other amphibious operations-related priorities. The Navy and Marine Corps have taken steps to identify and address amphibious training shortfalls, but their efforts to mitigate these shortfalls have not prioritized available training resources, systematically evaluated among potential training resource alternatives to accomplish the services' amphibious operations training priorities, or monitored progress toward achieving the priorities. The Navy and Marine Corps have taken some steps to improve coordination between the two services, but the services have not fully incorporated leading collaboration practices that would help drive efforts to improve naval integration for amphibious operations. GAO's prior work on interagency collaboration has found that certain practices can help enhance and sustain collaboration among federal agencies. For example, the services have not defined and articulate common outcomes for naval integration, such as defining and articulating common outcomes for naval integration. The services have not fully established compatible policies and procedures, such as common training tasks and standards and agreed-upon roles and responsibilities, to ensure their efforts to achieve improved naval integration are consistent and sustained. The Marine Corps has taken some steps to integrate virtual training devices into its operational training, but the Marine Corps' process to manage the development and use of its virtual training devices in operational training plans has gaps. For example, the Marine Corps does not (1) include consideration of critical factors for integrating virtual training devices into operational training in its front-end planning to support the acquisition of its virtual training devices, (2) consistently consider expected and actual usage data for virtual training devices to support its investment decisions, or (3) consistently evaluate the effectiveness of its virtual training devices for operational training. The Marine Corps' process to manage the development and use of virtual training devices in operational training plans has gaps due to a lack of guidance. Specifically, the Marine Corps does not (1) include consideration of critical factors for integrating virtual training devices into operational training in its front-end planning to support the acquisition of its virtual training devices, (2) consistently consider expected and actual usage data for virtual training devices to support its investment decisions, or (3) consistently evaluate the effectiveness of its virtual training devices for operational training. What GAO Recommends GAO recommends that the Navy and Marine Corps (1) develop an approach to prioritize available training resources, systematically evaluate among training resource alternatives to achieve amphibious operations priorities, and monitor progress toward achieving them; (2) define and articulate common outcomes for naval integration; (3) more fully establish compatible policies, procedures, and systems; (4) better leverage training resources; and (5) establish mechanisms to monitor results. DOD concurred with all three recommendations.
gao_GAO-19-60: Why GAO Did This Study The Secret Service is responsible for protecting the nation's financial and information systems. The Secret Service has faced long-standing challenges in managing its IT infrastructure. In 2009, the Secret Service initiated the Information Integration and Technology Transformation (IITT) investment, which is intended to modernize and enhance the component's infrastructure, communications systems, applications, and processes. GAO was asked to review the Secret Service's IT portfolio. This report examines the extent to which (1) the Secret Service has implemented selected IT oversight responsibilities, (2) the Secret Service has implemented leading workforce planning and management practices for its IT workforce, and (3) the Secret Service and the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) have implemented selected performance and progress monitoring practices for the IITT investment. GAO analyzed DHS policies and guidance, and interviewed DHS and Secret Service officials. What GAO Found The U.S. Secret Service (Secret Service) Chief Information Officer (CIO) fully implemented 11 of 14 selected responsibilities established for component-level CIOs in DHS's IT management policies. The Secret Service CIO fully implemented 11 of the 14 selected responsibilities. For example, the CIO developed an IT strategic plan that outlined the CIO's strategic IT goals and objectives, as well as tasks intended to meet the goals and objectives. The CIO also took steps to implement the tasks identified within the strategic plan, such as working to develop an IT training program. In addition, the CIO had partially implemented three component-level CIO responsibilities. For example, the CIO had managed the component's IT investment portfolio, including establishing a component-level IT acquisition review process that enables component and DHS review of component acquisitions (i.e., contracts) that contain IT. However, the Secret Service's enterprise governance policy did not specify this as the CIO's responsibility. Further compounding the issue of the Secret Service's enterprise governance policy not properly reflecting the CIO's and Deputy CIO's roles and responsibilities on the component's governance boards is that the Secret Service has not developed a charter for its Executive Resources Board. Until the Secret Service updates its enterprise governance policy to specify (1) the CIO's current role and responsibilities on the Executive Resources Board, to include developing and reviewing the IT budget formulation and execution; and (2) the Deputy CIO's role and responsibilities on the Enterprise Governance Council, the CIO's ability to develop and review the component's IT budget may be limited. Further, the Secret Service has not fully implemented the majority of the 15 selected leading planning and management practices for its IT workforce. Of the five selected workforce planning and management areas, the Secret Service had substantially implemented two of the areas and minimally implemented three of the areas for its IT workforce. In addition, of the 15 selected leading practices associated with these areas, the Secret Service had fully implemented 3 practices, partly implemented 8 practices, and did not implement any aspects of 4 practices. Until the Secret Service updates its recruiting and hiring strategies and plans to address all IT competency and staffing gaps identified (after OCIO completes its analysis of the entire IT workforce), the Secret Service will be limited in its ability to effectively recruit and hire staff to fill those gaps. The Secret Service substantially implemented three practices associated with the IT workforce, partly implemented 8 practices, and did not implement any aspects of 4 practices. Until the Secret Service updates its recruiting and hiring strategies and plans to address all IT competency and staffing gaps identified (after OCIO completes its analysis of the entire IT workforce), the Secret Service will be limited in its ability to effectively recruit and hire staff to fill those gaps. What GAO Recommends GAO recommends that the Secret Service update its enterprise governance policy to specify (1) the CIO's current role and responsibilities on the Executive Resources Board, to include developing and reviewing the IT budget formulation and execution; and (2) the Deputy CIO's role and responsibilities on the Enterprise Governance Council, to include developing and reviewing the IT budget formulation and execution. gao_GAO-18-240: Why GAO Did This Study The federal government is an important source of funds for GME training, and through its funding and workforce planning efforts, HHS, as the largest funder of GME training, has an important role in ensuring federal programs are meeting the nation's workforce needs. GAO was asked to review federal funding of GME training. This report examines (1) the amount spent on GME training in 2015, and the amount spent per full-time-equivalent (FTE) resident; (2) the extent to which federal agencies collect information about how federal funding is used to support GME training; and (3) the extent to which HHS collects information about how federal funding is used to support GME training. GAO analyzed federal and state data on GME training spending, reviewed literature and experts, and interviewed federal and state officials and experts from research and industry organizations. What GAO Found Federal agencies and state Medicaid agencies spent over $16.3 billion on graduate medical education (GME) training in 2015, and the amount spent per FTE resident varied across programs. The amount spent per FTE resident varied across programs, and the largest variation across payment recipients and regions was within Medicare due to variation in the values of factors used to calculate Medicare payment amounts. Almost half of participants received payments from more than one program, and the designs of federal programs may reduce the potential for duplicate payments. GME training costs vary by program characteristics, such as size, type, training setting, and age, and some training costs are more prone to variation than others. Challenges exist in measuring and comparing GME training costs due to a lack of standard cost methodologies across teaching sites and some training costs being difficult to measure. Further, little is known about how GME training costs relate to federal GME funding. Agencies generally collect information to manage their respective programs, ensure the accuracy of payments, and reduce the potential for duplicative payments within or across federal programs that fund GME training. However, HHS does not have sufficient information available to comprehensively evaluate the federal programs that fund GME training, identify gaps between federal GME programs' results and physician workforce needs, and make or recommend to Congress changes in order to improve the efficient and effective use of federal funds. For example, HHS does not collect information about the total number and specialty type of residents supported by all of the federal programs that fund GME training. As a result, HHS cannot identify problems and make or recommend changes to Congress in order to improve the efficient and effective use of federal funds. What GAO Recommends GAO recommends that HHS coordinate with federal agencies, including VA, that fund GME training to identify information needed to evaluate the performance of federal programs that fund GME training, including the extent to which these programs are efficient and cost-effective and are meeting the nation's health care workforce needs. HHS concurred with GAO's recommendations.

gao_GAO-18-539: Why GAO Did This Study The growth of shared mobility services—such as mobile applications that allow riders to request a ride or a ride-sharing service—has increased the use of public transit. gao_GAO-19-144: Why GAO Did This Study The federal government and private industry face a persistent shortage of cybersecurity and IT professionals to implement and oversee information security protections to combat cyber threats. The Federal Cybersecurity Workforce Assessment Act of 2015 required OPM, NIST, and other federal agencies to undertake a number of cybersecurity workforce-planning activities. The act also required GAO to report on the status of these activities. This report (1) determines the extent to which federal agencies have assigned work role codes to positions performing information technology (IT), cybersecurity, or cyber-related functions, and (2) describes the steps federal agencies took to identify work roles of critical need. GAO reviewed the act and OPM guidance and interviewed agency officials. GAO also reviewed a random sample of 2210 IT management positions from six agencies selected based on their total cybersecurity spending for fiscal year 2016. What GAO Found The 24 major departments and agencies covered by the Chief Financial Officers (CFO) Act of 1990 (the act) generally assigned work role codes to their positions. However, several agencies had not completed assigning codes to their vacant positions. In addition, most agencies had likely miscategorized the work roles of many positions. For example, in these instances, the agencies had assigned a code designated for positions that do not perform IT, cybersecurity, or cyber-related functions to positions that most likely perform these functions. The 24 agencies had taken steps to address the three selected activities required by the act. Specifically, OPM reported on agencies' progress in identifying critical needs and provided agencies with guidance for identifying IT, cybersecurity, and cyber-related work roles of critical need. In addition, the 24 agencies had submitted preliminary reports of their identified critical needs to OPM, but their efforts to identify critical needs were ongoing. The act required OPM to identify critical needs across federal agencies and submit a progress report to Congress on the identification of IT, cybersecurity, or cyber-related work roles of critical need by December 2017. The act also required OPM to provide timely guidance for identifying IT, cybersecurity, or cyber-related work roles of critical need, including current acute and emerging skill shortages. In addition, the 24 agencies had begun to identify critical needs and submitted a preliminary report of their identified critical needs to OPM. Most agencies' reports included the required critical needs and root causes. Specifically, Twenty-four agencies' reports documented work roles of critical need. Twenty-two agencies' reports included the root cause of the critical needs identified. What GAO Recommends GAO is making 28 recommendations to 22 agencies to complete the appropriate assignment of codes to their positions performing IT, cybersecurity, or cyber-related functions, in accordance with the requirements of the act. Of the 22 agencies to which GAO made recommendations, 20 agencies stated that they agreed with the recommendations directed to them; one agency partially agreed with the recommendation; and one agency agreed with one recommendation but did not agree with one recommendation. In addition, of the two agencies to which GAO did not make recommendations, one agency acknowledged its review of the report but did not otherwise provide comments; the other agency provided technical comments, which GAO incorporated into the report as appropriate.
gao_GAO-18-417: Why GAO Did This Study The Department of Defense (DOD) relies on its workforce to conduct research, development, and engineering. The National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2017 included a provision for GAO to review the defense laboratories' hiring efforts. This report examines (1) the defense laboratories' use of existing hiring authorities and what officials view as the benefits of authorities and incentives and the challenges in hiring; (2) the extent to which the department evaluates the effectiveness of hiring, including hiring authorities, at the defense laboratories; and (3) the extent to which DOD has time frames for approving and implementing new hiring authorities. GAO analyzed DOD hiring data for fiscal years 2015 through 2017 and interviewed officials from the defense laboratories. GAO also surveyed 16 laboratory officials on their perceptions of the various hiring authorities and incentives, and interviewed hiring officials and supervisors from the labs. What GAO Found The defense laboratories have used the defense laboratory-specific direct hire authorities more than any other category of hiring authorities when hiring science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) personnel. Moreover, the use of these direct hire authorities increased each year from fiscal year 2015 through fiscal year 2017. Of the 11,562 STEM hiring actions in fiscal years 2015 through 2017, approximately 46 percent were completed using one of the defense laboratory direct hire authorities. The second and third most used hiring authorities were internal hiring actions and the expedited hiring authority for acquisition personnel, each of which comprised approximately 12 percent of the hiring actions during the time period. The three defense laboratory-specific direct hire authorities were the most helpful to the labs' efforts to hire highly qualified candidates for STEM positions, and also reported that the use of certain incentives had been helpful in this effort. However, even with access to the authorities, these defense laboratory officials identified challenges associated with the hiring process that affected their ability to hire highly qualified candidates. The department and the defense laboratories track hiring data that can be used to evaluate some aspects of the individual labs' hiring efforts, but the Defense Laboratories Office has not routinely obtained or monitored these data or evaluated the effectiveness of hiring, including the use of hiring authorities, across the defense laboratories as a whole. Laboratory hiring data are captured at the department level in the Defense Civilian Personnel Data System (DCPDS)—the department's system of record for personnel data. In addition, the individual defense laboratories track hiring data, including the type of hiring authority used and certain milestone dates that can be used to measure the length of the hiring process, known as time to hire. According to Office of Personnel Management guidance and GAO's prior work, time to hire is a measure that may inform about the effectiveness of the hiring process, and federal agencies are required to report time to hire for certain types of hiring actions to OPM. Without routinely obtaining and monitoring defense laboratory hiring data and developing performance measures, the Defense Laboratories Office cannot effectively oversee the effectiveness of hiring, including the use of hiring authorities, at the defense laboratories. Specifically, without performance measures for evaluating the effectiveness of the defense laboratories' hiring, and more specifically the use of hiring authorities, the department lacks reasonable assurance that these authorities—in particular, those granted by Congress to the defense laboratories—are resulting in improved hiring outcomes. Without evaluating the effectiveness of the defense laboratories' hiring efforts, the department cannot understand any challenges experienced by the labs or determine appropriate strategies for mitigating these challenges. As a result, the department and defense laboratories may be unable to demonstrate that they are using their authorities and flexibilities effectively, or that such authorities and flexibilities should be maintained or expanded for future use. What GAO Recommends GAO recommends that the Secretary of Defense (1) routinely obtain and monitor defense laboratory hiring data to improve the oversight of the defense laboratories' use of hiring authorities; (2) develop performance measures to evaluate the effectiveness of the defense laboratories' hiring, including the use of hiring authorities, as part of the labs' overall hiring to better inform future decision making about hiring efforts and policies; and (3) establish and document time frames for its process for departmental coordination efforts related to the approval and implementation of new hiring authorities. DOD concurred with GAO's recommendations.
gao_GAO-19-84: Why GAO Did This Study The National Nuclear Security Administration (NNSA) is responsible for extending the life of existing U.S. nuclear warheads by replacing them with modern technologies. gao_GAO-18-290: Why GAO Did This Study The federal government invests billions of dollars annually in STEM education programs to enhance the nation's economic and educational competitiveness. The federal government has a portfolio of programs that provide similar services to similar groups in similar STEM fields. GAO previously reported that most federal STEM education programs overlapped to some degree with at least one other program, in that they offered similar services to similar groups in similar STEM fields to achieve similar objectives. GAO was asked to review the extent to which federal STEM education programs have evolved since 2010, and the extent to which the federal portfolio has been able to serve similar populations historically underrepresented in STEM fields. This report examines (1) the number of STEM education programs and their spending in fiscal year 2016, (2) the extent to which STEM education programs overlapped with at least one other program, and (3) the extent to which the Committee on STEM Education and the Office of Science and Technology Policy have fulfilled their responsibilities to assess the portfolio. GAO analyzed agency documents and data, and interviewed agency officials. GAO also surveyed 198 federal STEM education programs. What GAO Found From 2010 to 2016, the number of science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) education programs decreased while spending remained stable. Three agencies—the Department of Energy, the Department of Health and Human Services, and the National Science Foundation—administered more than half of all STEM education programs in fiscal years 2010 and 2016. Despite collectively reporting fewer STEM education programs, program officials responding to GAO's questionnaire reported spending about the same amount in fiscal year 2016 as they did in fiscal year 2010. In fiscal year 2016, program officials reported spending about $2.9 billion on the 163 programs. Spending by individual programs ranged from about $14,000 annually to hundreds of millions of dollars. The National Science Foundation and the Department of Health and Human Services programs account for about 60 percent of this spending. The Committee on STEM Education and the Office of Science and Technology Policy have not fully fulfilled their responsibilities to assess the federal portfolio of STEM education programs. Specifically, the Committee on STEM Education has not reviewed performance assessments of STEM education programs to ensure effectiveness—a primary function of its authorizing charter. Overall, the Committee made limited progress advancing its strategic goal of increasing the use of evidence-based approaches because, according to Committee leadership, they focused on achieving other strategic goals. By reviewing programs' performance assessments, the Committee could leverage existing performance information to identify and share promising practices that agencies could use in designing or revising their programs. Moreover, in doing so, the Committee could further its strategic goal of increasing the use of evidence-based approaches across the portfolio of STEM education programs. The Committee has not reported STEM education programs' participation rates of groups historically underrepresented in STEM fields, although broadening participation of those groups is one of the Committee's strategic goals. Moreover, the COMPETES Act requires that the Committee report the participation rates of women, underrepresented minorities, and persons from rural areas in its inventory of federal programs. Committee leadership acknowledged they have not reported these data, and added that such participation data are not fully available across all STEM education programs. However, such participation data were generally available. What GAO Recommends GAO recommends that the leadership of the Committee on STEM Education review performance assessments of federal STEM education programs and then take appropriate steps to enhance effectiveness of the portfolio, such as by sharing promising practices that agencies could use in designing or revising their programs. The Committee agreed with all four of GAO's recommendations and noted initial strategies for how they would implement three of them. Regarding implementation of the fourth recommendation to report on participation rates of underrepresented groups in federal STEM education programs, they noted plans to examine confounding factors inhibiting the reporting of the information required under the COMPETES Act. Gaining insight on the challenges agencies face collecting this information is an important first step. However, to comply with the requirement of the COMPETES Act and help ensure programs reach populations historically underrepresented in STEM fields, GAO continues to believe that the Committee should report the participation rates of women, underrepresented minorities, and persons from rural areas in federal STEM education programs that collect this information. To do so, the Committee may also need to develop strategies to help agencies overcome some of these confounding factors.
gao_GAO-19-57: Why GAO Did This Study Federal agencies own billions of dollars in real property assets, including buildings, warehouses, and roads. Effective asset management can help agencies optimize limited funding and make decisions to better target their policy goals and objectives. GAO was asked to review federal agencies' efforts to manage their real property assets. This report examines (1) key characteristics of an effective asset management framework, and how selected federal agencies' frameworks reflect these characteristics; (2) views of selected experts and practitioners on challenges and benefits to implementing an asset management framework; and (3) whether government-wide asset management guidance and information reflect standards and key characteristics of an effective asset management framework. GAO reviewed relevant literature, analyzed federal agencies' asset management frameworks, and interviewed experts and practitioners from six selected agencies. GAO selected these agencies based on their size, replacement value, and other characteristics. GAO also interviewed experts and practitioners about their views on challenges and benefits to implementing an asset management framework. What GAO Found Effective asset management frameworks include six key characteristics: (1) establishing formal policies and plans, (2) maximizing an asset portfolio's value, (3) maintaining leadership support, (4) using quality data, (5) promoting a collaborative organizational culture, and (6) evaluating and improving asset management practices. Each of the six agencies GAO reviewed had a real property asset management framework that included some of these key characteristics. However, agencies varied in how they performed activities in these areas. For example, while some agencies' asset management policies applied to large portions of their portfolios, other agencies' policies applied to only certain portions of their portfolios. In addition, two agencies—the Corps and Coast Guard—told GAO they were using the International Organization for Standardization (ISO) 55000 standards. For example, according to Corps officials, the Corps is in the process of incorporating elements of the ISO 55000 standards into its frameworks. Coast Guard officials told GAO they were using the ISO 55000 standards as a benchmark to compare against their existing framework. Officials from the six agencies GAO reviewed said that more centralized decision-making processes can provide improved standardization and clarity in the prioritization process, particularly for high value projects, and can help ensure that mission-critical projects receive funding.
