gao_GAO-18-21: Why GAO Did This Study Duty-free stores located along the U.S.-Mexico border are regulated by U.S. Customs and Border Protection (CBP) and U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE). Duty-free stores are not subject to U.S. tax laws. GAO was asked to review duty-free cigarette exports. This report examines (1) requirements that govern the lawful sale and export of cigarettes from duty-free stores on the southwest border and schemes for illicit trade in such cigarettes that agencies identified, (2) U.S. agency observations about these duty-free cigarette exports and efforts to counter illicit trade, and (3) the extent to which selected cigarette transaction data submitted by duty-free stores indicate compliance issues with reporting requirements. GAO reviewed relevant laws and regulations, analyzed export data from 2010 through 2015, and interviewed U.S. and Mexican agency officials. What GAO Found Duty-free stores may sell tax-exempt cigarettes in any quantity to passengers departing the United States for Mexico at a port on the land border; agencies have identified schemes and practices associated with duty-free sales that are used to evade U.S. and Mexican taxes. U.S. regulations require duty-free stores to have procedures to provide reasonable assurance that duty-free merchandise sold will be exported and require the exporter to report information on the export of commercial cargo, which CBP considers to be transactions valued at more than $2,500. Census data indicate that about 18,500 such transactions occurred from 2010 through 2015 at duty-free stores on the southwest border. According to information from CBP and a Mexican customs official, Mexican requirements dictate that, depending on place of residence, some adult travelers to Mexico can bring in one carton of cigarettes tax-exempt, and some residents can bring in an additional three cartons if they pay taxes on them. Bringing in any quantity above four cartons would require an individual to register as an importer with the Mexican government, according to the same Mexican official. U.S. agencies identified three schemes used to evade cigarette-related taxes and other legal requirements in the United States and Mexico: (1) diverting cigarettes from the store directly into U.S. commerce; (2) smuggling duty-free cigarettes into Mexico through U.S. ports of entry by concealing them, while potentially also bribing Mexican customs officials to evade payment of Mexican taxes; and (3) smuggling duty-free cigarettes back into the United States after first smuggling them into Mexico. U.S. agency officials said that some smuggling of duty-free cigarettes across the southwest border has links to organized crime, supplies the illicit tobacco market in Mexico, and poses oversight challenges. ICE officials said that transnational criminal organizations use smuggled, duty-free cigarettes to launder money and generate revenue. Furthermore, a Mexican customs official noted that relatively inexpensive cigarettes manufactured in the United States, which cannot legally be sold in the United States or in Mexico, are routinely sold for export from duty-free stores on the southwest border; such cigarettes are then smuggled across to supply Mexico's illicit tobacco market. One brand of such cigarettes has been cited in recent studies as a significant part of the illicit tobacco trade in Mexico. U.S. agency officials said that their efforts to counter the illicit movement of duty-free cigarettes face challenges related to the purchaser's ability to buy duty-free cigarettes in unlimited quantities and to use passenger, not commercial, crossings from the United States into Mexico. According to U.S. officials, while U.S. agencies do not have the authority to seize exports that violate Mexico's laws related to these cigarettes, U.S. officials reported working with Mexican officials on activities to enforce the customs laws and regulations of both countries. CBP has taken some steps to address compliance concerns with one duty-free store operator, but other possible actions remain, including the issuance of final instructions and guidance to all duty-free store operators on the border and the public. What GAO Recommends GAO recommends that CBP take steps to strengthen compliance with export reporting requirements related to duty-free cigarette sales on the southwest border. DHS concurred with GAO's recommendation.
gao_GAO-19-167: Why GAO Did This Study The Food and Nutrition Service (FNS) is responsible for overseeing the SNAP program, which provides food to millions of low-income households. FNS estimates the extent of trafficking in SNAP benefits, which is a form of fraud. GAO was asked to review FNS's efforts to prevent, detect, and respond to retailer trafficking. This report examines (1) the extent of retailer trafficking in SNAP and (2) steps FNS has taken to address retailer trafficking. GAO reviewed FNS data on trafficking and interviewed FNS officials. GAO also reviewed FNS's policies and procedures for authorizing and monitoring stores. What GAO Found FNS's data indicate an increase in the estimated rate of retailer trafficking in recent years. FNS reported in March 2011 that approximately $330 million in Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP) benefits were trafficked annually from 2006 through 2008, and that approximately 8.2 percent of all authorized stores engaged in trafficking. In its most recent report from September 2017, FNS reported that approximately $1 billion in SNAP benefits were trafficked annually from 2012 through 2014, and that approximately 11.8 percent of all authorized stores engaged in trafficking. Although FNS produces the trafficking estimates with accepted statistical methods, its reports do not clearly convey the level of uncertainty introduced by the approach used to calculate the estimates. Throughout each report, FNS presents its estimates as precise numbers. However, uncertainty is introduced when extrapolating from a smaller sample—in this case, an investigative sample that solely includes stores known to have trafficked or suspected of trafficking—to the full population of SNAP-authorized stores because the extent to which the sample reflects the broader population of stores is unknown. According to the Office of Management and Budget's statistical standards for federal agencies, possible variation in estimates should be noted, such as by reporting the range of each estimate. FNS officials stated the agency has not considered and does not intend to consider changes to how it reports its trafficking estimates in the next report. FNS has acknowledged limitations with its current approach to estimating retailer trafficking and evaluated ways to address some of those limitations. For example, FNS has not evaluated whether the factors used to identify stores for possible investigation could help reduce bias in the sample and improve the trafficking estimates. FNS officials said that they do not believe there are available data that indicate whether the assumption is accurate and, as such, any evaluation would require new data collection. However, according to contractors and a former official who had studied the methodology as well as USDA Office of Inspector General officials, data are currently available that may help FNS evaluate the accuracy of this assumption. Without evaluating the usefulness of the Watch List factors for adjusting the sample, FNS may miss an opportunity to reduce the bias in the sample and improve the accuracy of its trafficking estimates. FNS has taken some steps to prevent retailer trafficking that align with leading fraud risk management practices and GAO's prior recommendations, but has not pursued some opportunities for early oversight. For example, FNS has taken steps to improve how it detects retailer trafficking, such as increasing requirements for food that retailers must stock to participate in SNAP. However, FNS has not pursued some opportunities for early oversight. For example, FNS has not assessed retailer risk levels, which are key to preventing trafficking. Considering the benefits and costs of control activities to address identified risks is a leading practice in GAO's Fraud Risk Framework. By not assessing the benefits and costs of reauthorizing certain high-risk stores more frequently than other stores, FNS may be missing an opportunity to provide early oversight of risky stores and prevent trafficking. FNS measures the effectiveness of many of its trafficking detection and response activities, but lacks measures to evaluate its prevention activities. For example, FNS's Retailer Operations Division has an internal scorecard that tracks performance measures related to retailer oversight activities, but none of these focuses on prevention of trafficking. FNS officials said that they have not considered establishing measures related to preventing trafficking. FNS officials acknowledged that these data could be used to develop performance measures for its trafficking prevention activities. Establishing such measures would enable FNS to more fully assess the effectiveness of its retailer oversight activities and better balance retailer access to the program with those to prevent retailer fraud. What GAO Recommends GAO recommends that FNS (1) evaluate the usefulness of the Watch List factors for adjusting the sample, (2) assess the benefits and costs of reauthorizing a sample of high-risk stores more frequently than other stores, and (3) assess the benefits and costs of reauthorizing a sample of high-risk stores more frequently than other stores. FNS generally agreed with the recommendations.
gao_GAO-18-256: Why GAO Did This Study RFA requires agencies to analyze the impact of proposed rules on small entities and consider any significant regulatory alternatives that will achieve statutory objectives while minimizing any significant economic impact on small entities. RFA also requires GAO to review the implementation of RFA. This report examines (1) the extent to which RFA requirements apply to recent rules and the extent to which regulators certify that these rules would not have a significant economic impact on small entities and (2) the extent to which regulators have evaluated the potential economic effects of proposed rules and the extent to which they have documented the analyses. GAO reviewed RFA requirements and regulations, analyzed certifications and regulatory flexibility analyses, and interviewed agency officials. What GAO Found The Financial Regulations Act (FRA) requires that federal agencies, including the financial regulators, analyze the impact of proposed rules on small entities and consider any significant regulatory alternatives that will achieve statutory objectives while minimizing any significant economic impact on small entities. RFA requires that agencies assess the impact of proposed rules on small entities and consider any significant regulatory alternatives that will achieve statutory objectives while minimizing any significant economic impact on small entities. GAO found that many of the 316 rules subject to RFA requirements from 2010 through 2016 were not subject to RFA requirements. The regulators generally certified that most would not have a significant economic impact on a substantial number of small entities. However, the frequency with which individual regulators certified varied. For example, the Federal Reserve most frequently performed some RFA analyses in these rules, although such analyses were not required. GAO found that the factual basis provided for most certifications lacked key information (discussions of data sources or methodologies and of broader economic impacts, or definitions for key criteria) for understanding the analyses regulators used to support their conclusion. GAO also found that while most agencies relied on the Small Business Administration's definitions of small entities for use in their RFA analyses, two agencies relied on alternative definitions of small entities, some of which have not been updated in more than 35 years. GAO found that the factual basis provided for most certifications lacked key information (discussions of data sources or methodologies and of broader economic impacts, or definitions for key criteria) for understanding the analyses regulators used to support their conclusion. GAO also found that the regulators' guidance for complying with RFA generally does not include policies and procedures for helping to ensure consistent and complete RFA analyses. Without policies and procedures that would help ensure that key components were incorporated in certification assessments—including disclosing the methodology and data sources of economic analyses and considering potential broad economic impacts—regulators may be limiting the effectiveness of their reviews. In turn, such reviews hinder the achievement of RFA's goal. For example, incomplete disclosure of methodology and data sources could limit the public and affected entities' ability to offer informed comments in response to regulators' certification assessments in proposed rules. Many recent regulatory flexibility analyses had weaknesses. Many final rules described changes to limit burden, and few regulatory flexibility analyses concluded rules would have a significant impact on small entities. For most rules GAO reviewed, regulators were unable to provide documentation supporting their regulatory flexibility analyses. Moreover, regulators generally lacked comprehensive policies and procedures for RFA implementation, a potential contributing factor for many of the weaknesses GAO identified. By developing policies and procedures that provide specific direction to rulemaking staff, the regulators could better ensure consistent and complete implementation of RFA requirements and more fully realize the RFA goal of appropriately considering and minimizing impacts on small entities during and after agency rulemakings. What GAO Recommends GAO recommends that the Financial Deposit Insurance Corporation (FDIC) develop and implement specific policies and procedures for how it will consistently comply with RFA requirements and key aspects of Office of Advocacy guidance. FDIC agreed with GAO's recommendations.
gao_GAO-18-605: Why GAO Did This Study The Air Force has a fleet of 82 HH-60G Pave Hawks designated to meet its personnel recovery mission requirements. The Air Force has also designated 14 HH-60Gs for training and, development and testing. The National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2013 required the National Commission on the Structure of the Air Force to study the Air Force's structure and recommend modifications. The National Commission on the Structure of the Air Force issued its final report in January 2014. The Air Force agreed with 41 of the 42 recommendations. GAO was asked to review the Air Force's HH-60G fleet. This report examines (1) the extent to which the Air Force's HH-60Gs have experienced declines in condition and maintenance challenges, and (2) the extent to which the Air Force fielded its new Combat Rescue Helicopters. GAO reviewed the Air Force's inventory of HH-60Gs and maintenance data for fiscal years 2013-2017, and interviewed Air Force officials. GAO also reviewed the Air Force's Combat Rescue Helicopter fielding schedule. What GAO Found The material condition of the Air Force's HH-60G fleet has declined and maintenance challenges have increased, in part due to extensions beyond the initially designed service life of the helicopters. In November 2017, the Air Force's HH-60Gs were about 5 percent below their desired “mission capable” rate of 75 percent, which refers to the material condition of a squadron's possessed aircraft and their abilities to conduct their designed missions. Mission capable rates have shown some year-to-year fluctuations, without any clear trends. However, for each of the past 5 years, the helicopters' mission capable rates have been below the Air Force's goal, and for fiscal year 2017, 68 percent of the 96 helicopter fleet were mission capable. As the helicopters have aged, the amount of time spent conducting maintenance on them has increased. For example, according to Air Force officials, in fiscal year 2013 the fleet averaged about 21 maintenance manhours for every HH-60G flight hour. However, by fiscal year 2017, the maintenance time spent had increased to an average of more than 25 maintenance manhours for every flight hour. According to Air Force officials, these structural and major component failures can require time-consuming maintenance that negatively affects availability and mission capable rates. The Air Force fielded its new Combat Rescue Helicopters first to high flight-hour squadrons. The Air Force Reserve is scheduled to receive its new helicopters beginning in fiscal year 2026. The Air National Guard is scheduled to receive refurbished Operational Loss Replacement helicopters in fiscal year 2019 and the new Combat Rescue Helicopters beginning in fiscal year 2027. The last Combat Rescue Helicopters are scheduled to be fielded to all three components in fiscal year 2029. The Air Force has identified potential training challenges, but would likely incur costs if it adjusted the fielding schedule for its Combat Rescue Helicopters. The Air Force Reserve and Air National Guard did not concur with the Combat Rescue Helicopter fielding schedule. Reserve Component officials said they did not concur, in part, because the Air Force did not coordinate the fielding schedule prior to the contract's approval in 2014. However, according to Air Force officials, the Combat Rescue Helicopter fielding schedule was coordinated with and approved by all components prior to the 2014 contract being approved. Further, Air Force officials stated they plan to maintain the fielding schedule because changing it would require the renegotiation of the contract and would likely result in increased costs and possibly a delay in delivery of the new helicopters. Air Force officials acknowledge that based on the current fielding schedule there is a potential training gap that will occur in fiscal years 2025 through 2028 when the formal training units will no longer have any HH-60Gs available to train the reserve component. As of June 2018, Air Force officials said they were considering a number of options to address future training issues, including the following: The Air Force would provide legacy HH-60G helicopters, for a limited time, to the Air National Guard squadron at Kirtland Air Force Base. This would allow the Air National Guard to continue providing initial and requalification training on the legacy HH-60G helicopters for several years after the active component portion of the formal training unit at Kirtland Air Force Base has divested its legacy HH-60G helicopters. The Air Force would require personnel that have completed training on the Combat Rescue Helicopter at Kirtland Air Force Base to then receive additional training for the legacy platform at their home stations if their squadrons are still flying the HH-60Gs. What GAO Recommends GAO is not making any recommendations in this report. DOD had no comments
gao_GAO-18-607: Why GAO Did This Study Medicaid, a federal-state health care program, covered an estimated 72.2 million low-income and medically needy individuals in 2016. PPACA permitted states to expand Medicaid eligibility to a new population—non-elderly, non-pregnant adults who are not eligible for Medicare and whose income does not exceed 138 percent of the federal poverty level (FPL). PPACA also permitted states to expand Medicaid eligibility to a new population—non-elderly, non-pregnant adults who are not eligible for Medicare and whose income does not exceed 138 percent of the FPL. GAO was asked to describe (1) the number and demographic characteristics of uninsured, low-income adults in expansion and non-expansion states; (2) unmet medical needs for low-income adults in expansion and non-expansion states and by insurance status; (3) barriers to health care for low-income adults in expansion and non-expansion states and by insurance status; and (4) having a usual place of care and receiving selected health care services for low-income adults in expansion and non-expansion states and by insurance status. GAO analyzed data from the 2016 National Health Interview Survey (NHIS), which was the most recent available when GAO conducted its analyses. GAO also interviewed officials from the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS), a federal agency within the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS), and the National Center for Health Statistics (NCHS). GAO also reviewed relevant federal laws and regulations, and interviewed officials from the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS), a federal agency within the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS), and the National Center for Health Statistics (NCHS). What GAO Found According to the 2016 National Health Interview Survey (NHIS), 5.6 million low-income adults were uninsured in 2016. Of these 5.6 million, an estimated 1.9 million uninsured, low-income adults resided in expansion states, compared with an estimated 3.7 million in non-expansion states. Estimates of uninsured, low-income adults comprised less than 1 percent of the total population for all expansion states and 3 percent of the total population for all non-expansion states. Estimates of uninsured, low-income adults comprised less than 1 percent of the total population for all expansion states and 3 percent of the total population for all non-expansion states. Estimates of unmet medical needs showed that smaller percentages of low-income adults in expansion states reported having any unmet medical needs compared with those in non-expansion states; and smaller percentages of those who were insured reported having any unmet medical needs compared with those who were uninsured, regardless of where they lived. The 2016 NHIS estimates showed that smaller percentages of low-income adults in expansion states reported financial barriers to needed health care compared with those in non-expansion states; and smaller percentages of those who were insured reported financial barriers to needed health care compared with those who were uninsured, regardless of where they lived. The 2016 NHIS estimates showed that a larger percentage of low-income adults in expansion states reported having a usual place of care compared with those in non-expansion states; and larger percentages of those who were insured reported having a usual place of care compared with those who were uninsured, regardless of where they lived. The 2016 NHIS estimates showed that larger percentages of low-income adults in expansion states reported receiving selected health care services, such as a flu vaccine, compared with those in non-expansion states; and larger percentages of those with insurance reported receiving selected health care services compared with those who were uninsured, regardless of where they lived. The 2016 NHIS also asked respondents whether they visited or had spoken to a health care professional about their health, including: a general practitioner, family doctor, or a nurse practitioner, physician's assistant, or midwife; and a doctor who specializes in a particular disease, with the exception of obstetricians, gynecologists, psychiatrists, and ophthalmologists.
gao_GAO-18-60: Why GAO Did This Study Offshore seismic surveys provide federal agencies and commercial entities with a wide range of information, including data on fault zones and geology that may indicate the presence of oil and gas. This information can help inform regulatory and resource development decisions. BOEM, NMFS, and FWS review applications for permits and authorizations related to seismic surveys in each of the four OCS regions. GAO was asked to review BOEM's process for reviewing seismic survey permit applications. This report examines (1) BOEM's process for reviewing seismic survey permit applications in each OCS region, the number of applications reviewed from 2011 through 2016, and BOEM's review time frames; (2) NMFS's and FWS's processes for reviewing incidental authorization applications related to seismic surveys in each OCS region, the number of such applications reviewed by the agencies from 2011 through 2016, and their review time frames; and (3) the status of pending seismic survey permit applications and related incidental take authorizations in the Atlantic OCS region. GAO reviewed relevant laws and regulations, agency guidance, and agency documents, and interviewed agency officials and industry stakeholders. What GAO Found The Bureau of Ocean Energy Management (BOEM) has a documented process for reviewing seismic survey applications in each of the three selected Outer Continental Shelf (OCS) regions that differ at the final step. BOEM generally submits an application to BOEM for a seismic survey permit at the same time that the applicant submits an application to NMFS or FWS for an incidental take authorization. For the Gulf of Mexico region, BOEM generally issues permits without requiring incidental take authorizations to be in place. BOEM's process for reviewing seismic survey permit applications differs by OCS region. BOEM generally issues permits without requiring incidental take authorizations to be in place. NMFS and FWS follow a similar application review process for reviewing incidental authorization applications, and from 2011 through 2016, the agencies reviewed a total of 35 applications. However, neither agency was able to provide accurate data for the dates on which it began its formal processing of these applications because neither agency's guidance sufficiently describes how to record certain review dates. As a result, it is not possible to determine whether the agencies were meeting their statutory time frames for the type of incidental take authorization application that has such time frames—the incidental harassment authorizations. NMFS and FWS have been reviewing certain seismic survey permit and incidental take authorization applications in the Atlantic OCS region for several years. From 2011 through 2016, BOEM received six applications for seismic survey permits in the Atlantic region. Of the six applications, five also applied to NMFS for incidental harassment authorizations related to their seismic survey permit applications, from August 2014 to January 2016. The sixth applicant that applied to BOEM for a seismic survey permit in the Atlantic OCS region did not apply for an incidental harassment authorization with NMFS. NMFS officials told GAO that they did not issue the seismic survey permits because it had made a policy decision to wait for NMFS to issue incidental harassment authorizations before doing so. In January 2017, BOEM denied the six applications for deep-penetration seismic survey permits in the Atlantic OCS region after reviewing the applications for 948 to 982 days. In May 2017, BOEM announced it would reconsider the six applications for seismic survey permits in the Atlantic region, after the new administration rescinded the permit denials. As of August 2017, BOEM officials were unable to provide estimates of when the agency's reviews would be completed. What GAO Recommends GAO recommends that BOEM and FWS develop guidance that clarifies how and when staff should record the date on which the agency determines the "adequacy and completeness" of an application. NMFS and FWS agreed with GAO's recommendations.
gao_GAO-18-289: Why GAO Did This Study The Navy is the first military department to assert audit readiness for its real property. GAO was asked to review the Navy's audit readiness. This report (1) determines the extent to which the Navy had internal control deficiencies, if any, that may impair its ability to assert that its buildings, as reported in its financial statements, exist and that the information about the buildings is complete and adequately supported by property records and (2) identifies the challenges, if any, that the Navy faces in valuing its buildings in accordance with federal accounting standards. GAO reviewed relevant documentation, including Navy procedures and related control activities, and interviewed Navy officials. GAO also conducted site visits to selected buildings at 10 Navy installations. What GAO Found GAO identified internal control deficiencies that impaired the Navy's ability to assert that as of September 30, 2016, (1) buildings recorded in the Navy's accountable real property system (iNFADS) and reported as assets in Navy's financial statements existed and (2) all of the Navy's buildings were recorded in iNFADS and correctly reported as assets in Navy's financial statements. The effects of these internal control deficiencies contributed to the Navy (1) continuing to maintain records in iNFADS for buildings that had been demolished, sometimes many years ago, and including these buildings as assets in its financial statements; (2) excluding some of the buildings that it owns from being recorded in iNFADS and reported as assets in its financial statements; (3) erroneously reporting nonfunctional buildings as assets in its financial statements; and (4) excluding certain buildings from being reported as assets in its financial statements that met or exceeded DOD's capitalization threshold. The Navy faces several challenges in valuing its buildings in accordance with federal accounting standards, including (1) finalizing documentation of actual cost information for buildings that are acquired and placed in service after the Navy's opening balances have been established based on alternative valuation methods permitted by SFFAS No. 50; (2) capturing and recording costs of improvements that should be reported; (3) consistently completing asset evaluations for each building every 5 years as required by DOD Instruction 4165.14 to help ensure that each building's information in iNFADS is correct; and (4) determining placed in service dates for previously unrecorded buildings that are subsequently discovered/identified through physical inventories/asset evaluations. Navy officials are aware of these challenges and have various efforts under way to address them. Effective implementation of these efforts is crucial to help address these challenges. What GAO Recommends GAO recommends that the Navy develop and implement procedures and related control activities to reasonably assure that demolished buildings are recorded as disposed and removed from the accounting records. The Navy concurred with GAO's recommendations.
gao_GAO-18-635: Why GAO Did This Study The Bureau estimates the cost of the 2020 Census to be $12.3 billion, an increase of 27 percent over the estimated $12.3 billion in 2015. The Bureau's latest estimate, announced in October 2017, reflects the same design, but at an expected cost of $15.6 billion. GAO was asked to review the Bureau's cost estimates. This report evaluates (1) the extent to which the Bureau's life-cycle cost estimate and associated guidance met GAO's best practices for cost estimation and (2) compared the 2015 and 2017 life-cycle cost estimates to describe key drivers of cost growth. GAO analyzed the Bureau's cost estimates against best practices and interviewed Bureau and Department of Commerce officials. What GAO Found The Census Bureau (Bureau) has made significant progress in developing its life-cycle cost estimate for the 2020 Census. For example, the Bureau has put into place a work breakdown structure (WBS) that defines the work, products, activities, and resources necessary to accomplish the 2020 Census and is standardized for use in budget planning, operational planning, and cost estimation. However, the Bureau's October 2017 cost estimate for the 2020 Census does not fully reflect characteristics of a high-quality estimate as described in GAO's Cost Estimating and Assessment Guide and cannot be considered reliable. GAO found the Bureau met or substantially met three out of the four characteristics of a reliable cost estimate, while it partially met one characteristic: well-documented. The Bureau's estimate was not overly optimistic; appeared to be free of errors; was based on historical data or input from subject matter experts; and, according to Bureau officials, is updated regularly as information becomes available. The Bureau can enhance the accuracy of their estimate by increasing the level of detail included in the documentation, such as detail on specific inflation indices used, and by monitoring actual costs against estimates. The Bureau's cost estimate substantially met the criteria for credible, which is the ability to control for uncertainties and control for them by identifying and quantifying cost elements that represent the most risk. The Bureau's cost estimate clearly identifies risks and uncertainties, and describes approaches taken to mitigate them. The Bureau's cost estimate is used by management to inform decisions about program resources and to effectively measure progress against operational objectives. The Bureau's cost estimate serves as a tool for program development and oversight, supporting management to make informed decisions. The Bureau's cost estimate is used to examine the cost impact of program changes. The Bureau's latest cost estimate, announced in October 2017, reflects the same design, but at an expected cost of $15.6 billion. The largest increases occurred in the Response, Managerial Contingency, and Census/Survey Engineering categories. Increased costs of $1.3 billion in the response category (costs related to collecting, maintaining, and processing survey response data) were in part due to reduced assumptions for self-response rates, leading to increases in the amount of data collected in the field, which is more costly to the Bureau. Contingency allocations increased overall from $1.35 billion in 2015 to $2.6 billion in 2017, as the Bureau gained a greater understanding of risks facing the 2020 Census. Increases of $838 million in the Census/Survey Engineering category were due mainly to the cost of an IT contract for integrating decennial survey systems that was not included in the 2015 cost estimate. Bureau officials attribute a decrease of $551 million in estimated costs for Program Management to changes in the categorization of costs associated with risks: In the 2017 version of the estimate, estimated costs related to program risks were allocated to their corresponding WBS element. More generally, factors that contributed to cost fluctuations between the 2015 and 2017 cost estimates include: changes in assumptions for census operations, improved ability to anticipate and quantify risk, an overall increase in information technology (IT) costs, and more defined contract requirements. What GAO Recommends GAO is not making any new recommendations to the Bureau in this report. The Bureau agreed with GAO's findings regarding the improvements the Bureau has made in its cost estimates. However, Commerce did not agree with GAO's assessment that the Bureau's 2017 lifecycle cost estimate is "not reliable." Commerce noted that it had conducted two independent cost analyses and was satisfied that the cost estimate was reliable. The Bureau also provided technical comments that GAO incorporated, as appropriate.
gao_GAO-18-698: Why GAO Did This Study IRS collects millions of dollars in whistleblower awards each year to help identify tax fraud and abuse. In fiscal year 2017, IRS paid out $34 million on 367 claims. In February 2018, the statutory change to include FBAR penalties in whistleblower awards was enacted. GAO was asked to review the whistleblower program. This report examines (1) the extent to which IRS included FBAR penalties in whistleblower awards prior to the statutory change; (2) how IRS used whistleblower information on FBAR noncompliance and how IRS responded to the statutory change in definition of proceeds; (3) the purposes for which IRS collects and uses data from the FBAR Database and assesses the controls for ensuring data reliability; and (4) what is known about the potential effect exclusions from collected proceeds, including FBAR penalties, may have on whistleblowers bringing claims to IRS. GAO reviewed IRS documents and interviewed IRS officials and whistleblower attorneys. GAO also reviewed a stratified sample of closed 7623(b) claims closed between January 1, 2012, and July 24, 2017. GAO also interviewed 11 attorneys representing whistleblowers who have filed claims with IRS. What GAO Found Prior to February 2018, the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) did not consider whistleblower information that may have led to FBAR enforcement actions in award determinations. IRS assessed approximately $10.7 million in FBAR penalties to taxpayers who were identified in GAO's sample of whistleblower claims. GAO reviewed 92 whistleblower claims closed between January 1, 2012, and July 24, 2017, where the identified taxpayer was also subject to an IRS FBAR examination. IRS assessed FBAR penalties in 28 of these 92 cases. In none of these instances was the FBAR penalty included in the collected proceeds used to calculate whistleblower awards. GAO's analysis of these 28 claims suggests that if IRS had included FBAR penalties in the awards, the whistleblowers involved could have received an additional $1.6 million to $3.2 million, assuming an award of between 15 and 30 percent. IRS historically used FBAR information from whistleblower claims for enforcement efforts, but the statutory change in award basis increases the importance of reporting full information. IRS has taken some steps to communicate change in whistleblower award basis. For example, IRS issued guidance on how to review claims for non-Title 26 issues, but the guidance had not been updated to reflect the new law. IRS uses its FBAR Database for internal and external reporting but lacks sufficient controls for the reliability of FBAR penalty data. GAO found that the data fields GAO used were sufficiently reliable for its purposes. For example, GAO matched taxpayer identification numbers in the FBAR Database to those in IRS's Electronic Tax Accounts Tracking (E-TRAK) database and reported on enforcement outcomes, including a limited number of penalty payments. However, GAO found certain elements of the database to have limited reliability. For example, GAO found 44 records with input errors in this field. Because the FBAR data lack some reliability controls, IRS may rely on insufficient or incomplete data for reporting and decision making, including amounts of whistleblower awards. Whistleblower attorneys GAO spoke with referred to the former exclusion for FBAR and other non-Title 26 collections from whistleblower awards as a significant concern for them and their clients. These attorneys cited other concerns with the program that could continue to limit their willingness to represent tax whistleblowers and discourage whistleblowers. These concerns included limits on anonymity for whistleblowers appealing IRS award determinations; restrictions on filing claims anonymously; delays in award payments during the lengthy appeals process; and limited communication with the Whistleblower Office during the claim review process. What GAO Recommends GAO recommends that IRS (1) update its guidance on how to document how whistleblower information was used in any IRS actions taken, regardless of whether the laws administered, examined, or enforced are outside of Title 26, such as FBAR penalties; (2) improve controls for the validity, completeness, and accuracy of data on FBAR exams and enforcement actions; and (3) improve controls for the validity, completeness, and accuracy of data on FBAR exams and enforcement actions. IRS agreed with GAO's recommendations.
gao_GAO-18-538: Why GAO Did This Study DHS is responsible for ensuring the security of the nation's chemical infrastructure by identifying high-risk chemical facilities, assessing the risk posed by them, and requiring the implementation of measures to protect them. DHS issued regulations establishing risk-based performance standards for chemical facilities that, as determined by DHS, present high levels of risk. GAO was asked to review DHS's CFATS program. This report examines (1) DHS's actions to strengthen its processes for identifying high-risk chemical facilities and (2) the extent to which DHS has taken actions to ensure that first responders and emergency planners have the information needed to prepare for and respond to incidents at high-risk chemical facilities. GAO reviewed DHS documents and interviewed DHS officials and representatives from 11 industry associations representing facilities covered by CFATS and considered high-risk. What GAO Found The Department of Homeland Security's (DHS) Office of Infrastructure Protection (ISCD) has taken action to strengthen its processes for identifying high-risk chemical facilities. In response to GAO's July 2015 report, ISCD implemented a new methodology to identify high-risk facilities and assign them a risk-based tier. In addition, ISCD revised its risk assessment methodology to more accurately identify and assign high-risk chemical facilities to tiers. ISCD has nearly completed its efforts to apply this new methodology to facilities covered by the Chemical Facility Anti-Terrorism Standards (CFATS) program. ISCD has conducted an increased number of compliance inspections and continues to make changes to improve the efficiency of the inspection process. However, GAO found that ISCD's methodology and resulting performance metric do not reflect the program's impact on reducing a facility's vulnerability to an attack. ISCD may have an opportunity to explore how reductions in vulnerability at individual facilities resulting from the CFATS compliance inspection process could be used to develop an overall measure of the performance of the CFATS program in lowering risk and increasing security nationwide. ISCD shares some CFATS information with state and local officials, including access to CFATS facility-specific data via a secure portal; however, this portal is not widely used at the local level by first responders and emergency planners. What GAO Recommends GAO recommends that DHS (1) incorporate vulnerability into the CFATS site security scoring methodology to help measure the reduction in the vulnerability of high-risk facilities to a terrorist attack, and use that data in assessing the CFATS program's performance in lowering risk and enhancing national security, and (2) encourage access to and wider use of the IP Gateway and explore other opportunities to improve information-sharing with first responders and emergency planners. DHS concurred with both recommendations and outlined efforts underway or planned to address them.
gao_GAO-18-85: Why GAO Did This Study The Food Safety Modernization Act of 2015 (FSMA) requires that businesses take steps to ensure that agricultural water that comes into contact with produce is safe and of adequate sanitary quality for its intended use. The rule also requires that businesses take steps to prevent contamination of sprouts, which have been associated with foodborne illness outbreaks. The rule also requires that businesses take steps to ensure that agricultural water that comes into contact with produce is safe and of adequate sanitary quality for its intended use. GAO was asked to review FDA's implementation of the produce rule. This report examines (1) FDA's efforts to evaluate and respond to business concerns regarding the rule and (2) FDA's efforts to evaluate and respond to business concerns regarding the rule. GAO reviewed FDA's information clearinghouse, the TAN, and other documents; interviewed FDA officials; and analyzed TAN responses from businesses and other stakeholders. GAO also interviewed representatives from two produce industry associations, a farming organization, and four organizations working with FDA to implement the produce rule. What GAO Found The Food and Drug Administration (FDA) has continued to evaluate and respond to business concerns regarding the Food Safety Modernization Act of 2015 (FSMA) produce rule. Since GAO last reported on the rule, FDA has continued to use its information clearinghouse, the TAN, to evaluate and respond to questions and concerns from businesses and other stakeholders regarding the rule. FDA has also taken other steps, including funding training for industry, conducting visits to farms, and publishing guidance, to evaluate and respond to concerns. In addition, FDA is reviewing the produce rule agricultural water standards and in September 2017 published a proposed rule to extend compliance dates associated with those standards. FDA officials said that the agency is considering adding clarifying information on the standards in forthcoming guidance and, if necessary, making changes to the standards themselves by revising the produce rule. FDA has begun collecting survey results to assess the effectiveness of its information clearinghouse, the TAN, and has continued to develop metrics that will assess outcomes related to the agency's overall efforts to evaluate and respond to business concerns. In October 2016, FDA implemented the first part of its survey assessing the TAN. This first part of the survey, which FDA sent to businesses and other stakeholders that submitted questions to the TAN, solicited feedback about the TAN web page provided for submitting questions. This survey included questions about how stakeholders learned about the TAN web page, the clarity of the page, and how FDA could improve the page. FDA officials said they have begun making changes to the TAN web page based on the survey results. In addition, FDA is developing the second part of its TAN survey, which will solicit feedback from stakeholders on the timeliness and quality of answers provided by FDA through the TAN. In addition, FDA is continuing to develop metrics intended to assess outcomes related to the agency's overall efforts to evaluate and respond to business concerns. These outcomes are specified in a draft strategic framework the agency has developed to monitor implementation of the produce rule. The framework includes outcomes such as businesses' compliance with the rule, expanded use of incentives for compliance, and increased dissemination of good practices and other on-farm findings. FDA officials said they are working to respond more quickly to TAN questions and are revising the FDA review process for TAN responses. In addition, representatives from four groups GAO interviewed said that businesses need more information from FDA to comply with the produce rule and are awaiting FDA's forthcoming guidance pertaining to the rule. FDA officials said they are aware of businesses' concerns about the need for additional guidance. These officials said they are working to publish guidance on various topics related to the produce rule, as GAO has described elsewhere in this report. What GAO Recommends GAO is not making recommendations in this report.
gao_GAO-18-365: Why GAO Did This Study FOIA requires federal agencies to provide the public with access to government information. The act also requires agencies to report annually to Justice on their use of statutory exemptions, which include withholding information from the public. GAO was asked to review the implementation of FOIA. This report examines (1) the extent to which agencies have implemented selected FOIA requirements; (2) the methods established by agencies to reduce backlogged requests and the effectiveness of those methods; (3) identifies any statutory (b)(3) exemptions that have been used by agencies as the basis for withholding (redacting) information; and (4) what FOIA requests, if any, agencies received and processed that related to entities that received government assistance during the 2008 financial crisis. GAO reviewed relevant laws, regulations, and guidance; analyzed agency data; and interviewed agency officials. What GAO Found The 18 agencies GAO reviewed had fully implemented half of the six key Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) requirements and the vast majority of agencies implemented two additional requirements. However, 5 agencies published and updated their FOIA regulations in a timely and comprehensive manner. Fully implementing FOIA requirements will better position agencies to provide the public with necessary access to government records and ensure openness in government. The 18 selected agencies had FOIA request backlogs of varying sizes, ranging from no backlogged requests at some agencies to 45,000 or more of requests at other agencies. Generally, the agencies with the largest backlogs had received the most requests. In an effort to aid agencies in reducing their backlogs, Justice's Office of Information Policy (OIP) identified key practices that agencies can use. However, while the agencies reported using these practices and other methods, few of them managed to reduce their backlogs during the period from fiscal year 2012 through 2016. In particular, of the four agencies with the largest backlogs, only one—the National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA)—reduced its backlog. Agencies attributed their inability to decrease backlogs to the increased number and complexity of requests, among other factors. However, agencies also lack comprehensive plans to implement practices on an ongoing basis. During fiscal years 2010 to 2016, agencies claimed 237 statutes as the basis for withholding information. Of these statutes, the majority—178—fell into 4 of the 8 categories of information. The remaining 59 statutes were in four categories: internal agency functions and practices, financial regulation, international affairs, and environmental. The number of statutes not having a reference to the statutory exemption is evidence of the OPEN FOIA Act's uneven impact on the establishment of statutory exemptions. What GAO Recommends GAO recommends that the Secretary of the American Battle Monuments Commission designate a chief FOIA officer at the assistant secretary level or equivalent. The Department of Homeland Security concurred with the recommendations.
gao_GAO-18-339SP: Why GAO Did This Study DHS's mission to safeguard the American people and homeland requires a broad portfolio of acquisitions. However, the performance of DHS's major acquisition portfolio during 2017 did not improve compared to GAO's last review because more programs will require more time and may require more money to complete than initially planned. DHS is collecting more timely cost estimate information on its acquisition programs to make more informed investment decisions. Yet DHS continues to face challenges in funding its acquisition portfolio, which highlights the need for disciplined policies that reflect best practices to ensure that the department does not pursue more programs than it can afford. GAO was asked to review DHS's acquisition management, requirements development, test and evaluation, and resource allocation processes. This report examines (1) the extent to which DHS's major acquisition programs were on track to meet schedule and cost goals during 2017 and (2) DHS's policies for managing its acquisition portfolio and the extent to which they reflect key portfolio management practices. GAO reviewed DHS's acquisition management, requirements development, test and evaluation, and resource allocation policies and interviewed DHS officials. What GAO Found Of the 24 programs GAO assessed with approved schedule and cost goals, 10 were on track to meet those goals during 2017. The other 14 programs were not on track because they changed or breached their schedule goals, cost goals, or both. GAO found that most programs updated their cost estimates in response to requirements DHS established in January 2016 that are intended to provide decision makers with more timely information. These actions are in accordance with GAO's best practice to regularly update cost estimates and GAO plans to use these updated estimates to measure programs' cost changes going forward. DHS revised the format of its Future Years Homeland Security Program report to include acquisition affordability tables for select major acquisition programs. However, the report shows—and GAO's analysis of programs' current cost estimates confirms—that some programs face acquisition funding gaps in fiscal year 2018. GAO also reviewed 4 programs that were early in the acquisition process and planned to establish department-approved schedule and cost goals in calendar year 2017. However, these programs were delayed in getting department approval for their initial acquisition program baselines (APB) for various reasons and, therefore, GAO excluded them from GAO's assessment of whether programs were on track to meet their schedule and cost goals during 2017. DHS leadership subsequently approved initial APBs for 2 particularly complex and costly programs—a border wall system along the southwest U.S. border and the Coast Guard's Heavy Polar Icebreaker—in January 2018. GAO plans to assess these programs in next year's review, but provide more details on all 4 additional programs in the individual assessments in appendix I. DHS's policies for managing its acquisition portfolio generally reflect key portfolio management practices, but opportunities exist to leverage the results of these policies. For example, DHS's policies require components to submit a certification of funds memorandum when a program re-baselines as a result of a cost, schedule, or performance breach. DHS leadership approved the program's revised APB and removed it from breach status, even though DHS's Chief Financial Officer identified that the program's revised LCCE was not affordable. DHS leadership subsequently approved initial APBs for 2 particularly complex and costly programs—a border wall system along the southwest U.S. border and the Coast Guard's Heavy Polar Icebreaker—in January 2018. GAO plans to assess these programs in next year's review, but provide more details on all 4 additional programs in the individual assessments in appendix I. What GAO Recommends GAO recommends that DHS (1) update its acquisition management policy to require components to submit a certification of funds memorandum when a major acquisition program re-baselines as a result of a breach; and (2) require components to assess the results of major acquisition programs' post-implementation reviews and identify opportunities to improve performance across the acquisition portfolio. DHS concurred with both recommendations and identified actions it planned to take to address them.
gao_GAO-18-262: Why GAO Did This Study NASA is responsible for ensuring that its contractors and subgrantees are protected from reprisal if they disclose to certain persons or bodies information they reasonably believe is evidence of gross mismanagement of a federal contract or grant, a gross waste of federal funds, an abuse of authority relating to a federal contract or grant, or a violation of law, rule, or regulation related to a NASA contract or grant. In 2014, the statute was amended with the only significant change to protect grantee and subgrantee employees. GAO was asked to review the implementation of the whistleblower protections. This report examines (1) the extent to which NASA has investigated contractor and grantee whistleblower reprisal complaints and developed guidance for the investigations, (2) the extent to which NASA communicated the applicable whistleblower reprisal protections externally with contractors, and (3) the extent to which NASA communicated the applicable whistleblower reprisal protections with grantees. GAO reviewed relevant documentation, including guidance, and interviewed NASA officials. GAO also reviewed a generalizable sample of contracts awarded in fiscal year 2016 to determine the extent to which NASA included a whistleblower clause. What GAO Found From 2008 to June 2017, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration's (NASA) Office of Inspector General (OIG) addressed whistleblower reprisal complaints within required time frames. The OIG received 277 whistleblower disclosures leading to 48 reprisal complaints from 2008 through June 2017, and handled those complaints within required time frames. The OIG updated its guidance for investigating reprisal complaints to include subgrantee employees. During the course of GAO's review, the OIG updated the investigation guidance in October 2017 to include subgrantee employees. The Administrator of the NASA Office of Inspector General (OIG) failed to meet the required review time frame and issue an order of final determination of reprisal for 5 completed investigations received from the OIG from 2008 through June 2017. In all 5 cases, the Administrator took longer than the 30 days to issue an order. In one of those 5 complaints, an official from the Office of General Counsel was unable to provide GAO with the issued order and said he did not believe one was completed, and could not provide an explanation as to why an order was not completed. Despite acknowledging these challenges, the Administrator does not have a formal process or criteria to monitor and evaluate the way the office handles issuing an order of final determination of reprisal to ensure that it meets the statutory time requirements. Without monitoring, evaluating, and taking appropriate corrective action based on the way the Administrator or his or her designee makes a final determination of reprisal, there is no assurance that whistleblower reprisal complaints will be handled within required time frames in the future. NASA almost always communicates whistleblower protections to its contractors, but internal guidance is unclear. In almost all of the contracts GAO reviewed, NASA had met its obligation to ensure its contractors are communicating whistleblower protections to their employees through a whistleblower contract clause. GAO also found that NASA has put in place guidance to its contracting workforce on the protections, and guidance on when to include the whistleblower clause in contracts. However, GAO found that some NASA officials have interpreted this guidance differently. Further, NASA's guidance does not reflect an agency-wide policy on when to include the whistleblower clause when modifying a contract. Unlike provisions affecting contractors, the statute does not require NASA to ensure that grantees or subgrantees notify employees in writing of their rights under the statute. Unlike the requirement for NASA to ensure contractors communicate whistleblower reprisal rights to their employees in writing and in the employees' predominant language, the statute does not prescribe a similar requirement for NASA to ensure that grantees communicate whistleblower reprisal protections to their employees. During the grant application process, NASA requires grantees to attest that they will not require grantee employees to sign confidentiality agreements that would prohibit them from reporting fraud, waste, and abuse. NASA officials said that grant awards do not include a mechanism, such as a term or condition, to encourage NASA grantees to notify their employees of their whistleblower reprisal protections. What GAO Recommends GAO recommends that NASA monitor, evaluate, and make appropriate corrective actions, such as a documented process, to ensure it reviews reprisal complaints in a timely manner. NASA concurred with all three recommendations.
gao_GAO-18-692T: Why GAO Did This Study Railroads are required to implement PTC to prevent train-to-train collisions, derailments due to excessive speed, and incursions into work zone limits. Railroads may receive a maximum 2-year extension from FRA past the December 31, 2018, deadline if they meet six criteria set forth in statute. GAO was asked to testify on the implementation of PTC. This statement addresses (1) the status of PTC implementation and FRA's efforts to ensure railroads are in compliance with PTC deadlines and (2) the extent to which FRA has taken steps to ensure railroads are in compliance with PTC deadlines. This statement is based on GAO's March 2018 report, which examined PTC implementation and FRA's efforts to ensure railroads are in compliance with PTC deadlines. GAO reviewed FRA documents and interviewed FRA officials and representatives from 40 railroads. What GAO Found As of June 30, 2018, many railroads reported that they remain in the equipment installation and field-testing stages, which are early stages of PTC implementation. However, since GAO last testified in March 2018, railroads have made progress on equipment installation. Specifically, about half of the 40 railroads reported being more than 90 percent complete with locomotive equipment installation. Similarly, nearly three-quarters of railroads that must install wayside equipment reported being more than 90 percent complete. The remaining one-quarter of railroads are among those designated by FRA as at-risk of both not meeting the end of 2018 implementation deadline and not completing the requirements necessary to qualify for an extension. Specifically, in August 2018, FRA identified 9 railroads—all commuter railroads—as at-risk, fewer than the 12 railroads FRA had previously designated as at risk in its June 2018 letters to railroads. In June, July, and August 2018, FRA held three PTC symposiums that were attended by representatives from all 40 railroads and that focused on the extension process and substitute criteria, PTC testing, and safety plans, respectively. FRA's June 2018 symposium covered information consistent with GAO's March 2018 recommendation that the agency adopt a method for systematically communicating information related to the requirements and process for an extension to railroads. FRA officials said that they have clarified that for railroads eligible to use substitute criteria, initiating field testing was one approach that could potentially qualify as substitute criteria, rather than initiating revenue service demonstration (RSD). Representatives from the railroads that participated in the symposiums found them to be helpful and some railroads reported that the information presented led them to adjust their approach to meeting the December 2018 deadline. In recent months, FRA has continued to provide assistance to railroads and has taken a series of steps to better prepare railroads for the 2018 deadline. More than three-quarters of railroads (32 of 40) reported to GAO that they plan to apply for an extension. However, FRA officials noted that with the exception of possibly one or two railroads, they anticipate that all railroads will likely need an extension. gao_GAO-18-140: Why GAO Did This Study FDA is responsible for reviewing medical devices to ensure their safety and effectiveness. In 1997, FDA added a requirement that the agency use the least burdensome approach during certain parts of PMA and 510(k) reviews. FDAMA also added a provision that GAO review FDA's implementation of the least burdensome requirements. This report examines (1) the extent to which FDA requested additional information to support medical device reviews, and the factors that contributed to disagreements between sponsors and FDA, and (2) FDA's training on the least burdensome requirements and how it evaluates its training. GAO reviewed FDA guidance and training, and interviewed FDA officials and industry representatives. GAO also reviewed FDA's audit plans and interviewed FDA officials. What GAO Found The Food and Drug Administration (FDA) frequently requested additional information to support medical device reviews, and sponsor disagreements often related to the least burdensome requirements. FDA requested sponsors provide additional information for a majority of the medical device submissions it reviewed from 2001 through 2016. For example, from 2001 through 2016, FDA issued a large number of deficiency letters relative to the number of submissions, although there was variation annually. FDA officials acknowledged the historical increase in the number of deficiency letters and additional information letters, and noted the more recent decrease. The least burdensome requirements were often a significant contributing factor in disagreements between medical device sponsors, according to FDA officials and available FDA data. FDA officials said the most effective means of resolving disagreements is through discussion and mediation, and to that end, the Ombudsman's office is routinely involved in discussions between firms and medical device reviewers during the review process. FDA officials indicated that training specific to the least burdensome requirements was held in the years following the enactment of FDAMA in 1997. FDA officials said the agency offered other presentations in subsequent years that they said covered similar least burdensome topics. FDA officials said the agency is implementing such processes for all training, including courses related to the least burdensome requirements. FDA is also required by the 21st Century Cures Act to conduct an audit of the training and its effectiveness in implementing the least burdensome requirements. FDA is taking steps that may improve its requests for additional information overall, but has not fully evaluated its implementation of the least burdensome requirements. FDA is developing and implementing smart templates that guide reviewers as they evaluate medical device submissions and develop requests for additional information. FDA officials told GAO that the agency has had a smart template in place for the 510(k) process since 2013, and plans to hire a person to develop a template to guide PMA reviews, which will likely take most of 2018. FDA officials told GAO that the agency plans to hire a person to develop a template to guide PMA reviews, which will likely take most of 2018. In addition, FDA officials told GAO that the agency has not developed performance metrics that would allow it to evaluate its implementation of the least burdensome requirements. According to federal standards for internal control, performance metrics are important for management to have relevant, reliable, and timely information available for management decision-making and external reporting purposes. Without such a metric, FDA may be asking medical device sponsors to provide information unnecessarily or in less efficient ways that are not in compliance with the requirement to use the least burdensome approach to medical device reviews. What GAO Recommends GAO recommends that FDA develop performance metrics and use them to evaluate the implementation of the least burdensome requirements, such as during its planned audits of medical device deficiency letters. gao_GAO-19-176: Why GAO Did This Study IRS is responsible for ensuring that taxpayers comply with tax laws and that the agency has the capacity to hire and train its workforce. IRS has a long-standing lack of a strategic approach to human capital management. GAO designated strategic human capital management as a high-risk area in 2001 because of the federal government's long-standing lack of a consistent strategic approach to human capital management. GAO was asked to review IRS's strategic workforce planning efforts. This report assesses (1) how IRS defines its workforce needs and develops strategies for shaping its workforce; (2) the extent to which IRS identified the critical skills and competencies it will require to meet its goals, and describe its strategy to address skills gaps in its workforce; and (3) the extent to which IRS's Human Capital Office (HCO) has the capacity to hire employees in hard to fill positions. GAO reviewed IRS's strategic workforce planning efforts, analyzed IRS data, and interviewed IRS and Treasury officials. What GAO Found IRS has scaled back strategic workforce planning activities in recent years. Prior to 2011, IRS staff within its HCO or other dedicated program office conducted and coordinated agency-wide strategic workforce planning efforts. IRS officials told GAO that resource constraints and fewer staff with strategic workforce planning skills due to attrition since 2011 required HCO to largely abandon strategic workforce planning activities. Instead, HCO generally focused its efforts on completing HR transactions, such as retirements and benefits processing, meeting legal compliance activities, and facilitating hiring of seasonal employees. Since 2011, key human capital activities—such as developing an inventory of skills, identifying skills gaps, and attrition forecasting—decreased and shifted to the individual business divisions and program offices. IRS officials cited management familiarity of programmatic needs, challenges, processes, and culture as a benefit of workforce planning autonomy at business divisions and program offices. However, the officials told GAO these activities were often performed only to the extent those divisions had the time, resources, and top management interest. As a result, the quality of key human capital activities was uneven across the agency, if performed at all. In addition, IRS's implementation of its workforce planning initiative has been delayed for three primary reasons, according to IRS documents and officials. IRS could improve reporting on its progress in addressing skills gaps. High attrition among IRS employees, particularly in complex enforcement occupations and lower-than-average employee satisfaction rates, puts IRS at continued risk of skills gaps. These skills gaps have already been a significant contributor to IRS's decisions to scale back important enforcement activities that are critical to promoting voluntary compliance and closing the tax gap. However, IRS has not targeted its limited resources to addressing issues among the mission critical occupations most at risk of skills gaps. Instead, activities such as skills gaps assessments are only conducted to the extent business divisions and program offices make resources available, and management is aware of and inclined to seek assistance from IRS's HCO. Reporting on the results of efforts to close skills gap and developing a work plan or other mechanism for prioritizing assessments would better position IRS to address key gaps. Additionally, the results of an interagency working group effort intended to address skill gaps among IRS revenue agents and other occupations with skills gaps across the government may hold important lessons for addressing skills gaps among mission critical occupations at IRS. Each of these issues is exacerbated by limited capacity within HCO, which has redirected its resources to implementing the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act and meeting other routine transactional human resource requirements. Measuring the extent to which each of activities is effective would help HCO target resources to the most effective activities as it seeks to improve its capacity for hiring employees in hard to fill positions in the future. What GAO Recommends GAO recommends that IRS fully implement its strategic workforce planning initiative, improve reporting on its progress in addressing skills gaps, and develop a work plan or other mechanism for prioritizing assessments. IRS agreed with GAO's recommendations.

gao_GAO-18-40: Why GAO Did This Study The drug industry is a complex network of companies that conduct research, development, and marketing for new drugs. The federal government supports new drug research through tax incentives and other mechanisms. GAO was asked to review the drug industry. This report examines (1) how the financial performance and structure of the drug industry have changed over time; (2) how reported research and development spending and new drug approvals have changed; and (3) what is known about the potential effects of consolidation on drug prices and new drug development. GAO analyzed data from 2006 through 2015 on pharmaceutical and biotechnology sales revenue, profit margins, and mergers and acquisitions; reviewed literature; and interviewed agency officials, industry experts, and academics. What GAO Found According to the data GAO reviewed, the financial performance and structure of the drug industry have changed over time, with most companies reporting pharmaceutical and biotechnology sales revenue and profit margins for most companies grew from 2006 through 2015. The number of mergers and acquisitions among companies in the industry generally held steady from 2006 through 2015, but merger and acquisition deal values increased. Market concentration varied by the specific market level considered. Industry experts GAO interviewed noted that market pressures have driven structural changes in the industry. For example, some companies that traditionally manufactured brand-name drugs are expanding into the manufacturing of generic drugs. Similarly, some traditionally generic manufacturers are expanding into brand-name manufacturing to acquire product lines with more generous profit margins. In addition, some companies that traditionally manufactured biologics are expanding into the manufacturing of generic drugs. In addition, some companies that traditionally manufactured biologics are expanding into the manufacturing of generic drugs. The growth in pharmaceutical company-reported research and development spending grew slightly from 2008 through 2014, while federally funded spending decreased slightly over the period. Industry spending focused on drug development rather than earlier-stage research, whereas direct federal spending, such as through National Institutes of Health grants, funded a greater amount of basic research. Claims for the orphan drug credit, one of several federal tax incentives encouraging drug development, increased sharply from 2005 through 2014. Biologics and orphan drugs accounted for an increasing share of new drug approvals from 2005 through 2016. Studies GAO reviewed and experts interviewed suggested that potential revenues, costs, and policy incentives influenced drug company R&D investment decisions. Research GAO examined in its literature review suggests that the level of competition in a relevant market influences drug prices. Competition also matters for innovation. Certain empirical economic studies suggest that mergers among brand-name drug companies can negatively impact companies' innovation post-merger. What GAO Recommends GAO is not making recommendations in this report.
gao_GAO-18-220: Why GAO Did This Study Medicaid demonstrations allow states to test new approaches to providing and financing Medicaid coverage. The Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS) oversees these demonstrations. GAO was asked to review CMS's oversight of state-led evaluations. This report examines (1) the limitations in state-led evaluations and the extent to which CMS has addressed them, and (2) the extent to which CMS has evaluated state-led evaluations. GAO reviewed CMS documents and interviewed CMS officials and contractors. GAO also reviewed CMS's evaluations of demonstrations in selected states. GAO selected these states based on the number of years the demonstrations had been in effect and cost, among other things. GAO also interviewed CMS officials and contractors. What GAO Found The limitations in state-led evaluations of Medicaid demonstrations in selected states hindered their usefulness for federal decision-making. For example, the limitations in state-led evaluations—including methodological weaknesses and gaps in results—have, in part, hindered CMS's use of them to inform its policy decisions. CMS has taken steps since 2014 to improve the quality of state-led evaluations, but the agency has not established written procedures to help implement some of these improvements. For example, CMS has begun requiring states to submit final evaluation reports at the end of each demonstration cycle, rather than after the expiration of the demonstration. However, CMS has not established written procedures for implementing its planned policy, for example, for ensuring that the requirement is included in the demonstrations' strategic planning documents (STC) for all demonstrations, despite unique negotiations with each state. Federal internal control standards stress that management should implement control activities through policies. However, CMS does not have written procedures for implementing its planned policy, for example, for ensuring that the requirement is included in the STCs for all demonstrations, despite unique negotiations with each state, and that those requirements are consistently enforced. As a result, some state-led evaluations could continue to produce only more limited, interim findings that leave critical questions about the effects of the demonstrations on beneficiaries and costs unanswered. Data and other challenges have significantly limited the scope and progress of CMS's large, multi-state evaluation and the agency's evaluation of Indiana's demonstration. These challenges included limitations in the quality of CMS data and delays obtaining data directly from states. These limitations caused CMS to narrow the evaluation's scope, often by reducing the number of state demonstrations evaluated or limiting what was being examined. Despite these challenges, CMS's evaluations are likely to provide new information on the effects of demonstrations in different states to inform policy decisions. CMS has not released initial reports from the multi-state evaluation, limiting the potential use of those findings by states and other federal policymakers. CMS officials said that the reports were still under agency review and acknowledged that since some of the reports were almost 2 years old, CMS's contractor was reviewing and updating the information in them. CMS officials said that the reports had provided useful information and had influenced ongoing work with states designing related demonstrations. However, despite having received some of these reports from its contractor in 2015, CMS had not released these findings as of October 2017. What GAO Recommends GAO recommends that CMS (1) establish written procedures for implementing its policy requiring states to submit final evaluation reports after the end of each demonstration cycle, regardless of renewal status; (2) issue written criteria for when CMS will allow limited evaluation of a demonstration or a portion of a demonstration, including defining conditions, such as what it means for a demonstration to be longstanding or noncomplex, as applicable; and (3) establish and implement a policy for publicly releasing findings from federal evaluations of demonstrations, including findings from rapid cycle, interim, and final reports. HHS concurred with all three recommendations.
