gao_GAO-19-48: Why GAO Did This Study The nation's pipeline network is a vital part of the nation's transportation infrastructure. Terrorists and other malicious actors have attempted to disrupt the nation's pipeline network. TSA's Pipeline Security Branch is responsible for overseeing the physical security and cybersecurity of the nation's pipeline system. GAO was asked to review TSA's pipeline security program. This report examines (1) the extent to which pipeline operators use security guidelines and standards to address their physical and cybersecurity risks, and (2) the extent to which TSA has established performance measures and data to assess the effectiveness of its efforts to reduce risks to pipelines. GAO reviewed TSA's Pipeline Security Guidelines, analyzed TSA data, and interviewed TSA officials and 10 pipeline operators and industry association representatives. What GAO Found Pipeline operators that GAO interviewed reported using a range of guidelines and standards to address their physical and cybersecurity risks, and all of them reported implementing the Transportation Security Administration's (TSA) voluntary Pipeline Security Guidelines that were applicable to their operations. TSA revised and issued its Pipeline Security Guidelines in March 2018, but the revised guidelines lack a documented process to consider updates to supporting guidance such as to the National Institute of Standards and Technology's Cybersecurity Framework. Without a documented process defining how frequently TSA is to review and revise its guidelines, TSA cannot ensure that its guidelines reflect the latest known standards and best practices for physical and cybersecurity, or address the persistent and dynamic security threat environment currently facing the nation's pipeline system. TSA's Pipeline Security Branch conducts security reviews to assess pipeline operators' implementation of TSA's Pipeline Security Guidelines, but gaps in staffing and lack of a workforce plan may affect its ability to carry out effective reviews. The Pipeline Security Branch developed a pipeline risk assessment to rank relative risk of the top 100 critical pipeline systems and to prioritize its security reviews of pipeline companies, but shortfalls in its calculations of threat, vulnerability, and consequence may limit its ability to accurately identify pipeline systems with the highest risk. Finally, the pipeline risk assessment has not been peer reviewed to validate the assessment's data and methodology, which GAO previously reported as a best practice in risk management. TSA has established performance measures, as well as databases to monitor pipeline security reviews and analyze their results. However, weaknesses in its performance measures and its efforts to record pipeline security review recommendations limit its ability to determine the extent that its pipeline security program has reduced pipeline sector risks. For example, many of TSA's measures cover agency goals and mission, but they generally lack clarity and measurable targets, provide significantly overlapping information, and do not include baseline and trend data. Further, TSA has not tracked the implementation status of past recommendations for over 5 years and related security review data are not sufficiently reliable. Until TSA monitors and records the status of these reviews' recommendations, it will be hindered in its efforts to determine whether its recommendations are leading to significant reduction in risk. What GAO Recommends GAO recommends that TSA (1) implement a documented process for reviewing, and if deemed necessary, revising its Pipeline Security Guidelines at regular defined intervals; (2) develop a strategic workforce plan for its Security Policy and Industry Engagement's Surface Division; (3) update the Pipeline Relative Risk Ranking Tool to include up-to-date data; (4) fully document the data sources, underlying assumptions, and judgments that form the basis of the assessment; and (5) incorporate that data into the Pipeline Relative Risk Ranking Tool to assess relative risk of critical pipeline systems. DHS concurred with GAO's recommendations.
gao_GAO-19-212: Why GAO Did This Study DOD is responsible for approving contractor business systems that reduce risk to the government and taxpayer. In fiscal year 2017, DOD spent approximately $1.4 billion on contractor business systems. In fiscal year 2017, DCAA reported that it had a backlog of incomplete incurred cost audits. GAO was asked to review the CBS review process. This report examines (1) the extent to which DOD has clarified roles and responsibilities for conducting CBS reviews and (2) the extent to which DOD has a mechanism to monitor and ensure that contractor business system reviews and audits are conducted in a timely manner. GAO reviewed relevant laws, regulations, and guidance; analyzed DCMA and DCAA data; and interviewed officials from DCMA and DCAA. What GAO Found The Department of Defense (DOD) has taken actions to clarify the roles and responsibilities of the Defense Contract Management Agency (DCMA) and the Defense Contract Audit Agency (DCAA) in conducting business system reviews and consolidate the number of reviews to be performed; clarify how often DOD should conduct business system reviews; establish what criteria are used to evaluate a contractor's business system; establish timeframes by which Administrative Contracting Officers (ACO) are to make a determination on the adequacy of the contractors' business systems; and implement the use of payment withholds for contractors that are found to have significant deficiencies in their contractor business systems. GAO's review of six selected contractors' business system reviews found that the whole process from the review or audit, to the follow up and resolution, can be lengthy. In three out of six selected cases GAO reviewed, it took 4 or more years for a contractor's system to be approved. DCMA and DCAA do not have a mechanism to monitor and ensure that contractor business system reviews and audits are conducted in a timely manner. DCAA's data show that it conducted few business system audits in the past 6 years, due, in part, to the need for it to reduce its backlog on completing incurred cost audits. Looking to the future, DCAA has developed plans for the number of CBS audits it intends to perform over the next 3 years and expects that it will be caught up in conducting the audits for which it is responsible by fiscal year 2022. Successfully executing its plan is dependent on several factors, including the ability to shift resources from conducting incurred cost audits to business systems audits, the use of public accounting firms to perform a portion of the incurred cost audits, and the ability of DCAA auditors to use new audit plans and complete the required audits in a timely manner. For its part, DCMA relies on the offices that perform the reviews of the three systems to maintain the information on the reviews completed and to plan for future reviews, but DCMA headquarters does not centrally track its reviews or whether audits conducted by DCAA are being completed within the timeframes described in policy. What GAO Recommends GAO recommends that DCMA, in collaboration with DCAA, develop a mechanism to monitor and assess whether contractor business system reviews are being completed in a timely manner. DOD agreed with the recommendation.
gao_GAO-19-76: Why GAO Did This Study DOT has promulgated consumer protection regulations to enhance airline consumer protections since 2009, and DOT has taken steps to educate passengers about their rights. GAO was asked to review DOT's efforts to ensure airlines' compliance with consumer protection requirements. This report examines (1) trends in DOT data on airline service from 2008 through 2017 and airlines' actions to improve service; (2) how effectively DOT ensures airlines' compliance with consumer protection requirements; and (3) the extent to which DOT's airline passenger education efforts align with key practices for consumer outreach. GAO analyzed DOT data on airline service from 2008 through 2017 and interviewed DOT officials and representatives from 11 selected airlines. GAO also reviewed relevant literature and interviewed DOT officials. What GAO Found The Department of Transportation (DOT) data provide mixed information on whether service improved from 2008 through 2017. DOT requires reporting airlines to provide operational data, including information on late, cancelled, or diverted flights; mishandled baggage; and denied boardings. These data showed some general improvement in the quality of airline service from 2008 through 2017. However, during the same time period, the total number of passenger complaints filed with DOT increased for "selected" airlines. Moreover, while these data may be imperfect measures of service quality, they do provide some indication of the passenger experience. DOT publishes data on both operational performance and passengers' complaints in its monthly Air Travel Consumer Report to inform the public about the quality of services provided by airlines. DOT promotes and monitors airlines' compliance with consumer protection requirements and deters noncompliance in five key ways, such as by reviewing passenger complaint data and taking enforcement action where it identifies violations. However, GAO found that DOT could improve its procedures to provide additional assurances that analysts consistently code passengers' complaints and properly identify potential consumer protection violations, in addition to more fully utilizing data from DOT's information systems to inform its compliance program. DOT has objectives for each of its five key compliance activities, but it lacks performance measures for three of these objectives. As a result, DOT is limited in its ability to assess progress toward achieving its goal of promoting airlines' compliance with consumer protection requirements or to identify and make any needed improvements. DOT has made recent improvements to its aviation consumer protection website, but its passenger education efforts do not fully align with key practices for consumer outreach. For example, DOT has successfully identified the goals and objectives of its passenger education program and identified the appropriate media mix for disseminating its materials. Similarly, GAO found that DOT had identified and engaged stakeholders, a step that, according to DOT officials, allowed them to better tailor materials. However, DOT's actions do not align with the key practice to "identify resources" and only partially align with the key practice to "develop consistent, clear messages" based on the established budget. Obtaining input directly from passengers on what information they want or what they know about their rights would provide DOT with greater assurance that educational materials are appropriately tailored to meet a wide range of passengers' needs. Finally, DOT has not established performance measures to understand the quality of its passenger education materials (i.e., process measures) or the effectiveness of its efforts (i.e., outcome measures). DOT officials said that they receive informal input from stakeholders on the quality of the materials and track website traffic to understand whether materials are reaching passengers. However, these mechanisms do not help it understand the quality of the materials and measure the success of its passenger education efforts. Establishing such measures would provide DOT with greater assurance that its educational efforts are appropriately tailored to passengers and leading to improved understanding of passengers' rights, including whether any adjustments are needed. What GAO Recommends GAO recommends that DOT assess its procedures and training materials for coding passenger complaints, as appropriate, to help ensure that passengers' complaints are consistently coded and that potential consumer protection violations are properly identified. DOT concurred with GAO's recommendations.
gao_GAO-19-124: Why GAO Did This Study The United States exported over $2 billion in tobacco and tobacco-related products in 2017. Congress has restricted the use of funds that are generally appropriated for State, Commerce, and USDA from being used to promote the sale or export of U.S. tobacco or tobacco products since the 1990s. In fiscal year 2018, Congress altered the restriction language in the act making appropriations for State, which makes promotion activities permissive with respect to the use of State appropriations. GAO was asked to review the implementation of these restrictions. This report examines (1) the guidance select U.S. agencies have issued to implement funding restrictions on promoting tobacco exports overseas, (2) to what extent overseas officials from select U.S. agencies were aware of the restrictions and guidance, and (3) to what extent select U.S. agencies have implemented this guidance overseas. GAO reviewed agency documents and interviewed officials in headquarters from State, Commerce, and USDA. GAO also interviewed representatives of the tobacco control community and business associations. What GAO Found The Departments of State (State), Commerce (Commerce), and Agriculture (USDA) collaborate with each other to develop and periodically issue an interagency guidance cable to implement funding restrictions on promoting tobacco. State officials draft the updated cable and Commerce, USDA, and other agency officials have the opportunity to review and comment on it before State issues it through its cable system. This cable serves as the primary source of guidance for implementing the restrictions on promoting tobacco for their officials overseas. Commerce relies on both the interagency guidance cable as well as its client eligibility policy to implement restrictions on promoting tobacco. USDA relies on the interagency guidance cable to provide direction to its officials overseas, and does not have agency-specific guidance for implementing its permanent funding restrictions on promoting tobacco. USDA officials said that the cable sufficiently addresses the funding restrictions on the agency's promotion activities and helps to ensure that all officials serving at posts overseas conduct activities in a consistent manner. Most State, Commerce, and USDA officials overseas GAO interviewed were aware of the restrictions on promoting tobacco and received some guidance concerning the restrictions, but many did not receive training about the restrictions. Officials in 21 of the 24 offices overseas GAO interviewed were aware of the restrictions. The three offices that were not aware of the restrictions were from State. Although these officials were not aware of the restrictions, they said they had never provided services to U.S. tobacco companies. Commerce and USDA officials said the guidance concerning these restrictions has been consistent for many years and that staff in the field and in headquarters are very aware of the restrictions. Officials in 15 of the 24 offices overseas GAO interviewed said they did not receive any training concerning the restrictions. Federal internal control standards state that appropriate training, aimed at developing employee knowledge, skills, and abilities, is essential to an organization's operational success. If agencies do not explicitly include information about the restrictions and related guidance in training materials for officials conducting export promotion activities overseas, officials may work at a post for several months, or longer, before learning about the restrictions. Officials in 24 offices in nine countries and GAO's review of agency documents showed that posts have implemented the funding restrictions on tobacco as outlined in the interagency guidance cable issued by State. For example, post officials said they have not promoted the sale or export of tobacco or tobacco products or attended events solely sponsored by tobacco companies, though many officials said they attended events at which officials from tobacco companies were present. Post officials identified three areas of the guidance that may benefit from additional clarification, according to GAO interviews with agency officials and GAO's review of agency emails. For example, officials raised questions about whether and when it is permissible to attend events at which tobacco company representatives are present. The guidance does not specifically address attendance at events also attended by representatives of tobacco companies. State headquarters officials said the vast majority of questions received from posts concern whether personnel at a post may participate in an event when representatives from a company engaged in the tobacco industry are also expected to participate in that event. Officials also asked for additional guidance about the types of services they are permitted to provide to tobacco companies or the types of companies or products they can support. For example, some officials asked whether they could engage with the host country government to obtain information about pending tobacco-related legislation at the request of a tobacco company. In addition, some officials also indicated that the current guidance lacks clarity on the types of services officials are allowed to provide to tobacco companies and what constitutes a tobacco product. More specific guidance would help ensure that State, Commerce, and USDA officials consistently implement their agency-specific funding restrictions on promoting tobacco exports. What GAO Recommends GAO recommends that State and USDA work with the Foreign Service Institute to include information about the restrictions and relevant guidance on promoting the sale or export of tobacco or tobacco products in its training materials
gao_GAO-18-59: Why GAO Did This Study The Coast Guard relies on EHRs to provide health care services to nearly 50,000 members throughout the United States. However, the agency has not implemented an EHR system since 2010, and the agency has been unable to return to managing health records using its legacy electronic capabilities. In 2010, the Coast Guard began an effort to expand the original EHR modernization effort to integrate other necessary and outdated services. In 2010, the Coast Guard awarded a $14 million contract to acquire a commercial off-the-shelf EHR system. However, the agency decided to terminate the project in October 2015, citing financial, technical, schedule, and personnel risks. GAO was asked to review the Coast Guard's management and oversight of the project. This report (1) describes what led the agency to the decision to terminate further development of the project, and how much was spent on the project; (2) evaluates the Coast Guard's management and oversight actions for the discontinued EHR modernization project and what, if any, lessons learned were identified; (3) describes the Coast Guard's current process for managing health records and the challenges, if any, it is encountering; and (4) determines the Coast Guard's plans for effectively implementing a new EHR system and the current status of its efforts. GAO reviewed relevant Coast Guard policies and guidance, surveyed 166 clinics and 125 sick bays, and interviewed Coast Guard officials. What GAO Found The United States Coast Guard (Coast Guard) abruptly discontinued the Integrated Health Information System (IHiS) project in October 2015, citing financial, technical, schedule, and personnel risks. The Coast Guard ordered project management and contractor staff to cease work on IHiS until a determination was made regarding the antideficiency violation. In addition, the Director of HSWL provided GAO a written summary of information on the IHiS project risks that she said she had verbally communicated to the Executive Oversight Council (EOC) during meetings on September 24, 2015, and October 6, 2015. The Director and the related e-mail identified the following technical risks: Lack of testing. IHiS lacked an independent security assessment to verify that the system's security infrastructure was adequate. Limited system functionality. The system that was to provide user verification and IHiS role management services was not yet complete. Limited system functionality. The system that was to provide user verification and IHiS role management services was not yet complete. Changes in project management staff. Although HSWL staff had been managing the IHiS project since it was initiated in 2010, the Coast Guard's Command, Control, Communications, Computers and Information Technology (C4&IT) Directorate was directed to assume the oversight responsibilities for IHiS implementation in May 2015 due to concerns about the project's adherence to established governance processes raised by internal investigators looking into the potential Antideficiency Act violations. By August 2015, the key project management personnel that had overseen the project since 2010 had been removed. As a result of the changes in staff, one vendor noted that it was unclear as to who were stakeholders, responsible parties, and decision makers. According to the Director, these risk factors had demonstrated that the project was far from ready for deployment and that continuing IHiS could cause significant stewardship and reputational harm to the Coast Guard. As a result of the risks presented by the Director, the EOC members made the decision to cancel IHiS, and did not consider any other alternatives to its cancelation. The Coast Guard could not demonstrate that it effectively managed and oversaw the IHiS project prior to its discontinuance. Specifically, although the Coast Guard was to follow the SDLC Practice Manual to guide its management and oversight of the project, the agency could not provide complete evidence that it had addressed 15 of the 30 selected project management practices GAO selected for evaluation. In addition, project team members provided inconsistent explanations regarding whether or not documentation existed to demonstrate the actions taken to manage and oversee the IHiS project. Further, although the Coast Guard developed charters for various governance boards to provide project oversight and direction, the boards were not active and the Chief Information Officer (CIO) was not included as a member of the boards, further contributing to a lack of key governance mechanisms for IHiS. The Coast Guard is managing its health records using a predominately paper process. After canceling the IHiS project in October 2015, the agency could not return to managing health records using its legacy electronic capabilities because the PGUI was decommissioned in 2015 and the Coast Guard's Composite Health Care System (CHCS) was decommissioned in January 2016. gao_GAO-18-303: Why GAO Did This Study The U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service (FWS) provides grants to a variety of recipients, including state agencies, tribal governments, and nongovernmental organizations. In fiscal year 2016, FWS awarded $1.5 billion in grants, which was about 50 percent of the agency's total $2.9 billion budget authority. WSFR awards grants to a variety of recipients, including state agencies, tribal governments, and nongovernmental organizations. GAO was asked to review the award and monitoring processes for WSFR grants. This report (1) describes the competitive grant programs that WSFR awards and monitors; (2) examines how WSFR awards grants under these programs and the extent to which this is consistent with relevant federal regulations; and (3) examines how WSFR monitors grants under these programs and the extent to which this is consistent with relevant federal regulations. GAO reviewed relevant federal laws and regulations, agency guidance, and agency policies and guidance. GAO also interviewed WSFR officials and grant applicants. What GAO Found The Wildlife and Sport Fish Restoration (WSFR) awards and monitors five competitive grant programs, according to agency documents and officials GAO interviewed. These five grant programs are (1) the Boating Infrastructure Tier 2 Grant Program, (2) the Clean Vessel Act Grant Program, (3) the Competitive State Wildlife Grant Program, (4) the Multistate Conservation Grant Program, and (5) the National Coastal Wetlands Conservation Grant Program. While these grant programs support different types of projects, they generally are funded from the Sport Fish Restoration and Boating Trust Fund, and most require non-federal matching funds from the grant recipient based on statute. The exceptions to this are the Multistate Conservation Grant Program, which also receives funds from the Wildlife Restoration Account and does not require matching funds, and the Competitive State Wildlife Grant Program, which receives funding from annual appropriations. The award process WSFR uses for the five competitive grant programs generally involves announcing the grant opportunity and reviewing applications to make award decisions, and in some cases federal agencies or third parties are involved in these activities. The award process used for the five competitive WSFR grant programs is generally consistent with federal grant regulations in the Office of Management and Budget's Uniform Administrative Requirements, Cost Principles, and Audit Requirements for Federal Awards (Uniform Guidance). WSFR monitors its competitive grants primarily by reviewing annual financial and performance reports submitted by grant recipients, which is consistent with federal regulations. GAO found in its review of these reports for a sample of grant projects awarded funds in fiscal year 2015 that grant recipients generally submitted them on time, but that some performance reports were missing required information. WSFR staff review the financial reports to ensure they contain required information, such as an update on the progress of meeting the specified goals of a grant project. In addition, WSFR grant specialists review the performance reports to ensure they contain required information, such as an update on the progress of meeting the specified goals of a grant project. WSFR staff occasionally perform site visits to grant projects to verify grant activities described in the performance reports. In addition, GAO found in its review of the agency's monitoring process for selected grants awarded in fiscal year 2015 that WSFR required both financial and performance reports at least annually, as required by the Uniform Guidance. In addition, the number and due dates of these reports were specified in the letters provided to grant recipients when they were awarded the grant. These award letters also specified the amount of federal funding for the grant along with any required non-federal matching funds. GAO found in its review of the agency's monitoring process for selected grants awarded in fiscal year 2015 that WSFR required both financial and performance reports at least annually, as required by the Uniform Guidance. In addition, the majority of the reports GAO reviewed met the content requirements found in the Uniform Guidance and the FWS Service Manual. However, in GAO's review of the performance reports for six awarded grants, GAO found that the performance reports submitted for these grants did not include a comparison of actual accomplishments to the goals of the project, as required by the Uniform Guidance. Without a template or standardized method for performance reporting across competitive grant programs, WSFR grant recipients may continue to submit performance reports to WSFR that do not contain the information required by the Uniform Guidance and do not convey all the information needed for FWS to oversee its competitive grant programs. What GAO Recommends GAO recommends that WSFR develop a template or other standardized method to facilitate collection of all required information for grant performance reports. The Department of the Interior agreed with GAO's recommendation and described actions it plans to take.
gao_GAO-18-648: Why GAO Did This Study The Veterans First program, established in 2006, provides contracting preferences to small businesses that are owned and controlled by veterans. The Supreme Court ruled in 2016 that VA must restrict competition to SD/VOSBs if: 1) the contracting officer reasonably expects that at least two such businesses will submit offers and that award can be made at a fair and reasonable price that offers the best value to the government; and 2) the award can be made at a fair and reasonable price that offers the best value to the government. GAO was asked to examine changes to how VA implements the Veterans First program as a result of the Supreme Court's decision. This report examines (1) how VA procurement obligations to veteran-owned small businesses changed in the period from fiscal years 2014 through 2017; (2) what actions VA has taken to update Veterans First policies and regulations and provide training following the Supreme Court's decision; (3) what challenges, if any, VA is encountering in applying Veterans First policies; and (4) the extent to which VA has mechanisms in place to monitor compliance with subcontracting limitations by veteran-owned small businesses. GAO analyzed VA's policies and regulations, guidance, and training materials related to the program, and interviewed VA contracting officers and contracting officers' representatives. What GAO Found The Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) has consistently set aside a much greater percentage of construction contracts and orders for service-disabled veteran-owned small businesses (SD/VOSB) than for other types of goods and services. The number of SD/VOSBs certified by VA also increased, as did the number of those firms that received contract awards. VA's 2016 Veterans First policy requires contracting officers to use the Vendor Information Pages (VIP) as the first step in market research to identify SD/VOSBs capable of performing the work. However, over three-quarters of the 35 contract files GAO reviewed did not contain such documentation. Such documentation, combined with support for overall market research efforts, provides VA with assurance that contracting officers have performed this search as part of the basis for their Rule of Two decision. Contracting officers also expressed confusion about how to determine whether the prices offered by SD/VOSBs in response to a set-aside solicitation are fair and reasonable. VA contracting officers are generally required to make this determination for every contract award. However, GAO found that many of the contracting officers GAO interviewed were uncertain how to balance the Veterans First preference with the determination of fair and reasonable price when lower prices were available on the open market. Contracting officers also expressed confusion about how to determine whether the prices offered by SD/VOSBs in response to a set-aside solicitation are fair and reasonable. VA contracting officers are generally aware of subcontracting limitations, but they told GAO they do not have sufficient time or knowledge to conduct oversight. VA conducts some audits of compliance through a separate program. While the scale of that effort has been limited, these audits have identified a number of violations. VA, however, has not shared subcontracting limitation compliance risks or practices to improve monitoring efforts. By conducting a comprehensive assessment of fraud risk, VA would be better positioned to detect potential fraud related to subcontracting limitations for the Veterans First program. What GAO Recommends GAO recommends that VA take steps to ensure contracting officers adhere to the requirements for documenting the required Vendor Information Pages searches in contract files; assess whether training on the Veterans First policy should be designated as mandatory; and monitor subcontracting limitations. VA concurred with all of GAO's recommendations.
gao_GAO-18-610: Why GAO Did This Study The Great Lakes-Seaway system is a critical transportation link linking U.S. manufacturing, agricultural, and other industries in the nation's interior to the global economy. The system is managed by the Army Corps of Engineers (Army Corps) and the U.S. Seaway Corporation (U.S. Seaway Corporation). The Army Corps manages the Soo locks, which are critical to the system's ability to maintain the integrity of the Great Lakes' navigation infrastructure. The U.S. Seaway Corporation manages the St. Lawrence Seaway, which is primarily used by Canadian and foreign vessels. The U.S. Seaway Corporation manages the St. Lawrence Seaway, which is primarily used by Canadian and foreign vessels. GAO was asked to review the Great Lakes-Seaway system. This report examines (1) how Great Lakes-Seaway shipping trends have changed since 1980 and what factors have shaped recent trends, (2) selected stakeholders' perspectives on challenges to using the system, and (3) to what extent the agencies have made progress on lock infrastructure renewal efforts and how the agencies measure performance of these efforts. GAO analyzed Great Lakes-Seaway data from 1980 to 2016 and interviewed 24 stakeholders representing a range of traditional and emerging system users and experts. What GAO Found The amount of cargo transported annually on the Great Lakes-Seaway—specifically for U.S. Great Lakes domestic and Seaway cargo—has generally declined since 1980. The Great Lakes U.S. domestic “laker” cargo traffic declined from about 115 million tons in 1980 to about 78 million tons in 2016. The trend includes many noticeable year-to-year changes over this time period, which may be in response to broader economic factors, such as global economic factors. Meanwhile, cargo traffic on the St. Lawrence Seaway, which is primarily used by Canadian and foreign vessels, declined by 48 percent over the same time period, from about 74 million tons in 1980 to about 39 million tons in 2016. Stakeholders identified a range of challenges to using the Great Lakes-Seaway, including challenges to traditional system use, such as transport of bulk commodities such as iron ore, and challenges to emerging system uses, such as the cruise industry and container market. The U.S. Seaway Corporation has not fully assessed the extent to which the challenges pose risks to the use of the Great Lakes-Seaway. The U.S. Seaway Corporation has taken steps to improve the condition of lock infrastructure, but it has not fully assessed the risks to the system's use. The U.S. Seaway Corporation has taken steps to address challenges, such as hiring a full-time employee to advance the Corporation's trade and economic development activities in the Great Lakes region. However, the Corporation has not fully assessed the extent to which the challenges pose risks to the system's use. The U.S. Seaway Corporation and the Army Corps have made progress on asset renewal efforts, but the Army Corps lacks a specific operational goal or measures for the Soo locks. The U.S. Seaway Corporation has a lock performance goal and measure that officials use to monitor its asset renewal efforts, in accordance with government internal control standards, but the Army Corps does not have such a goal specific to the Soo locks. Standards for Internal Control in the Federal Government states that agencies should define objectives clearly and in measurable terms so that performance toward achieving those objectives can be assessed. Similarly, Leading Practices in Capital Decision-Making states that organizational goals should be integrated into the capital decision-making process and that agencies should use performance measures to evaluate results of capital projects to determine if goals have been met. Without goals and associated measures for the Soo locks, the Army Corps is not able to demonstrate whether the substantial investments made so far and planned in the future will improve the Soo locks' performance and by extension, the reliability of the Great Lakes navigation infrastructure. What GAO Recommends GAO recommends that the Administrator of the U.S. Seaway Corporation establish a process to identify, analyze, and monitor risks to the system's use to inform future actions to address those risks. The Departments of Transportation and Defense concurred with GAO's recommendations.
gao_GAO-18-57: Why GAO Did This Study The Commercial Space Launch Act provides federal indemnification for third-party damages that result from a commercial launch or reentry. The act requires FAA to evaluate its MPL methodology incorporating three requirements, but the agency's report did not fully address these requirements. GAO was asked to review FAA's MPL methodology. This report examines the extent to which FAA has (1) addressed the act's mandated requirements and (2) revised its MPL methodology since GAO's 2012 report. GAO reviewed FAA's MPL methodology and interviewed agency officials. GAO also reviewed FAA's MPL methodology and interviewed agency officials. What GAO Found The Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) did not fully address the Commercial Space Launch Act's (CSLCA) mandated requirements for evaluating its MPL methodology. CSLCA required FAA to evaluate its MPL methodology incorporating three requirements, but the agency's report did not fully address these requirements. First, the act required FAA to ensure a balance of risk between launch companies and the federal government. However, agency officials told GAO that they did not re-evaluate the probability thresholds—which are used to divide the risk of loss between launch companies and the federal government—as part of evaluating its MPL methodology when implementing the risk profile method due to resource constraints. Second, the act required FAA to consider the cost impact of implementing an updated MPL methodology, but the agency did not evaluate the impact of implementing its revised methodology on the direct costs to launch companies (insurance premiums) and to the federal government (indemnification liability). Third, the act required FAA to consult with the commercial space sector and insurance providers in evaluating its MPL, but they did not consult such parties in response to the act. Without fully addressing CSLCA's mandated requirements, FAA cannot ensure that the federal government is not exposed to greater liability costs than intended or that launch companies are not required to purchase more insurance coverage than necessary. FAA has taken steps designed to improve two of three elements of its MPL methodology, including revising its methodology for estimating the number of potential casualties for a given launch and changing the factor it uses to derive estimated property damage from estimated casualties. However, the agency has not updated the third element, the amount it uses for the cost of an individual casualty, leaving a previously identified weakness unaddressed. In March 2017, GAO reported that FAA had taken steps to address weaknesses in two of these three areas. Specifically, FAA revised its methodology for estimating the number of potential casualties for a given launch and changed the factor it uses to derive estimated property damage from estimated casualties. However, the agency has not updated the third element, the amount it uses for the cost of an individual casualty, leaving a previously identified weakness unaddressed. In March 2017, GAO also reported that there are instances where deriving estimated property damage from estimated casualty costs is inappropriate. As of November 2017, FAA does not have guidance to identify such instances or to guide decisions on which tools to use in developing the MPL estimate. What GAO Recommends GAO recommends that FAA (1) reevaluate the probability thresholds, (2) evaluate the cost impact of implementing its revised MPL methodology, (3) consult with the commercial space sector and insurance providers in evaluating its MPL, and (4) update the cost-of-casualty amount. FAA concurred with GAO's recommendations.
gao_GAO-18-701T: Why GAO Did This Study The Department of Homeland Security's (DHS) Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) has a long-standing interest in removing foreign nationals from the United States. In fiscal year 2013, the ATD program, which aims to remove foreign nationals from the United States who are awaiting final decisions on their immigration proceedings, was the largest program in the federal government. In fiscal year 2013, ICE reported that the ATD program had a total of 73,495 removals of foreign nationals. This testimony discusses (1) the extent to which the ATD program has addressed GAO's prior recommendations and (2) the extent to which ICE established performance measures to assess the ATD program's effectiveness. This statement is based on GAO's prior reports issued from June 2005 through June 2017 and selected updates conducted in February 2018. GAO reviewed relevant documents and interviewed DHS officials, experts, and stakeholders. What GAO Found GAO reported in June 2017 that the number of open cases before the court during a single fiscal year grew 44 percent from fiscal years 2006 through 2015 due to an increase in the case backlog, while case receipts remained steady and the immigration courts completed fewer cases. GAO also reported in June 2017 that EOIR's case backlog more than doubled from fiscal years 2006 through 2015 due to an increase in the case backlog, while case receipts remained steady and the immigration courts completed fewer cases. GAO also reported in June 2017 that EOIR has faced long-standing management and operational challenges. In particular, GAO identified challenges related to EOIR's workforce planning, hiring, and technology utilization, among other things. GAO recommended actions to improve EOIR's management in these areas. EOIR generally concurred and has initiated actions to address GAO's recommendations. However, EOIR needs to take additional steps to fully implement GAO's recommendations to help strengthen the agency's management and reduce the case backlog. In November 2014, GAO reported that the ATD program increased and costs less than detention. For example, the average daily cost of the ATD program was $10.55 in fiscal year 2013, while the average daily cost of detention was $158. While GAO's analyses showed that the ATD program was significantly less than the average daily cost of detention, the length of immigration proceedings affected the cost-effectiveness of the ATD program to varying extents under different scenarios. For example, GAO found that the ATD program would have surpassed the cost of detention after a foreign national was in the program for 1,229 days in fiscal year 2013—significantly longer than the average length of time foreign nationals spent in the ATD program in that year (383 days). GAO also reported in November 2014 that ICE established two program performance measures to assess the ATD program's effectiveness in (1) ensuring foreign national compliance with court appearance requirements and (2) ensuring removals from the United States, but limitations in data collection hindered ICE's ability to assess overall program performance. For example, ICE did not collect court compliance data for foreign nationals in the ATD program that ICE was responsible for managing—which accounted for 39 percent of the overall ATD program in fiscal year 2013. As a result, GAO recommended that ICE collect and report data on all available data on the majority of foreign nationals in both components of the ATD program. ICE agreed with GAO's recommendation.
gao_GAO-18-487: Why GAO Did This Study CBP is responsible for securing the U.S. border between ports of entry and responding to threats to the United States in the air and maritime environments at and beyond the border. CBP has taken steps to improve its recruitment, hiring, and retention of law enforcement officers, including increasing the number of applications it receives for these positions and reducing the amount of time it takes to hire applicants. GAO was asked to review CBP's hiring process. This report examines (1) the extent to which CBP has enhanced its recruitment efforts and applications for law enforcement officer positions and (2) the extent to which CBP has taken steps to retain qualified law enforcement personnel. GAO reviewed CBP's hiring process and recruitment budgets, interviewed CBP officials, and analyzed CBP data on attrition and retention. GAO also reviewed CBP data on the number of Border Patrol agent and CBP officer positions and interviewed CBP officials. What GAO Found The Department of Homeland Security's (DHS) U.S. Customs and Border Protection (CBP) has increased its emphasis on recruitment and increased the number of recruitment events it has participated in since fiscal year 2015. Specifically, CBP more than tripled the total number of recruitment events it participated in, from 905 events in fiscal year 2015 to roughly 3,000 in both fiscal years 2016 and 2017. CBP has also increased its use of recruitment incentives, such as retention and relocation incentives, to help staff hard-to-fill locations. CBP officials stated that recruitment incentives have been effective in filling staffing shortages at hard-to-fill locations. CBP has also increased its use of recruitment incentives, although use by components varied. CBP has taken steps to improve its hiring process for law enforcement officers, but the process remains lengthy. CBP has made efforts to improve its hiring process by revising certain aspects of the process and piloting two key hiring initiatives—Hiring Hub events and the Applicant Care program. According to CBP officials, these efforts have collectively resulted in the decreased time-to-hire and increased overall applicant pass rates for all three components. In addition, CBP's contract with Accenture Federal Services, LLC, is intended to enhance CBP's ability to achieve its primary goal—hiring law enforcement officers to meet target staffing levels—by augmenting CBP's current hiring infrastructure and pursuing new and innovative hiring initiatives. CBP has enhanced its retention efforts, but does not have a systematic process for capturing and analyzing information on departing law enforcement officers. CBP officials across all three operational components confirmed that they do not systematically conduct formal exit interviews to collect data on departing employees. CBP officials across all three components told GAO that departing law enforcement officers receive the DHS exit survey and therefore have the option to provide these data. However, CBP officials told GAO that this information was of limited value due to low response rates. Taking steps to ensure that the agency's operational components are systematically capturing and analyzing complete and accurate information on all departing law enforcement officers—including the factors that influenced their decision to separate—would better position CBP to understand its retention challenges and take appropriate action to address them. What GAO Recommends GAO recommends that CBP systematically collect and analyze data on departing law enforcement officers and use this information to inform retention efforts. DHS concurred with GAO's recommendation.
gao_GAO-18-163: Why GAO Did This Study The federal government provides about $3.5 billion in federal student aid annually to about 1.4 million borrowers. The CDR is intended to hold schools accountable for borrowers who default on their student loans during the first 3 years of repayment. The CDR is also intended to hold schools accountable for borrowers who have defaulted on their loans during the first 3 years of repayment. GAO was asked to review the extent to which schools and their default management consultants use to manage their CDRs. This report examines (1) how schools work with borrowers to manage their CDRs, and how these strategies affect borrowers and schools' accountability for defaults; and (2) the extent to which Education oversees the strategies schools and their default management consultants use to manage schools' CDRs and informs the public about its efforts to hold schools accountable. GAO analyzed data from Education for the most recent CDR cohorts for a population of over 4,000 schools, reviewed documentation from default management consultants, and interviewed Education officials and student loan experts. What GAO Found Some schools' default management consultants encourage borrowers to postpone loan payments through forbearance, even when better borrower options may be available. Some consultants have an incentive to encourage forbearance in particular as a strategy to prevent borrowers from defaulting within the 3-year cohort calculation. This is because forbearance keeps borrowers current on their loans, and borrowers would not go into default until they had made no payments for an additional 360 days after the forbearance period ended. Moreover, including borrowers who spend 18 months or more in forbearance in the CDR calculation reduces the CDR's ability to hold schools accountable for high default rates since long periods of forbearance appear to delay—not prevent—default for some borrowers. Absent a statutory change, schools and their consultants seeking to keep CDRs below allowable thresholds will continue to have an incentive to promote forbearance over other repayment and postponement options. The Department of Education (Education) plays an important role in overseeing schools and their default management consultants to ensure that they are held accountable and student loan borrowers are protected. However, because Education asserts that it lacks explicit statutory authority to establish requirements regarding the information that schools and consultants provide to borrowers after they leave school, Education does not hold them accountable for providing accurate and complete information about repayment and postponement options. In addition, public information on CDR sanctions is important for assessing the usefulness of the CDR to hold schools accountable. Yet, Education's practice of reporting the number of schools potentially subject to sanction without reporting the number of schools ultimately sanctioned following the appeals process limits transparency about the CDR's usefulness for Congress and the public. What GAO Recommends GAO recommends that Congress consider strengthening schools' accountability for student loan defaults by revising the CDR calculation to account for the effect of borrowers spending long periods of time in forbearance during the 3-year CDR period, specifying additional accountability measures to complement the CDR, or replacing the CDR with a different accountability measure. Education agreed with GAO's draft report and disagreed with the draft report's recommendation. GAO continues to believe that Education should require that schools and consultants provide borrowers with accurate and complete information about repayment and postponement options after they leave school.
gao_GAO-18-52: Why GAO Did This Study FEHBP is a federal-state health insurance program that provides health insurance coverage to about 8 million FEHBP enrollees. The program is administered by OPM, which is responsible for negotiating health benefits and premiums with carriers. GAO was asked to review the program. This report examines (1) the number of plan offerings available to FEHBP enrollees and the extent to which these offerings have changed over time, (2) the extent to which FEHBP market shares have changed over time, and (3) the extent to which stakeholders have expressed their views about the potential effects of expanding OPM's contracting authority. GAO analyzed FEHBP enrollment data from 2000 through 2015, reviewed relevant studies, and interviewed OPM officials and 10 stakeholders selected based on a variety of factors, including enrollment, premiums, and market shares. GAO also interviewed officials from OPM and FEHBP carriers. What GAO Found The number of plan offerings available to FEHBP enrollees generally increased from 2007 through 2015. In 99 percent of counties nationwide, enrollees had more plan offerings in 2015 than they had in 2007. The median number of plan offerings available in a county increased from 19 in 2007 to 24 in 2015. Most of these offerings were the nationwide fee-for-service (FFS) plans that are available in all counties. There were 17 such plan offerings in 2007 and 19 in 2015. The remaining plan offerings were health maintenance organization (HMO) plans that were available in more limited areas. Despite increases in the availability of the median number of HMO plan offerings in a county, there was wide variation in the number of HMO offerings available to enrollees in a given county. For example, while FFS plan offerings were available nationwide, in some counties enrollees had no HMO plan offerings. Since 2007, however, the number of counties without any HMO plan offerings declined from 18 percent to less than 2 percent in 2015. Most counties had a couple of HMO plan offerings, and some counties had at least 10 HMO offerings. The combined market share for the three largest FEHBP carriers in a state was generally similar to the large group market and higher than Medicare Advantage. The combined market share for the three largest FEHBP carriers in a state was generally similar to the large group market and higher than Medicare Advantage. Stakeholder opinions and cost estimates do not offer clear consensus about the potential effects of expanding the Office of Personnel Management's (OPM) contracting authority. Stakeholders GAO interviewed generally supported expanding OPM's contracting authority to allow it to contract with a greater variety of health plan types than are currently offered in the Federal Employees Health Benefits Program (FEHBP). However, the two stakeholders that offer nationwide FFS plans and 1 stakeholder that represents federal employees opposed it. Most of the concerns expressed by these 3 stakeholders were related specifically to the potential effects of adding regional PPO plans to FEHBP. For example, 5 of these 6 stakeholders said there could be instability and higher premiums in FEHBP if new regional PPO plans were able to "cherry pick" low-cost areas in which to participate. Additionally, 6 of the 10 stakeholders GAO interviewed and who commented on OPM's contracting authority said that adding regional PPO plans to FEHBP would have positive effects. For example, 1 of these stakeholders that offers HMO plans and referred to FEHBP's plan type labels as antiquated noted that this would enable them to promote their existing FEHBP products—currently categorized as HMO plans—more appropriately as regional PPO plans. Stakeholders GAO interviewed and who commented on OPM's contracting authority, however, said that adding regional PPO plans to FEHBP would have negative effects. For example, 5 of these 6 stakeholders said there could be instability and higher premiums in FEHBP if new regional PPO plans were able to "cherry pick" low-cost areas in which to participate. What GAO Recommends GAO is not making any recommendations in this report.
gao_GAO-18-254: Why GAO Did This Study Fintech firms—such as mobile wallets and financial account aggregators—offer financial products and services to consumers through the Internet or via mobile devices. Fintech firms can provide consumers with various benefits, such as greater convenience and lower costs, but may also pose risks to consumers. GAO was asked to review the regulatory environment for fintech. This report examines (1) the benefits and risks of fintech activities and (2) the extent to which these activities are subject to federal oversight. GAO reviewed relevant literature and regulatory documents, and interviewed federal and state regulators, market participants, and other stakeholders. GAO also reviewed relevant federal laws and regulations. What GAO Found Fintech products in payments, lending, wealth management, and distributed ledger technology can provide consumers and the broader financial system with various benefits but may also pose risks similar to those of traditional products. Consumer benefits include greater convenience; lower cost; increased financial inclusion; faster services; and improved security. However, consumers face the risk of unauthorized transactions regardless of whether they use a traditional or fintech firm to make payments. Fintech products also pose risks to consumers, including fraud, discrimination, and unsuitable advice. For example, consumers may face the risk of financial loss due to data breaches regardless of whether they use a traditional or fintech firm. Fintech firms are subject to federal oversight of their compliance with applicable consumer or other laws. Fintech firms that offer investment advice typically register with and are subject to examinations by federal securities regulators. Some fintech firms providing payments or loans that have partnered with federally regulated banks or credit unions may receive indirect oversight from federal financial regulators as part of their efforts to ensure that their regulated entities are adequately managing the risks of these arrangements. Nonpartnered fintech firms would not typically be subject to routine examinations by a federal financial regulator but would instead be subject to state regulatory oversight and enforcement. While regulatory oversight is fragmented across multiple regulators at the federal level, GAO found that indications of fintech firms causing widespread harm were limited as they were subject to fewer complaints than large financial institutions. The complexity of the U.S. financial regulatory system can complicate fintech firms' ability to identify the laws with which they must comply and clarify the regulatory status of their activities. For example, understanding the laws and regulations that apply to fintech firms was not easy because existing regulations were sometimes developed before the type of product or service they are now offering existed. In addition, the cost of researching applicable laws and regulations can be particularly significant for fintech firms that begin as technology start-ups with small staffs and limited venture capital funding. Also, federal agencies could improve collaboration and clarify issues related to financial account aggregation by making sure that interagency efforts dedicated to fintech include all relevant participants and incorporate other leading practices. In addition, because banks are liable for risks posed by third parties, fintech firms may face delays in entering into partnerships with banks. gao_GAO-18-116: Why GAO Did This Study The Kissell Amendment, enacted in 2009, requires DHS to purchase uniforms made in the United States. The amendment also requires DHS to apply the Kissell Amendment in a manner consistent with U.S. obligations under international agreements. The amendment also requires GAO to review DHS's implementation and compliance with the Kissell Amendment. This report examines the extent to which (1) DHS has incorporated the Kissell Amendment into its procurement policies and procedures and (2) the Kissell Amendment affects DHS's procurement of textiles. GAO reviewed relevant laws and policies, DHS and component-level contracts, and ordering data for the largest textile contract since the effective date of the Kissell Amendment. GAO also interviewed DHS and U.S. textile and apparel industry officials. What GAO Found The Department of Homeland Security (DHS) updated its procurement regulations to incorporate the Kissell Amendment restriction on the procurement of textiles from foreign sources. Since then, DHS inserted language incorporating the restriction into the 11 uniform and body armor contracts GAO reviewed. The HSAR establishes standardized DHS policies for all procurement activities within the department; according to DHS officials, all DHS components are to follow these policies. Pursuant to the Kissell Amendment, the restriction on the procurement of textiles became effective for DHS on August 16, 2009. One day later, DHS published an interim rule with a request for comments from the public that amended relevant Homeland Security Acquisition Regulation sections to reflect the statutory change limiting the procurement of products containing textiles from sources outside the United States (i.e., the Kissell Amendment). On June 9, 2010, after receiving comments from the public, DHS adopted the amendments issued under the interim rule as final and without change. The amended sections detail the restriction on procurements of foreign textiles. They also provide a list of the types of textile items included in the restriction (i.e., yarn, wool, cotton), the exceptions noted in the Kissell Amendment, and provide detail on the specific application of trade agreements. DHS employs multiple procedures, according to officials, in an effort to ensure that the Kissell Amendment is properly applied, including (1) a standardized procurement contract review process; (2) a requirement for all DHS components to use established department-wide contracts; (3) verification procedures to ensure the stated country of origin is correct; and (4) trainings on foreign procurement restrictions. The Kissell Amendment affects DHS textile purchases in a limited manner due to multiple factors. For most DHS components, these factors limit the effect of the Kissell Amendment restriction to certain foreign textile procurements directly related to U.S. national security interests that fall between $150,000 and $191,000. Specifically, from October 2009 to June 2017, only 14 DHS-awarded textile contracts, excluding the Transportation Security Administration (TSA), fell within this range, according to FPDS-NG data. TSA textile procurements, unlike most DHS components, are excluded from the coverage of most U.S. international agreements. Therefore, the Kissell Amendment restricts TSA's procurement of certain foreign textiles above $150,000 from all but three foreign countries. According to DHS officials, the current contracts to which the Kissell Amendment applies are department-wide contracts for uniforms and body armor. As of June 2017, under the current uniforms contract, 58 percent of the value of ordered uniform items by DHS came from foreign sources. In addition, DHS officials stated that the current body armor contracts source all textile items from the United States. What GAO Recommends GAO is not making recommendations in this report.
gao_GAO-18-150: Why GAO Did This Study The MTW demonstration is a multiyear, multibillion-dollar demonstration to identify successful approaches to public housing that can be applied nationwide. The demonstration is on the brink of significant expansion, but HUD does not yet have the people, data, and processes in place to effectively oversee agency participants and assess the demonstration's performance and effects on tenants. GAO was asked to review HUD's oversight of the demonstration. This report examines (1) HUD's efforts to improve oversight of the demonstration and (2) the extent to which HUD has a framework for monitoring the demonstration's effect on tenants. GAO reviewed HUD documents and interviewed HUD officials and MTW agencies. GAO also reviewed HUD's guidance and data on the demonstration's effect on tenants. What GAO Found The Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD) has taken steps to improve oversight of the Moving to Work (MTW) demonstration, but has not conducted workforce planning for the demonstration expansion. HUD has taken some steps to improve MTW agencies' annual reporting and its process for monitoring compliance with requirements of the demonstration. However, GAO found that HUD's oversight—review of annual reports and compliance assessments—has not been timely and HUD has not fully documented its process for assessing compliance, due to limited staffing and competing priorities. While the MTW Office added staff to assist with the oversight of the current 39 MTW agencies, HUD has not conducted workforce planning to address the resources needed for overseeing the 100 agencies to be added through the MTW demonstration expansion. Federal internal control standards state that management should design control activities, including management of human capital, to achieve objectives and respond to risks. Without strategic workforce planning that reflects the oversight strategy for the expanded MTW demonstration, identifies the critical skills and competencies needed, and includes strategies to address any gaps, HUD will not be able to reasonably ensure that it has the staffing resources necessary to oversee an expanded demonstration. GAO found significant differences between MTW agencies and comparable non-MTW agencies in key outcomes: MTW agencies had lower public housing occupancy rates, lower voucher unit utilization rates, and higher program expenses in 2009–2015 than comparable non-MTW agencies. MTW funding flexibilities may partly explain the differences, but limitations in HUD data (such as the inability to determine which funding source was used to fund which activity) make it difficult to more fully understand the differences. MTW agencies accumulated relatively large reserves of voucher funding, but HUD has performed limited oversight of reserves for these agencies. HUD does not have a framework—standard definitions for rent reform and self-sufficiency, clear guidance on reporting requirements, or analysis plans—for monitoring the effect of rent-reform, work-requirement, and time-limit policies on tenants. HUD's definition of rent reform is unclear, leading to agencies inconsistently categorizing some policies and not reporting required information for rent-reform activities. Federal internal control standards state that management should externally communicate the necessary quality information to achieve the entity's objectives. Without a more clear definition of rent reform and specific criteria or standards with which to classify activities as rent reform, HUD cannot collect consistent information that would allow for the evaluation of the effect of MTW rent-reform and occupancy policies on tenants. HUD's guidance on how agencies are to perform impact analyses, reevaluate activities, and establish hardship policies has not described the elements of the analysis, required submission of reevaluations, or described elements of hardship policies. Federal internal control standards state that management should externally communicate the necessary quality information to achieve the entity's objectives. Without a more clear definition of rent reform and specific criteria or standards with which to classify activities as rent reform, HUD cannot collect consistent information that would allow for the evaluation of the effect of MTW rent-reform and occupancy policies on tenants. What GAO Recommends GAO recommends that HUD complete workforce planning for the MTW demonstration, develop and implement a process to monitor MTW reserves, and clarify its definition of rent reform. HUD agreed with GAO's recommendations.
gao_GAO-19-171: Why GAO Did This Study Emergency communications are vital to first responders' ability to respond to emergencies and to ensure their safety. OEC supports and promotes the ability of public-safety officials to communicate in emergencies and work toward operable and interoperable emergency communications nationwide. In November 2018, legislation was signed into law that reorganized and renamed OEC. This report examines (1) OEC's and FEMA's collaborative efforts to develop and implement guidance for grantees using federal grants for interoperable emergency communications; (2) how OEC incorporates FirstNet's nationwide public-safety broadband network and other emerging technologies into its plans and offerings, and stakeholders' views regarding those efforts; and (3) the extent to which OEC has assessed its methods of communication. GAO reviewed relevant documents and interviewed OEC officials and stakeholders. GAO also surveyed all 54 statewide interoperability coordinators (SWIC) from 48 states, five territories, and the District of Columbia. What GAO Found The Office of Emergency Communications (OEC) and the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) have responsibilities for developing and implementing guidance for grantees using federal funds for interoperable emergency communications. Specifically, OEC and FEMA officials told GAO FEMA is responsible for administering the grants, and OEC coordinates emergency communications grant guidance annually through SAFECOM's Guidance on Emergency Communications Grants. GAO reviewed OEC's and FEMA's collaborative efforts related to grant guidance and found that their efforts generally follow GAO's previously identified leading practices for effective interagency collaboration. For example, OEC and FEMA officials said they collaborate with their grants offices to develop guidance and share information. OEC officials said the agencies have not implemented the monitoring procedures because the grants for the 2018 grant cycle were not yet awarded. Accordingly, GAO could not evaluate the effectiveness of the new procedures to monitor and assess grantee compliance, and without conducting such an evaluation, GAO could not determine whether OEC's and FEMA's efforts align with the key practice in this area. OEC incorporated FirstNet's network and other emerging technologies into its plans and offerings. For example, OEC officials said that they provide stakeholders with a wide range of products and services to help prepare for the adoption, integration, and use of broadband. However, OEC officials told GAO that FirstNet's network is only one of several emergency-communications technology options and that OEC should continue to provide information to public-safety stakeholders regarding other providers. OEC officials said that they maintain a neutral position for all technologies and vendors. Accordingly, OEC is not responsible for promoting any vendor solutions, including FirstNet's network, and there is no requirement for OEC to do so. Additionally, the majority of SWICs that GAO surveyed said that OEC sufficiently incorporates information regarding FirstNet's network into its guidance and offerings. For example, officials from 6 of 10 organizations that GAO interviewed said that OEC must strike a balance between FirstNet's network and other emerging technologies, and that OEC has successfully accomplished this task. In addition, the majority of SWICs that GAO surveyed reported that OEC has incorporated FirstNet's network, to a large or moderate extent, into its written guidance, technical assistance offerings, training opportunities, workshops, and grant guidance. However, fewer SWICs reported that OEC incorporated FirstNet's network, to a large or moderate extent, into its training opportunities (39 percent) and grant guidance (33 percent). Even following the implementation of FirstNet, public-safety stakeholders told GAO they expect OEC will play an important role in ensuring interoperable emergency communications, both regarding the FirstNet network and other technologies. OEC is required to conduct extensive nationwide outreach to support and promote interoperable emergency-communications capabilities by state, regional, local, and tribal governments and public-safety agencies in the event of natural disasters and acts of terrorism and other man-made disasters. According to federal standards for internal control, management should externally communicate the necessary quality information to achieve the entity's objectives. This includes communicating with external parties and using the appropriate methods of communication. The federal standards state that management should periodically assess the entity's methods of communication so that the entity has the appropriate tools to communicate quality information throughout and outside of the entity on a timely basis. What GAO Recommends GAO recommends that OEC assess its methods of communication to help ensure it has the appropriate tools and approaches to communicate quality information to public-safety stakeholders, and as appropriate, make adjustments to its communications strategy. DHS concurred with GAO's recommendation.
gao_GAO-18-287: Why GAO Did This Study RRB provides disability benefits to railroad workers who have physical or mental impairments that prevent them from performing their specific railroad job, even though they may be able to perform other kinds of work. RRB also conducts continuing disability reviews (CDR) to determine if beneficiaries continue to meet the disability requirements of the law. GAO was asked to review RRB's CDR program. This report examines (1) the extent to which RRB conducts CDR, (2) the number of CDR completed and the number of overpayments identified, and (3) the extent to which RRB oversees its CDR program. GAO reviewed RRB data and policies, interviewed RRB officials, and analyzed RRB data for fiscal years 2014-2016. What GAO Found The Railroad Retirement Board (RRB) completed 427 CDRs during fiscal years 2014-2016, an average of about 35,000, including both occupational and total and permanent (T&P) disability beneficiaries. Most of the reviews it completed were medical CDRs, but earnings CDRs identified most of the ineligible beneficiaries and overpayments. RRB completed 43 medical CDRs for beneficiaries, about 0.1 percent of disability beneficiaries, and 43 CDRs for earnings CDRs. RRB developed criteria for conducting additional medical CDRs to target cases at high risk for potential fraud, but these CDRs identified no ineligible beneficiaries in two years. Earnings CDRs identified the greatest number of ineligible beneficiaries and overpayments, but outdated earnings information limits their effectiveness. RRB completed 163 earnings CDRs during fiscal years 2014-2016, but the data RRB provided for these CDRs were incomplete. RRB officials acknowledged delays of a year or more in calculating overpayments for disability beneficiaries identified by CDRs, and that RRB lacks a standard time frame for doing so. RRB has no plans to establish a standard time frame for processing overpayments identified through CDRs. Identifying and calculating overpayments in a timely manner are important to RRB's long-term performance goal related to payment accuracy, as outlined in its strategic plan. RRB's oversight of its CDR program has focused on high-risk reviews rather than overall program data. RRB officials said they plan to track certain annual measures for high-risk CDRs, such as the number of cases referred to the Office of Inspector General for potential fraud, CDR outcomes (continuances, suspensions, and terminations), and any overpayments identified. GAO's findings and the Program Evaluation and Management Services' 2016 conclusions indicate that these high-risk CDRs have not been effective in identifying ineligible beneficiaries, or identifying potential fraud. By continuing to conduct high-risk CDRs, RRB may be expending resources that could be used for other purposes that are more effective in identifying ineligible beneficiaries. RRB does not routinely analyze program data for its CDR operations as a whole. The lack of routine data collection and analysis limits its ability to identify potential gaps in oversight and monitor program performance. What GAO Recommends GAO recommends that RRB develop a standard for the timely processing of disability program overpayments identified through CDRs, consider whether to reallocate resources used for high-risk CDRs to other CDR efforts that produce more effective outcomes, and routinely analyze CDR program data, such as the number of cases selected for review, the number of beneficiaries in each medical improvement category, outcomes, and the costs and benefits of conducting CDRs, to improve program oversight. RRB agreed with all three recommendations and noted that it has already taken initial steps to implement them.
