gao_GAO-18-421: Why GAO Did This Study SBA's 7(a) program guarantees loans to small businesses for working capital and other general business purposes. The 7(a) program is required to serve borrowers who cannot obtain conventional credit at reasonable terms. SBA relies on lenders with delegated authority to make credit elsewhere determinations. GAO was asked to review SBA's 7(a) program. This report examines (1) 7(a) lending to selected categories of small business borrowers from fiscal years 2007 through 2016; (2) how SBA monitors lenders' compliance with the credit elsewhere requirement; (3) the extent to which SBA evaluates trends in lender practices related to the credit elsewhere requirement; and (4) lenders' views on the criteria used to determine eligibility for 7(a) loans and other issues related to the 7(a) program. GAO analyzed SBA data on 7(a) loans and borrowers from fiscal years 2007 through 2016; reviewed SBA's lender reviews; and interviewed SBA officials and representatives from 11 lenders. What GAO Found From fiscal years 2007 through 2016, a majority of 7(a) loans went to small businesses that were new, partially or wholly owned by women, or located in a distressed area. The remaining 37 percent of 7(a) loan dollars went to businesses that were established, solely male-owned, and not located in economically distressed areas. SBA relies on on-site reviews as its primary mechanism for evaluating lenders' compliance with the credit elsewhere requirement. SBA's standard operating procedures state that lenders must substantiate that credit is not available elsewhere by (1) discussing the criteria that demonstrate an identifiable weakness in a borrower's credit and (2) including the specific reasons why the borrower does not meet the lender's conventional loan policy requirements. SBA's contractors and SBA staff who conduct on-site reviews are supposed to assess whether lenders have adequately documented the credit elsewhere criteria and provided specific reasons supporting the criteria in the credit memorandum. SBA's contractors said adequate documentation of the credit elsewhere determination in the credit memorandum would include not just which of the criteria a borrower met but also a discussion of the basis or justification for the decision. SBA's contractors also told GAO that they carefully review a lender's loan policies in preparation for on-site reviews and refer to a lender's policies throughout the reviews. Reviewers do not attempt to verify the evidence given in support of the credit elsewhere reason beyond the information provided in the credit memorandum. SBA's reviews in fiscal year 2016 identified a high rate of noncompliance with the credit elsewhere documentation requirement. The key factors underlying lenders' high rate of noncompliance with the credit elsewhere documentation requirement were lenders' lack of proper internal controls and procedures and lack of awareness of the credit elsewhere requirement. Federal internal control standards state that management should design control activities to achieve objectives and respond to risks, including appropriate documentation of transactions and internal control. Because SBA does not require reviewers to document their assessment of lenders' policies and practices for complying with the credit elsewhere documentation requirement, the agency does not have good information to help explain why so many lenders are not in compliance. This hinders SBA's ability to take informed and effective actions to improve lender compliance with the requirement and ensure that the 7(a) program is reaching its intended population. SBA does not routinely collect information on the criteria lenders use in their credit elsewhere justifications. SBA does not routinely collect information on the criteria lenders use in their credit elsewhere justifications. Federal internal control standards state that management should design control activities to achieve objectives and respond to risks, including appropriate documentation of transactions and internal control. SBA does not routinely collect or analyze information on the criteria lenders use in their credit elsewhere justifications to evaluate patterns in lender practices. SBA recently began collecting some information on lenders' use of the criteria, but this information is limited, and SBA does not analyze the information that it does collect to better understand lenders' practices. Without more robust information and analysis, SBA may be limited in its ability to understand how lenders are using the credit elsewhere criteria and whether 7(a) loans are reaching borrowers who cannot obtain credit from other sources at reasonable terms. What GAO Recommends GAO recommends that SBA (1) require reviewers to document their assessments of lenders' policies and practices for complying with the credit elsewhere documentation requirement; (2) analyze information on lenders' use of the credit elsewhere criteria obtained from its reviews to identify lenders that may be at greater risk of noncompliance and to inform its selection of lenders for further review for credit elsewhere compliance; and (3) analyze information on lenders' use of the credit elsewhere criteria obtained from its reviews to identify lenders that may be at greater risk of noncompliance and to inform its selection of lenders
gao_GAO-19-81: Why GAO Did This Study The United States has a long-standing interest in resolving international tax disputes. In the United States, the U.S. Competent Authority (USCA) is the agency responsible for resolving disputes over double taxation. USCA is responsible for resolving disputes over the adjustment of U.S. corporations' foreign income. GAO was asked to review the MAP process. This report examines (1) the extent to which USCA evaluates the management of MAP cases, and (2) the extent to which APMA tracks and analyzes data on MAP cases. GAO reviewed IRS documents and data on MAP cases, and interviewed IRS officials. GAO also analyzed a generalizable sample of MAP case files from a generalizable random sample of 84 cases. What GAO Found USCA provides information about the Advanced Pricing and Mutual Agreement Program (MAP) process through an IRS web page on competent authority assistance. However, the information on the website is highly technical and may not be easily understood by taxpayers seeking relief from double taxation. USCA officials said that they are engaged in some efforts that may improve the information they provide to taxpayers. USCA does not track key data or use existing data to assess the management of MAP cases. For example, USCA does not track the hours that analysts spend on cases and the milestones of cases. As a result, USCA does not have a full understanding of the efficiency of the MAP process, including ways to improve it. It also does not have processes to ensure the quality of the data it collects, therefore cannot ensure accurate performance measurement. APMA's inventory data-base includes data on both pending and resolved MAP cases that can help management monitor program operations and potentially identify areas to improve the management of MAP cases. However, APMA does not systematically analyze data to identify areas for improvement. For example, analysis of trends and comparisons of certain case characteristics—such as the country initiating the adjustment, the elapsed time on the case, whether an economist was assigned to the case, and the negotiated outcome—can help to identify how these characteristics may be related. According to APMA officials, they do not undertake this kind of data analysis because they use the data as needed to manage current resources and to achieve their primary goal of satisfying the Organization for Economic Co-operation and Development's (OECD) minimum standards. Analyzing trends in case characteristics could help to identify areas for improvement. APMA does not track the tax issue that was in dispute. Without tracking the tax issue in dispute, APMA is unable to analyze trends in tax issues which could be used to determine if there are systemic issues that could be solved through means such as changes in IRS regulations, treaty, or statute. Conducting similar reviews of this type of information could help APMA better match its resources in terms of experience with different types of tax issues within its country-focused teams. Conducting similar reviews across tax issues may help identify areas for increased scrutiny to ensure effective administration. Collecting key characteristics and conducting relevant analyses would help ensure effective internal control and could help improve USCA's management of MAP cases. What GAO Recommends GAO recommends that USCA provide an overview of the MAP process that is more accessible and transparent than the Revenue Procedure. USCA agreed with GAO's recommendations.
gao_GAO-18-222: Why GAO Did This Study The federal government has a long-standing interest in accelerating the delivery of highway and transit projects. gao_GAO-19-164: Why GAO Did This Study FEMA is responsible for providing disaster relief and emergency response assistance to the public. FEMA has identified 10 primary legacy IT systems that support its grants management activities. FEMA initiated GMM in 2015, in part, due to the agency's failed attempt to modernize its grants management environment. GAO was asked to review FEMA's grants management processes. This report examines the extent to which (1) FEMA is implementing leading practices for reengineering its grants management business processes and incorporating business needs into GMM requirements; (2) the program's estimated costs and schedule; and (3) FEMA is addressing key cybersecurity practices for GMM. GAO reviewed relevant documents and interviewed FEMA officials. GAO also reviewed relevant federal laws and DHS guidance. What GAO Found The Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) has implemented most leading practices for reengineering its grants management business processes and incorporating business needs into GMM requirements. For example, FEMA has taken steps to assess and document its business environment and performance goals, defined initial IT requirements for GMM, took recent actions to better track progress in delivering planned IT requirements, and incorporated input from end user stakeholders. However, the agency has not finalized plans or established time frames for implementing its organizational change management actions, plans and communicates system transition activities, and maintains clear traceability of IT requirements. Until FEMA finalizes plans and time frames for implementing its organizational change management actions, plans and communicates system transition activities, and maintains clear traceability of IT requirements, FEMA will be limited in its ability to provide streamlined grants management processes and effectively deliver a modernized IT system to meet the needs of its large range of users. GMM's initial cost estimate was reliable, but key assumptions about the program changed soon after DHS approved the estimate in May 2017. Thus, the initial cost estimate no longer reflects the current approach for the program. The forthcoming updated cost schedule is expected to better reflect the current approach. However, the program's unreliable schedule to fully deliver GMM by September 2020 is aggressive and unrealistic. The delays the program has experienced to date further compound GMM's schedule issues. Without a robust schedule that has been informed by a realistic assessment of GMM's development activities, leadership will be limited in its ability to make informed decisions on what additional increases in cost or reductions in scope might be needed to achieve their goals. FEMA's implementation of cybersecurity practices for GMM in the areas of system categorization, selection and implementation, and monitoring will help the program. However, GMM lacked essential details for evaluating security controls, did not approve the security assessment plan before proceeding with the security assessment, did not follow DHS's guidance to develop corrective action plans for all security vulnerabilities, and did not fully test all security controls. As a result, the GMM engineering and test environment remains at an increased risk of exploitations. What GAO Recommends GAO recommends that FEMA finalizes its organizational change management plan and time frames for implementing change management actions, and that FEMA update the GMM program schedule to address leading practices for a reliable schedule. DHS concurred with all eight recommendations and provided estimated completion dates for implementing each.
gao_GAO-18-565: Why GAO Did This Study The Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (PPACA) requires the exchanges to provide health insurance coverage to uninsured and underinsured consumers. The exchanges are funded by the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) and are designed to provide consumers with access to health insurance coverage through the exchanges. HHS also provides financial assistance to navigator organizations that provide in-person consumer enrollment assistance. GAO was asked to review the 2018 open enrollment period. This report examines (1) the extent to which enrollment through the exchanges changed from 2017 to 2018 and the factors that affected enrollment, and (2) the extent to which HHS allocated navigator funding for the 2018 open enrollment period. GAO reviewed relevant federal laws and regulations, and interviewed HHS officials and 23 stakeholders, including navigator organizations, state insurance departments, and professional trade associations. What GAO Found Enrollment through the health insurance exchanges was 5 percent lower in 2018 than 2017—the most recent year for which data were available. About 8.7 million consumers enrolled in health insurance exchanges during the open enrollment period for 2018 coverage, 5 percent less than the 9.2 million who enrolled for 2017. This decline continues a trend from 2016, when a peak of 9.6 million consumers enrolled in such plans. Since that peak, enrollment has decreased by 9 percent. Stakeholders GAO interviewed reported that plan affordability likely played a major role in 2018 exchange enrollment—both attracting and detracting from enrollment—and enrollees' plan selection. In 2018, premiums across all health insurance plans increased an average of 30 percent—more than expected given overall health cost trends. As a result of these premium increases, plans were less affordable in 2018 compared to 2017 for exchange consumers without advance premium tax credits (15 percent in 2018). One driver of these premium increases was the elimination of federal cost-sharing reduction payments to issuers in late 2017, which resulted in larger premium increases for silver tier plans (the most popular healthcare.gov metal tier). Stakeholders GAO interviewed reported that a variety of other factors likely affected 2018 exchange enrollment, but opinions on the impact of each factor were mixed. For example, most stakeholders GAO interviewed, including all 4 navigator organizations and 3 professional trade organizations, reported that consumer confusion about PPACA and its status likely played a major role in detracting from 2018 enrollment. HHS reduced its consumer outreach—including paid advertising and navigator funding—for the 2018 open enrollment period. HHS allocated the navigator funding using a narrower approach and problematic data, including consumer application data that it acknowledged were unreliable and navigator organization-reported goal data that were based on an unclear description of the goal, and which HHS and navigator organizations likely interpreted differently. HHS allocated the navigator funding using a narrower approach and problematic data, including consumer application data that it acknowledged were unreliable and navigator organization-reported goal data that were based on an unclear description of the goal, and which HHS and navigator organizations likely interpreted differently. Federal internal control standards state that management should use quality information to achieve the agency's objectives, such as by using relevant, reliable data for decision-making. Without reliable performance data and accurate goals, HHS will be unable to measure the effectiveness of the navigator program and take informed action as necessary. Further, because HHS calculated awards using problematic data, navigator organizations may have received awards that did not accurately reflect their performance in enrolling individuals in exchange plans. Without reliable performance data and accurate goals, HHS will be unable to measure the effectiveness of the navigator program and take informed action as necessary. What GAO Recommends GAO recommends that HHS (1) ensure that the approach and data it uses for determining navigator award amounts accurately and appropriately reflect navigator organization performance, (2) establish numeric enrollment targets for the 2018 open enrollment period, and (3) assess other aspects of the consumer experience, such as those it previously identified as key, to ensure it has quality information to achieve its goal. HHS concurred with two of GAO's recommendations.
gao_GAO-18-637: Why GAO Did This Study The LIHTC program provides tax credits to developers of affordable housing projects. The Internal Revenue Service (IRS) administers the program and oversees allocating agencies. GAO was asked to review LIHTC development costs. This report examines (1) the costs of LIHTC projects completed in 2011–2015, (2) how allocating agencies manage and verify LIHTC development costs, and (3) the extent to which allocating agencies collect and maintain data related to LIHTC project costs. GAO analyzed LIHTC project costs from 12 allocating agencies, selected based on geographic location, number of units, and number of bedrooms. GAO also interviewed IRS and Treasury officials and industry stakeholders. What GAO Found The median per-unit cost of the LIHTC projects completed in GAO's sample in 2011–2015 was $204,000. The median per-unit cost of new construction projects was about $50,000 higher than for rehabilitation projects ($218,000 compared to $169,000). For new construction projects, the median per-unit cost was about $38,000 higher in urban areas than in nonurban areas (about $230,000 compared to $192,000). For rehabilitation projects, the median per-unit cost was about $72,000 higher in urban areas than in nonurban areas (about $196,000 compared to $124,000). The median per-unit cost of new construction projects was about $147,000 for new construction projects (about 67 percent of the total development cost) and $103,000 for rehabilitation projects (about 61 percent of the total development cost). Other funding sources, such as private loans or state and local programs, made up for differences between project costs and equity investments. GAO's analysis of the cost of LIHTC projects completed in 2011–2015 found that the median per-unit cost of new construction projects was about $204,000. The median per-unit cost of rehabilitation projects was about $226,000 in 2015 dollars. The median per-unit cost of new construction projects across the 12 selected allocating agencies ranged from a low of about $126,000 in Texas to a high of $326,000 in California. The median per-unit cost of rehabilitation projects was lower and varied less than those for new construction projects. The characteristics of each agency's LIHTC projects generally can be expected to reflect the real estate conditions, built environment, and populations of the areas they serve. Allocating agencies took steps to manage and verify LIHTC development costs, but IRS policies do not require detailed cost information. Allocating agencies used approaches that included cost and fee limits and cost-based scoring criteria to manage project-development costs. A few agencies adopted additional measures such as detailed contractor certifications at project completion to help guard against a risk of fraud involving misrepresentation of contractor costs, but LIHTC policies do not require these enhancements. Data limitations, including inconsistencies among allocating agencies in the collection, definition, and format of key variables, constrain analysis and oversight of LIHTC development costs. IRS does not specifically require allocating agencies to collect and report cost-related data that would facilitate programwide assessment of development costs. IRS officials said that doing so would be inconsistent with their authority and role, which is focused on taxpayer compliance rather than program evaluation. As a result, allocating agencies have flexibility in what cost-related data to collect, how to maintain these data, and how to define variables for purposes of program evaluation. GAO's tax expenditure evaluation guide suggests federal agencies assess (determine and define) what data are needed to evaluate tax expenditures. Without standardized, accessible data on LIHTC development costs, federal agencies and credit allocating agencies cannot rigorously assess the factors that drive costs, the reasonableness of costs, and the efficiency of LIHTCs in producing affordable housing. Currently, no standards exist for collecting and maintaining data related to LIHTC project costs. What GAO Recommends GAO recommends that IRS require general contractor cost certifications for LIHTC projects, and that IRS communicate to allocating agencies how to collect and review information on LIHTC syndication expenses, including upper-tier partnership expenses. IRS disagreed with GAO's recommendation to require cost certifications for LIHTC projects, but said it was not clear whether the recommendation would uncover and deter misrepresentation of contractor costs. GAO maintains that requiring general contractor cost certifications would help address this fraud risk by providing greater cost transparency to allocating agencies and auditors.
gao_GAO-18-44: Why GAO Did This Study The opioid epidemic has grown significantly in recent years, and the number of people who use opioids has increased. HHS has implemented five key efforts from 2015 through August 2017 that focus on expanding access to MAT for opioid use disorders. GAO was asked to review HHS's efforts to expand access to MAT for opioid use disorders. This report examines (1) HHS's efforts to expand access to MAT for opioid use disorders and (2) the extent to which HHS has established performance measures with targets and timeframes for its evaluation of its efforts. GAO reviewed relevant federal laws and regulations, HHS documents, and other documents; interviewed HHS officials and stakeholders; and analyzed HHS data on the number of prescriptions for MAT and the treatment capacity of practitioners who are authorized to prescribe buprenorphine for opioid use disorders. What GAO Found The Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) has implemented five key efforts from 2015 through August 2017 that focus on expanding access to medication-assisted treatment (MAT) for opioid use disorders. Four of these are grant programs, including programs focused on health centers or primary care practices in rural areas. HHS's fifth effort increases treatment capacity by expanding the waivers that practitioners may receive to prescribe buprenorphine. Specifically, the new regulation became effective August 8, 2016 increasing the number of patients that eligible practitioners can treat with buprenorphine outside of an opioid treatment program (OTP) (e.g., in an office-based setting). Previously, qualified practitioners could request approval to treat up to 30 patients at a time, and after 1 year the limit could increase to 100 patients at a time upon SAMHSA approval. The new regulation expanded access to MAT by allowing eligible practitioners who have had waivers to prescribe buprenorphine to 100 patients for at least 1 year to request approval to treat up to 275 patients thereafter. HHS officials told GAO that as of August 2017, the department is in the process of finalizing its approach for evaluating the implementation of its agencies' collective efforts to address the opioid epidemic that were undertaken as part of the HHS Opioid Initiative and will continue under the new administration's Opioid Strategy. HHS officials told GAO that the evaluation will focus initially on whether HHS's efforts have been implemented as intended, and officials expect the evaluation to also provide information on any challenges HHS has faced in implementing these efforts. HHS officials told GAO that in the future an evaluation may also focus on the effectiveness of these efforts, including the effectiveness of efforts to expand access to MAT. Doing so would be consistent with federal standards for internal control, which call for agencies to evaluate results. HHS has some of the information that could be used in a future evaluation of the effectiveness of its efforts to expand access to MAT. For example, HHS has identified three potential ways to measure access to MAT: the number of prescriptions for MAT medications, the treatment capacity of practitioners who are authorized to prescribe buprenorphine for opioid use disorders through a Drug Addiction Treatment Act of 2000 waiver, and the treatment capacity of OTPs certified to administer methadone and other medications. However, HHS has not adopted specific performance measures with targets specifying the magnitude of the increases HHS hopes to achieve through its efforts to expand access to MAT, and by when. For example, HHS has not established a long-term target specifying the percentage increase in the number of prescriptions for buprenorphine HHS would like to achieve, which would help to show whether efforts by HHS and others are resulting in sufficient progress in increasing prescriptions for this MAT medication. HHS has not chosen a specific method of measuring treatment capacity or established targets associated with it, which would help to show whether a sufficient number of providers are becoming available to evaluate and treat patients who may benefit from MAT. Without performance measures with targets and evaluation timeframes, HHS increases the risk that the evaluation will not be completed in a timely manner or that HHS will not know whether its MAT-related efforts are successful or whether new approaches are needed. The evaluation is particularly important, given the hundreds of millions of dollars HHS has invested in its MAT-related grant programs. What GAO Recommends GAO recommends that HHS establish performance measures with targets related to expanding access to MAT for opioid use disorders and establish timeframes in its evaluation approach that specify when its evaluation of efforts to expand access to MAT will be implemented and completed. HHS concurred with both recommendations.

gao_GAO-18-602: Why GAO Did This Study The U.S. Postal Service (USPS) provides retiree health benefits to about 500,000 postal retirees. The RHB Fund is the initial funding source for USPS's share of retiree health benefits. The fund is projected to be depleted in 12 years under the status quo. GAO was asked to review the financial outlook of the RHB Fund. This report examines (1) the financial outlook of the RHB Fund and (2) potential policy approaches to address the financial sustainability of postal retiree health benefits. GAO reviewed relevant laws, regulations, and reports; analyzed data on the number of companies offering retiree health benefits; and interviewed officials from OPM, USPS, and companies that have retained their retiree health benefits. What GAO Found The financial outlook for the Postal Service Retiree Health Benefits Fund (RHB Fund) is poor as USPS has missed approximately $38 billion in payments to the fund since fiscal year 2010, and the fund's balance is declining. Beginning in fiscal year 2017, the Office of Personnel Management (OPM) started drawing from the fund to pay USPS's share of premiums for postal retirees' health benefits. OPM's payments in that year exceeded the fund's income from interest, and OPM projects that, based on the status quo, future payments will continue to exceed the fund's income from interest. As long as USPS continues to miss its annual payments--which were nearly $4.3 billion in fiscal year 2017 and are $4.5 billion in fiscal year 2018--the fund is on track to be depleted in fiscal year 2030 based on OPM projections requested by GAO. GAO's analysis of past practices and USPS statements suggests that USPS will not be able to fill the financial gap once the RHB Fund is depleted. There is no certainty on what actions should be taken to address this problem. However, GAO has identified multiple approaches that could be used, individually or in combination, that Congress could consider to help address the financial shortfall in this area. All of these approaches have different potential effects, and it is up to Congress to consider the merits of the approaches and determine the most appropriate action to take. It would be preferable to take action when careful consideration is possible, rather than wait until lack of adequate funding could disrupt postal retiree health benefits. What GAO Recommends Congress should consider passing legislation to put postal retiree health benefits on a more sustainable financial footing. USPS concurred with GAO's matter for congressional consideration. However, USPS said GAO's discussion of potential policy approaches for postal retiree health benefits would benefit from additional context and balance. USPS also put forth additional information for three of the potential policy approaches highlighted in GAO's report.
gao_GAO-18-29: Why GAO Did This Study The federal government is required to grant security clearances to individuals who require access to classified information. The IRTPA, which was enacted in 2014, established the PAC and NBIB to improve the personnel security clearance process government-wide. GAO was asked to review the reform effort. This report examines (1) the status of reform efforts, (2) the extent to which executive branch agencies have met timeliness objectives for initial investigations and adjudications, and (3) the extent to which NBIB has taken steps to improve the background investigation process. GAO reviewed relevant documents and interviewed officials from the PAC, OPM, and DOD. What GAO Found Executive branch agencies have made progress in reforming the personnel security clearance process government-wide, but long-standing key initiatives remain incomplete. Executive branch agencies have issued guidance, updated strategic documents, and adjudicative guidelines to establish single, common adjudicative criteria for security clearances. However, implementing certain aspects of the 2012 Federal Investigative Standards, including changing the frequency of periodic reinvestigations for certain clearance holders and establishing a continuous evaluation program, remain incomplete. In addition, the issuance of a reciprocity policy remains incomplete. While the executive branch has taken steps toward establishing performance measures for the quality of government-wide personnel security clearance investigations, there is no milestone for their completion. Executive branch agencies have experienced challenges in meeting timeliness objectives for investigation and adjudication of initial personnel security clearances, and their reporting on timeliness has been limited. The number of executive branch agencies meeting established timeliness objectives for both initial secret and initial top secret clearances decreased from fiscal years 2012 through 2016. While the Office of Personnel Management (OPM) has taken steps to address timeliness challenges, it has not developed a government-wide approach to help agencies improve the timeliness of initial personnel security clearances. In addition, the executive branch's reporting on timeliness has been limited, which inhibits both transparency and oversight of the personnel security clearance process. The transition from the Federal Investigation Service (FIS) to the National Background Investigations Bureau (NBIB) has involved organizational changes intended to improve the background investigation process, but the bureau faces operational challenges in addressing the investigation backlog and associated workforce planning. NBIB's organizational changes include the creation of some new departments, and DOD is now responsible for designing, developing, and maintaining a new information technology (IT) system for the bureau, but must contend with risks posed by vulnerabilities in OPM's legacy IT systems, which NBIB still utilizes. As NBIB transitions, it has taken steps to improve its oversight of background investigation contracts and measure the completeness of background investigations; however, it faces operational challenges in developing a plan to reduce the size of the investigation backlog and in ensuring that its overall workforce is sized and structured to meet its mission. What GAO Recommends GAO recommends that the Director of National Intelligence, in his capacity as Security Executive Agent, develop, implement, and report to Congress on government-wide, results-oriented performance measures for the quality of background investigations. ODNI did not state whether it concurred with GAO's recommendations.
gao_GAO-19-226: Why GAO Did This Study Indian students attend public schools in both urban and rural areas. In school year 2015-16, approximately 505,000 Indian students attended public schools, representing 1 percent of all public school students. In addition, approximately 45,000 attended Bureau of Indian Education schools, which serve mostly low-income students. GAO was asked to examine the public school choice options available to Indian students. This report examines the public school choice options located in areas with large populations of American Indian and Alaska Native students, collectively referred to as Indian students. GAO analyzed Education data for school year 2015-16, focusing on: (1) school districts with high percentages of Indian students and school options; and (2) the 100 school districts with the largest number of Indian students. GAO analyzed Education data for school year 2015-16, focusing on: (1) school districts with high percentages of Indian students and school options; (2) the 100 school districts with the largest number of Indian students; and (3) Indian student enrollment in public school options. GAO analyzed Education data for school year 2015-16, focusing on: (1) school districts with high percentages of Indian students and school options; (2) the 100 school districts with the largest number of Indian students; and (3) Indian student enrollment in public school options. GAO analyzed Education data for school year 2015-16, focusing on: (1) school districts with high percentages of Indian students and school options; (2) the 100 school districts with the largest number of Indian students; and (3) Indian student enrollment in public school options. GAO analyzed Education data for school year 2015-16, focusing on: (1) school districts with high percentages of Indian students and school options; (2) the 100 school districts with the largest number of Indian students; and (3) Indian student enrollment in public school options. GAO also interviewed federal officials and academic subject matter experts. What GAO Found Few areas with high percentages of Indian students had options other than traditional public schools, according to GAO's analysis of Education data for school year 2015-16. Of the 451 school districts with high percentages of Indian students in GAO's analysis, 84 percent (378 districts) had only traditional public schools. The remaining 16 percent (73 districts) had at least one Bureau of Indian Education (BIE) school, charter school, magnet school, or career and technical education (CTE) school. The most common option was a BIE school. Among districts that had only traditional public schools, about three-quarters of them had more than one school. The presence of a school choice option or more than one traditional school in a given location does not mean that a given school is necessarily available to all Indian students in the area. This may be because of school-level factors such as enrollment caps, eligibility requirements, or grade levels offered, and environmental factors, such as limited transportation options. GAO also analyzed Education data from the 100 school districts with the largest number of Indian students. Some of these districts were located in large urban areas and a majority had at least one other option in addition to traditional public schools. Of these 100 districts, 62 offered at least one option other than a traditional public school, with the most common option being charter schools. Even when Indian students had more school choice options, there was no consistent enrollment pattern across districts with large numbers of Indian students. In about a quarter of the districts that had at least one charter school, Indian students enrolled in charter schools in similar percentages as non-Indian students. In the remaining districts, enrollment patterns varied. For example, in one school district near Boise, Idaho and another near Fairbanks, Alaska, Indian students attended charter schools at higher percentages than their peers by 60 percentage points and 6 percentage points, respectively. In the remaining districts, Indian students attended magnet schools at lower percentages than non-Indian students. Whether Indian students enrolled in different types of schools could be a function of local differences in school choice and could be influenced by the extent to which these schools offered curricula that reflect Indian languages, cultures, or histories. Experts with whom GAO spoke said that in some areas, tribes have more control over education for Indian students, which can increase the tribe's ability to influence curricula and accountability metrics to help meet Indian students' academic and non-academic needs. Experts further noted that many districts with high percentages of Indian students are located near tribal lands, which can offer Indian students living there greater access to culturally-relevant curricula and instruction in Native languages than their peers in urban areas.
gao_GAO-19-115: Why GAO Did This Study SNAP is the nation's largest food assistance program for low-income individuals and households. In fiscal year 2017, SNAP provided $2 billion in benefits to about 5.5 million SNAP recipients. GAO was asked to review SNAP recipient fraud. This report examines (1) the extent to which SNAP households in selected states are making out-of-state purchases that may indicate potential recipient fraud; (2) the extent to which selected states are using data analytics—including those applied to out-of-state transactions—to find potential SNAP recipient fraud, and what advantages and challenges, if any, have they experienced doing so, and (3) how FNS has assisted states in implementing leading practices for data analytics for fraud detection. GAO analyzed fiscal year 2017 SNAP transaction data from FNS for all participating households in the three selected states, and interviewed officials from FNS and state SNAP agencies. What GAO Found A relatively large number of Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP) households made out-of-state purchases, as allowed under the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP) statute, but the total dollar value of out-of-state purchases was small compared to SNAP purchases overall. GAO identified approximately 5.5 million households that made out-of-state SNAP purchases in fiscal year 2017. In comparison, FNS reported that the monthly average number of SNAP households was approximately 21 million in fiscal year 2017. Out-of-state purchases may indicate potential program violations, including eligibility fraud or trafficking. However, because out-of-state purchases are permitted, analysis of additional household and transaction information is generally needed to identify potential fraud. GAO's analysis of fiscal year 2017 transaction data in the three selected states found that SNAP households without out-of-state purchases were generally just as likely to have made the types of purchases that may indicate SNAP recipient fraud as households with out-of-state purchases. GAO found that the analysis of transaction data for other factors may allow states to identify households at risk of trafficking and make them a higher priority for investigation. GAO found out-of-state purchase information alone is of limited benefit to identify SNAP households that may be engaged in trafficking. Some selected states reported using data analytics beyond required data matching and cited advantages as well as organizational and resource challenges. For example, officials in all seven selected states reported conducting additional data analytics beyond data matching, such as conducting data mining to detect and flag transactions that indicate potential recipient fraud. Officials in all seven selected states reported a range of organizational and resource challenges that either prevented them from using more advanced data analytics techniques or made their current data analytics practices difficult to implement. For example, officials in Washington reported that they were unable to quantify the benefits of data analytics because of the challenge of quantifying how often fraud is prevented before it occurs. Officials in Maine reported that they were able to combine data from multiple databases to facilitate SNAP data analytics. FNS has provided individualized assistance and training to several states across the country to build their capacity for data analytics on SNAP, consistent with several of GAO's leading practices. FNS provided assistance through grants, pilot projects, and training at conferences. The pilot projects also informed FNS's early efforts to help states improve their fraud prevention, detection, and investigation processes using data analytics. FNS's assistance to states has aligned with 4 of the 10 leading practices for data analytics identified by GAO in its Fraud Risk Framework. FNS officials said that FNS is in the early stages of promoting states' use of data analytics for SNAP fraud prevention and detection, and its efforts have focused on assessing the current capacity of states to use data analytics and determining analytic practices that are effective. What GAO Recommends GAO recommends that FNS develop and implement additional methods to widely disseminate information about states that have built support for data analytics and leveraged existing resources to implement or expand their data analytics programs to states seeking such examples. FNS agreed with GAO's recommendation.
gao_GAO-18-231: Why GAO Did This Study The 2005 BRAC round was the largest and most complex ever. The BRAC process was intended to reduce excess infrastructure, transform the military, and promote jointness. The BRAC Commission recommended that DOD close or realign installations, establish joint bases, and construct new facilities. The BRAC 2005 round ended on September 15, 2011. GAO was asked to review the BRAC process. This report assesses the extent that (1) DOD (1) measured the achievement of goals for reducing excess infrastructure, transforming the military, and promoting jointness for the 2005 BRAC round and (2) implemented prior GAO recommendations and addressed any additional challenges faced in BRAC 2005 to improve performance for any future BRAC round. GAO reviewed DOD's BRAC 2005 report and BRAC 2005 recommendations, and interviewed DOD officials and 26 military units or organizations. What GAO Found The Department of Defense (DOD) generally did not measure the achievement of the 2005 Base Realignment and Closure (BRAC) goals—reducing excess infrastructure, transforming the military, and promoting jointness. Specifically, a senior ASD (EI&E) official stated that no performance measures existed to evaluate the achievement of goals and the office did not create baselines to measure performance. Air Force officials stated that they did not measure the achievement of goals but that it would have been helpful to have metrics to measure success, especially as DOD had requested from Congress another BRAC round. Army officials similarly stated it did not measure the achievement of goals, noting that measuring excess capacity would have been important to help DOD get authorization for another BRAC round. Navy and Marine Corps officials said that they did not track performance measures or otherwise measure the achievement of the BRAC 2005 goals. Instead of measuring the achievement of BRAC 2005 goals, officials with ASD (EI&E) and the military departments stated that they tracked completion of the BRAC recommendations by the statutory deadline of September 2011 and measured the cost savings associated with the recommendations. Senior ASD (EI&E) officials stated that the primary measure of success was completing the recommendations as detailed by the implementation actions documented in the business plans. However, tracking completion of the recommendations and measuring savings did not enable the department to determine the success of the BRAC round in achieving its goals. Without a requirement to identify and measure the achievement of goals for a BRAC round, DOD cannot demonstrate to Congress whether the implementation of any future BRAC round will improve efficiency and effectiveness or otherwise have the effect that the department says its proposed recommendations will achieve. If Congress would like to increase its oversight for any future BRAC round, requiring DOD to identify appropriate measures of effectiveness and track achievement of its goals would provide it with improved visibility over the expected outcomes. DOD has implemented 33 of the 65 prior GAO recommendations that GAO identified in its work since 2004, and it has the opportunity to address additional challenges regarding communications and monitoring to improve any future BRAC round. Specifically, for the BRAC analysis phase, DOD implemented 1 of 12 recommendations, and it has agreed to implement another 7 recommendations should Congress authorize any future BRAC round. Additionally, GAO found that DOD can improve its communications during the analysis phase. For the implementation phase, DOD implemented 28 of 39 recommendations, and it has agreed to implement another 3 recommendations. Further, GAO found it can improve monitoring of mission-related changes. For the disposal phase, DOD implemented 4 of 14 recommendations, and it has agreed to implement another 8 recommendations. What GAO Recommends GAO recommends that DOD (1) ensure that ASD (EI&E) and the military departments take steps to establish clear and consistent communications throughout the department during data collection, and (2) provide specific guidance for the military departments to monitor and report mission-related changes that require significant changes to the recommendation business plans. DOD concurred with both recommendations.
gao_GAO-18-554: Why GAO Did This Study The federal government obligates about $3 billion annually for advertising contracts, which are contracts that provide information on the government's contract awards and obligations. GAO has previously reported that federal agencies have obligated more than $3 billion annually for advertising contracts. GAO was asked to review federal contracting with small disadvantaged businesses (SDB) and women-owned businesses. This report examines (1) the amount federal agencies have obligated on advertising contracts over the 5 most recent fiscal years (2013 through 2017) and the amount going to SDBs and women-owned businesses; and (2) the agencies that have directed the most advertising contract obligations to these businesses and how this has changed over time. GAO analyzed federal contract obligations data for fiscal years 2013 through 2017 and interviewed agency officials. GAO also analyzed federal advertising contract obligations to the five agencies that obligated the most on advertising contracts over the past 5 years. What GAO Found Over the past 5 fiscal years (2013 through 2017), federal agencies have obligated on average about $870 million annually for advertising contracts, with about 13 percent (approximately $114 million annually) of these obligations going to specified businesses. This share of advertising contract obligations going to these businesses over fiscal years 2013 through 2017 was consistent with the share of total federal contracting obligations going to these businesses (also on average 13 percent over this period). The amount of advertising contract obligations going to these businesses nearly doubled from fiscal year 2013 to 2017 (from $75 million to $147 million) and also increased as a percent of total advertising contract obligations (from 9 percent of these obligations to 16 percent). Specified businesses also represented an increasing share of businesses receiving advertising contract obligations, from 30 percent (194 businesses) in fiscal year 2013 to 39 percent (250 businesses) in fiscal year 2017. The most notable increase over the 5-year timeframe, both in dollars and as a percentage of total advertising contract obligations, was in the women-owned category, which increased by $56 million, or 93 percent. Specified businesses also represented an increasing share of businesses receiving advertising contract obligations, from 30 percent (194 businesses) in fiscal year 2013 to 39 percent (250 businesses) in fiscal year 2017. The most notable increase over the 5-year timeframe, both in dollars and as a percentage of total advertising contract obligations, was in the women-owned category, which increased by $56 million, or 93 percent. Specified businesses were those classified as small disadvantaged businesses (including those that self-identify as small disadvantaged businesses and those that are certified by the Small Business Administration for the 8(a) business development program), minority-owned businesses, and women-owned businesses. Minority-owned businesses were those categorized as being owned by Asian-Pacific-, Subcontinent-Asian-, Black-, Hispanic-, and Native-Americans, as well as “other minorities.” The departments of Defense (DOD), Homeland Security (DHS), and Health and Human Services (HHS) were responsible for 73 percent of the $570 million of federal advertising contract obligations that went to specified businesses over fiscal years 2013 through 2017. Thirty four other agencies were responsible for the remaining 27 percent of these obligations. For each of the 5 years GAO reviewed, DOD, DHS, and HHS were consistently the top three agencies in terms of the amount of advertising contract obligations they directed to specified businesses. Additionally, all three generally increased the amounts they obligated to these businesses. For example, in fiscal year 2013, these three agencies obligated over 60 percent of all federal advertising contract obligations to specified businesses; in 2017 they accounted for more than 80 percent of these obligations. In several cases agencies directed more than half of their advertising contract obligations to specified businesses, though these agencies in general obligated less to advertising contracts than top-spending agencies. Ten agencies with advertising contract obligations of at least $1 million over fiscal years 2013 through 2017, such as the departments of Justice and Energy, directed at least half of their obligations to specified businesses. With the exception of DHS, which obligated about $200 million for advertising contracts over the 5-year period, these agencies all obligated less than $25 million for advertising contracts over this timeframe. In contrast, DOD directed a relatively small share (5 percent) of its advertising contract obligations to specified businesses, making it 29th out of 37 agencies when ranked according to the percentage of advertising contract obligations going to these businesses. However, because the department obligated a large amount for advertising contracts ($2.6 billion over the 5-year period), it ranked second in terms of the amount obligated to specified businesses. What GAO Recommends GAO is not making any recommendations in this report.
gao_GAO-18-230: Why GAO Did This Study DOD's current budget request for fiscal year 2016 included a provision for GAO to review DOD's 2017 excess capacity report. This report examines (1) the extent to which DOD's 2017 report addressed the required elements and partially addressed the required elements, and (2) the extent to which DOD's methodology and analysis for estimating excess capacity have the accuracy and analytical sufficiency to provide Congress with a reasonable estimate of the actual excess capacity within the department. GAO reviewed DOD's 2017 report and interviewed DOD officials. What GAO Found The Department of Defense's (DOD) 2017 excess capacity analysis does not have the accuracy and analytical sufficiency to provide Congress with a reasonable estimate of the actual excess capacity within the department. DOD's 2017 excess capacity analysis does not have the accuracy and analytical sufficiency to provide Congress with a reasonable estimate of the actual excess capacity within the department. Specifically, DOD's use of a 1989 baseline for excess capacity results in inaccurate estimates of excess capacity; DOD's methodology included assumptions that were not always reasonable; and DOD's approach to estimating excess capacity is not always sufficient or implemented consistently across the military departments. DOD noted some of these same limitations in its 2017 infrastructure capacity report. Specifically, DOD's use of a 1989 baseline for excess capacity results in inaccurate estimates of excess capacity; DOD's methodology included assumptions that were not always reasonable; and DOD's approach to estimating excess capacity is not always sufficient or implemented consistently across the military departments. DOD noted some of these same limitations in its 2017 infrastructure capacity report. What GAO Recommends GAO recommends that DOD update the baseline used for estimating excess capacity; use assumptions that are considered reasonable; and develop guidance to improve the methods used in the analysis and ensure consistent implementation of DOD's methodology to produce reliable estimates of excess capacity across the department. DOD concurred with one recommendation and partially concurred with the other two recommendations.
gao_GAO-18-172: Why GAO Did This Study TSA is responsible for securing the nation's commercial aviation system. TSA has a policy that requires that all passengers and property be screened before being transported on a commercial passenger aircraft. TSA also has the authority to enter into OTAs, which are legally enforceable promises between TSA and another party that are other than a procurement contract, grant, cooperative agreement, lease, or loan. GAO was asked to review TSA's use of OTAs. This report examines (1) how TSA uses OTAs, (2) how TSA determines price reasonableness and monitors selected OTAs, and (3) the extent to which TSA has implemented OTA oversight. GAO reviewed TSA's OTA policy and analyzed OTA data from fiscal years 2012 through 2016. GAO also interviewed TSA officials. What GAO Found From fiscal years 2012 through 2016, the Transportation Security Administration (TSA) reported obligating millions annually through OTAs, which amounted to at least $1.4 billion, or about 13 percent of its overall obligations. Five TSA reimbursement programs used OTAs to partially or fully reimburse airports and law enforcement agencies for the allowable costs associated with TSA security programs such as the design and construction of checked baggage inline systems. These five reimbursement programs accounted for about 99 percent of the $1.1 billion that TSA obligated on OTAs that were awarded during this period. The remaining three non-reimbursement programs accounted for a small amount of obligations and awarded a low number of OTAs for services including intelligence analysis and the development of aviation standards. GAO's review of 29 OTAs awarded by 8 TSA programs from fiscal years 2012 through 2016 found that the methods used to determine price reasonableness and monitor these OTAs varied based on the complexity of the requirement. For example, for OTAs awarded by the Electronic Baggage Screening Program where the requirements for infrastructure design and construction can be complex, the program produces an independent government cost estimate based on design drawings and specifications from the airports which are required to follow TSA's detailed guidance. The program compares the estimate with the airport authority's independent bid for the design and construction. TSA's contracting officer's representative (COR) is the primary interface between TSA and the airport and is responsible for performing stakeholder coordination functions. For the 29 OTAs GAO reviewed, the methods used to determine price reasonableness and monitor these OTAs varied based on the complexity of the requirement. For example, for OTAs awarded by the Electronic Baggage Screening Program where the requirements for infrastructure design and construction can be complex, the program produces an independent government cost estimate based on design drawings and specifications from the airports which are required to follow TSA's detailed guidance. TSA's OTA policy requires contracting officers to determine that the price negotiated under the OTA is reasonable and to appoint a COR to provide monitoring and a range of administration tasks to ensure that requirements are satisfactorily delivered. For the key areas GAO reviewed, the OTAs generally met the requirements of TSA's policy. Nonetheless, TSA's own 2015 internal compliance review found significant gaps in OTA documentation and reporting. In response to these deficiencies, TSA has taken action to strengthen oversight and compliance with its policy. What GAO Recommends GAO is not making recommendations in this report.
gao_GAO-18-236: Why GAO Did This Study TSA is responsible for ensuring that the nation's aviation security system is adequately protected. TSA operates a screening process that includes screening passengers and their baggage using TSA equipment and screening checked baggage using TSA equipment. TSA uses a computer-based staffing allocation model to allocate staff to airports. GAO was asked to review TSA's process for allocating staff to airports. This report examines (1) how TSA's staffing allocation model is modified and how TSA uses airport-specific information to tailor staffing levels to individual airports, and (2) how TSA monitors airport operations and responds to increases in passenger wait times and throughput. GAO reviewed TSA's staffing allocation model, analyzed wait time and throughput data, and interviewed TSA officials at headquarters and eight airports selected based on the number of TSOs and airport size and configuration. What GAO Found The Transportation Security Administration (TSA) modified the assumptions used in its staffing allocation model (model) to reflect changes identified through annual evaluations performed by a contractor. The contractor is specifically tasked with evaluating the assumptions related to the time needed to screen passengers and their baggage. For example, TSA officials stated that they increased the expected time needed to screen passengers for one type of passenger screening equipment in fiscal year 2017 because the contractor found that the actual time needed was more than the assumption TSA used in fiscal year 2016. Similarly, in fiscal year 2016, TSA allocated fewer staff to review images of checked baggage, compared to previous years, because the contractor's evaluation determined it took TSA less time to review the images than the time observed in previous years. TSA uses airport-specific information to tailor staffing levels to individual airports' needs. For example, beginning in fiscal year 2016, TSA used passenger throughput forecasts to allocate staff commensurate with the expected rate of increase in passenger throughput at each airport. The estimated increase in passenger throughput for each fiscal year is based primarily on national and airport-level data from the previous 3 months from the TSA's web-based data collection system, TSA's web-based data collection system, and flight forecast data from the airline industry, as well as additional input from other sources. TSA uses airport-specific information to tailor staffing levels to individual airport needs. For example, TSA headquarters officials use airport-specific data on staff availability, training needs, supervisory needs, and additional security layers to manually adjust the model's staffing allocation output at a line item level. TSA uses passenger wait time and throughput data to monitor airport operations and respond to increases in passenger wait times and throughput. TSA requires all airports to enter their wait time and throughput data daily into the Performance Measurement Information System (PMIS), TSA's web-based data collection system, no later than 3:30 AM Eastern Time of the next calendar day so that the data can be included in the morning's Daily Leadership Report. TSA also monitors airport operations at 28 airports in near real time. TSA airport officials use a variety of tools to respond to increases in passenger wait times and throughput. TSA officials at select airports use passenger screening canines to expedite the screening process and support screening operations during increased passenger throughput and wait time periods. TSA headquarters has taken steps intended to improve information sharing with stakeholders about staffing and related screening procedures at airports. For example, TSA headquarters officials hold daily conference calls with industry association, airline, and airport officials at the 28 airports monitored by the Airport Operations Center (AOC). TSA headquarters officials also held presentations and meetings with industry, airline, and airport officials to discuss TSA's staffing allocation model, security enhancements at airports, and airport screening processes, among other things. Stakeholders GAO interviewed generally reported improved satisfaction with TSA headquarters information sharing efforts and with most TSA airport-level staff. For example, officials from seven of eight airlines and all eight airports GAO visited stated that they have positive relationships with their FSDs and that their FSDs were accessible and available when needed, while the remaining airline official noted improving access to information. What GAO Recommends GAO is not making any recommendations in this report.
gao_GAO-18-100: Why GAO Did This Study The Medicare FFS program, which consists of two parts, consists of 38 million beneficiaries enrolled in Medicare Part A and Part B. The current design includes separate deductibles for Part A and Part B services, a variety of per-service copayments and coinsurance after the deductibles are met, and no cap on beneficiaries' cost-sharing responsibilities. The Medicare Prescription Drug, Improvement, and Modernization Act of 2015 included a provision for GAO to review the Medicare FFS cost-sharing design. This report examines (1) the current Medicare FFS cost-sharing design, (2) the potential effects of modernizing the design, and (3) the potential effects of modernizing the design on beneficiaries' cost-sharing responsibilities. GAO analyzed documents and interviewed officials from CMS, the American Academy of Actuaries, and other experts. GAO also analyzed four illustrative cost-sharing designs that were illustrative in terms of the number of beneficiaries, the cost-sharing responsibilities, and the number of beneficiaries with cost-sharing responsibilities. GAO also interviewed experts and reviewed studies and experts on the design. What GAO Found The current Medicare fee-for-service (FFS) cost-sharing design can be confusing, contribute to beneficiaries' overuse of services, and leave beneficiaries exposed to catastrophic costs. Modernizing the design could address these concerns, but would involve trade-offs. For example, maintaining Medicare's share of costs would involve a trade-off between the level of the cap and the deductible (or other cost-sharing). The current Medicare FFS cost-sharing design can be confusing, contribute to beneficiaries' overuse of services, and leave beneficiaries exposed to catastrophic costs. Modernizing the design could address these concerns, but would involve trade-offs. For example, maintaining Medicare's share of costs would involve a trade-off between the level of the cap and the deductible (or other cost-sharing). The direct effect of modernizing the Medicare FFS cost-sharing design (i.e., the effect when holding utilization and enrollment constant) on beneficiaries' cost-sharing responsibilities would depend on the specific revisions and the time horizon examined. The direct effect of modernizing the Medicare FFS cost-sharing design (i.e., the effect when holding utilization and enrollment constant) on beneficiaries' cost-sharing responsibilities would depend on the specific revisions and the time horizon examined. The current Medicare FFS cost-sharing design would affect beneficiaries' costs indirectly through beneficiaries' and supplemental insurers' behavioral responses to altered incentives, according to the studies GAO reviewed and experts GAO spoke to. These studies and experts identified several types of behavioral responses that would influence the net effect of a modernized design on beneficiaries' out-of-pocket costs, including changes in beneficiaries' demand for, and insurers' supply of, supplemental insurance; changes in beneficiaries' utilization of services; changes in Medicare beneficiaries' enrollment in FFS versus MA; and interactions among these and other behavioral responses, including effects on the price of supplemental insurance. According to studies and experts GAO interviewed, implementing a modernized design would likely trigger changes in the demand for, and supply of, supplemental insurance. For example, a focus group of current and future Medicare beneficiaries convened by the Medicare Payment Advisory Commission and a report from the American Academy of Actuaries stated that the addition of an annual cap would reduce the need of some beneficiaries to purchase supplemental insurance. While beneficiaries who drop their supplemental insurance would then need to pay all their Medicare cost-sharing responsibilities, those might be less than their annual premium for supplemental insurance. Additionally, according to experts GAO interviewed and studies GAO reviewed, different behavioral responses would also likely interact and affect beneficiaries' out-of-pocket costs. For example, a study by the Kaiser Family Foundation and a report by the Congressional Budget Office both anticipated that a modernized design could change the proportion of Medicare beneficiaries who decide to enroll in FFS or MA. Similarly, officials from the American Academy of Actuaries told GAO that they would expect a change in demand for MA under a modernized design. What GAO Recommends GAO is not making recommendations in this report.
gao_GAO-19-66: Why GAO Did This Study VA has a mission to prevent veteran suicide. In 2010, VHA began a suicide prevention media outreach campaign to raise awareness about VHA's suicide prevention resources. In September 2016, VHA awarded a new contract to a contractor to provide both suicide prevention and mental health media outreach. GAO was asked to review VHA's suicide prevention media outreach. This report examines (1) the extent to which VHA's suicide prevention media outreach activities declined in fiscal years 2017 and 2018 compared to earlier years of the campaign, and (2) the extent to which VHA monitors the effectiveness of its suicide prevention media outreach campaign. GAO reviewed relevant federal laws, regulations, and guidance; interviewed VA and contractor officials; and analyzed VHA's suicide prevention media outreach activities. What GAO Found The Department of Veterans Affairs' (VA) Veterans Health Administration (VHA) has decreased in recent years in its suicide prevention media outreach activities due to leadership turnover and reorganization. For example, VHA officials said the National Director for Suicide Prevention position was vacant from July 2017 through April 2018. VHA filled the position temporarily with a 6-month detail from another agency from October 2017 through March 2018 and then hired this individual as the permanent director on April 30, 2018. VHA officials that worked on the campaign told GAO they shifted their focus away from the suicide prevention media outreach campaign toward the mental health outreach campaign due to reorganization of the offices responsible for suicide prevention activities in 2017. Specifically, under the new organization, and in the absence of suicide prevention program leadership, the officials began reporting directly to mental health program leadership and became more focused on the mental health outreach aspects of the contract. Following the reorganization, officials that worked on the campaign did not have a clear line of reporting to the suicide prevention program. This is inconsistent with federal internal control standards for control environment, which require agencies to assign responsibilities to achieve its objectives. If a key role is vacant, management needs to determine by whom and how those responsibilities will be fulfilled in order to meet its objectives. VHA works with its contractor to create and monitor metrics to help gauge the effectiveness of its suicide prevention media outreach campaign in raising awareness among veterans and others about VHA services, such as the Veterans Crisis Line (VCL). The metrics primarily focus on the number of individuals who were exposed to or interacted with VHA's suicide prevention content across various forms of outreach, including social media, public service announcements (PSA), and websites. According to VHA, the metrics are intended to help VHA ensure that its media outreach activities achieve intended results, such as increasing awareness and use of the resources identified on the VCL website. VHA officials told GAO that the metrics are intended to help VHA ensure that its media outreach activities achieve intended results, such as increasing awareness and use of the resources identified on the VCL website. However, VHA has not established targets for the majority of the metrics it uses to help gauge the effectiveness of its suicide prevention media outreach campaign. As a result, VHA does not have the information it needs to fully evaluate the campaign's effectiveness in raising awareness of VHA's suicide prevention resources among veterans, including the VCL. For example, GAO found that VHA's contractor's monitoring reports—a summary of key metrics that VHA uses to routinely monitor information regarding the campaign—generally focused on outreach “highlights” and positive results. The reports did not set expectations based on past outreach or targets for new outreach, and lacked more comprehensive information on whether outreach performed against these expectations. For example, a monitoring report from 2018 showed that during one month, there were 21,000 social media mentions of keywords specific to VA suicide prevention, such as “VCL” or “veteran suicide,” across social media platforms. These mentions earned 120 million impressions; however, there was no indication of the number of keyword mentions or impressions that VHA expected based on its media outreach activities. In addition, the report did not indicate the proportion of mentions that VHA believed were specifically driven by its outreach activities, and there also was no indication of whether these mentions were positive or negative, or what actions to take based on this information. VHA officials told GAO that they have not established targets for most of the suicide prevention media outreach campaign because they lack meaningful targets for the metrics to help evaluate the campaign. VHA officials said that the only target they have established is for each PSA to rank in the top 10 percent of the Nielsen ratings because this is the only meaningful target available that is accepted industry-wide. VHA officials stated that using any other targets would be arbitrary.
