gao_GAO-18-127: Why GAO Did This Study The number of vehicles affected by safety defect vehicle recalls has increased dramatically since 2011. In 2011, NHTSA initiated a recall of over 8 million vehicles with faulty ignition switches. In 2015, NHTSA began a national advertising campaign encouraging consumers to check for open recalls using the agency's vehicle identification number (VIN) and year, make, and model look-up tools. In 2016, NHTSA began consolidating its websites into NHTSA.gov to provide a single access point for its auto recall content. GAO was asked to review the use of publicly available auto recall information. This report examines (1) how consumers and industry stakeholders use publicly available auto recall information; (2) how easy or difficult to use consumers find the auto recall areas of NHTSA.gov; and (3) steps, if any, NHTSA has taken to raise consumer awareness about auto recalls and how NHTSA evaluated the effectiveness of these steps. GAO analyzed NHTSA data on recalls, interviewed NHTSA officials, and conducted 12 focus group discussions with 94 consumers. What GAO Found Consumers in focus groups GAO conducted with used and new vehicle owners who had experienced an auto recall in the last 24 months selected safety risk and convenience as the two most influential factors they considered when using auto recall information to decide whether to complete repairs. Consumers in the sessions overwhelmingly selected safety risk as the most influential factor they considered when making repair decisions. Consumers in the sessions overwhelmingly selected safety risk as the second most influential factor they considered when making repair decisions. While most consumers in our focus groups reported a preference to receive auto recall notification by mail, most preferred to receive notifications by at least one additional electronic means such as e-mail, phone calls, and text messages. Although the vast majority of consumers in our focus groups reported a preference to receive auto recall notification by mail, most preferred to receive notifications by at least one additional electronic means such as e-mail, phone calls, and text messages. Although most consumers in our focus groups found the auto recall areas of NHTSA.gov easy to use, some consumers experienced difficulties completing tasks GAO asked them to perform. For example, some consumers found the search results did not provide the information they were seeking. Federal key website usability practices state that agencies should ensure that results of user searches provide the precise information being sought, and in a format matching users' expectations. Federal key website usability practices state that agencies should communicate quality information externally and select appropriate methods for communicating with the public. While most consumers in our usability testing sessions found the auto recall areas of NHTSA.gov easy to use, some consumers experienced difficulties completing tasks GAO asked them to perform. For example, some consumers found that they did not know enough information about their specific vehicles to feel confident that they were searching for the correct vehicle. Federal key website usability practices state that agencies should write website content using plain language, so website visitors can easily find and use what they need. NHTSA has initiated activities to raise consumer awareness about auto recalls, but it is too early to evaluate the agency's efforts. NHTSA began a pilot program to evaluate the feasibility and effectiveness of informing consumers about open recalls during vehicle registration. In September 2016, NHTSA issued a Notice of Proposed Rulemaking (NPRM) that proposes to require manufacturers to notify consumers about open recalls by electronic means—such as e-mails, phone calls, and text messages, in addition to First-Class Mail. NHTSA officials told GAO the agency is working with the administration on NHTSA's regulatory portfolio and priorities, including this rulemaking. What GAO Recommends GAO recommends that the Administrator of NHTSA determine a completion date for the agency's website consolidation effort. The Administrator of NHTSA should, while the agency continues its website consolidation effort, take interim steps to improve the usability of the auto recall areas of NHTSA. DOT concurred with GAO's recommendations.
gao_GAO-18-305: Why GAO Did This Study The federal government enacted SMCRA to regulate the surface effects of coal mining and reclamation. SMCRA requires that financial assurances be sufficient to ensure reclamation compliant with water quality standards. OSMRE oversees the coal program in 23 states and four Indian tribes. GAO was asked to review the financial assurances that OSMRE and state regulatory authorities have received. This report examines (1) the amount of financial assurances that state regulatory authorities and OSMRE have held as financial assurances for coal mine reclamation, (2) the steps OSMRE has taken to oversee financial assurances, and (3) the challenges that OSMRE and state regulatory authorities face in managing financial assurances for coal mine reclamation. GAO reviewed federal and state regulations and OSMRE and state regulatory authority data on financial assurances held as financial assurances for coal mine reclamation. GAO also interviewed federal and state regulatory authority officials, representatives from organizations associated with the mining and financial assurance industries, and representatives from environmental nongovernmental organizations. What GAO Found The Department of the Interior's Office of Surface Mining Reclamation and Enforcement (OSMRE) reported holding a total of approximately $10.2 billion in financial assurances for coal mine reclamation in 2017. Of the total amount of financial assurances, approximately 76 percent ($7.8 billion) were in the form of surety bonds, 12 percent ($1.2 billion) in collateral bonds, and 12 percent ($1.2 billion) in self-bonds. Of the total amount of financial assurances, approximately 76 percent ($7.8 billion) were in the form of surety bonds, 12 percent ($1.2 billion) in collateral bonds, and 12 percent ($1.2 billion) in self-bonds. Twenty-four states reported holding surety bonds, 20 states reported holding collateral bonds, and 8 states reported holding self-bonds. In addition, OSMRE officials identified 6 states—Indiana, Kentucky, Maryland, Ohio, Virginia, and West Virginia—that have also established alternative bonding systems, such as bond pools. OSMRE has taken a variety of steps to oversee financial assurances and aspects of the mining and reclamation process that can affect whether the amount of financial assurances obtained will cover the cost of required reclamation. For example, OSMRE and state regulatory authorities periodically review financial assurance amounts, inspect mine sites, and review state programs that implement SMCRA. OSMRE and state regulatory authorities face a number of challenges in managing financial assurances for coal mine reclamation—including those related to self-bonding, unanticipated reclamation costs, and the financial stability of surety companies—according to federal and selected state regulatory authority officials, representatives from organizations associated with the mining and financial assurance industries, and representatives from environmental nongovernmental organizations. For example, OSMRE and state regulatory authorities face challenges in managing financial assurances for coal mine reclamation—including those related to self-bonding, unanticipated reclamation costs, and the financial stability of surety companies—according to federal and selected state regulatory authority officials, representatives from organizations associated with the mining and financial assurance industries, and representatives from environmental nongovernmental organizations. For example, OSMRE and state regulatory authorities face challenges in managing the risk associated with self-bonding. For example, the financial relationships between parent and subsidiary companies have become increasingly complex, making it difficult to ascertain an operator's financial health on the basis of information reported in company financial and accounting documents. OSMRE and state regulatory authorities may find it difficult to get operators to replace existing self-bonds with other financial assurances if needed, according to some parties GAO interviewed. For example, in 2015 the Wyoming regulatory authority determined that an operator no longer qualified for self-bonding and ordered it to replace a $411 million self-bond. However, the operator entered into bankruptcy without having replaced the self-bond. OSMRE recently announced that it is reconsidering the need for and scope of potential changes to its self-bonding regulations. OSMRE officials said that they did not have a timeline for finalizing a decision on potential changes in its bonding regulations. In addition, OSMRE rescinded its August 2016 policy advisory that states take steps to assess whether operators currently using self-bonds can still quality to do so and that states not accept any new self-bonds. What GAO Recommends Congress should consider amending SMCRA to eliminate the use of self-bonding as a type of financial assurance for coal mine reclamation. The Department of the Interior did not provide written comments on GAO's findings and matter for congressional consideration. OSMRE provided technical comments in an e-mail, which GAO incorporated as appropriate.
gao_GAO-18-375: Why GAO Did This Study VHA provides outpatient care through CBOCs, which are clinics that provide primary care and mental health care services, and also may provide specialty care services such as cardiology or neurology, in an outpatient setting. VHA policy requires that VHA-operated and contracted CBOCs provide the same standard of care to veterans that is of high quality. GAO was asked to review VHA's oversight of CBOCs. This report examines (1) the extent to which VHA-operated and contracted CBOCs provide the same standard of care and (2) the extent to which VHA has implemented oversight requirements and the extent to which the CBOC Report provides accurate and complete information on CBOCs. GAO reviewed VHA policies and procedures, interviewed VHA officials, and compared the CBOC Report to VHA's most recent CBOC Report. What GAO Found The Department of Veterans Affairs' (VA) Veterans Health Administration (VHA) operates multi-specialty outpatient clinics (CBOC) that provide primary care and mental health care services, and also may provide specialty care services such as cardiology or neurology, in an outpatient setting. VHA-operated CBOCs provided more specialty care and less primary care and mental health care as a proportion of their total provided services than contracted CBOCs in fiscal years 2014 through 2016. For example, in fiscal year 2016, specialty care (e.g., cardiology, gastroenterology, physical therapy) comprised 13 percent of services provided at VHA-operated clinics and 5 percent of services provided at contracted clinics. In contrast, VHA-operated clinics provided proportionally less primary care and mental health services (services offered at all CBOCs) in fiscal year 2016—these services comprised 66 percent of the services provided at VHA-operated clinics, but 84 percent of the services provided at contracted clinics. GAO found that VHA-operated CBOCs had higher per-encounter expenditures than contracted CBOCs—a difference ranging from 3 to 5 percent per encounter. GAO also found that per-encounter expenditures for almost all service types were higher on average for VHA-operated CBOCs than contracted CBOCs in fiscal year 2016. VHA has not fully implemented oversight requirements, and inaccurate information limits its oversight of CBOC quality of care. Specifically, VHA has not fully implemented oversight requirements that align with its established policies, including a requirement to establish guidelines for monitoring quality of care in CBOCs. The CBOC Report, which is VHA's only report that allows for comparing clinical quality of care data across VHA-operated and contracted clinics, lacks accurate and complete information. These gaps limit the CBOC Report's usefulness as a monitoring tool to determine whether VHA-operated and contracted CBOCs are providing the same standard of care. This is inconsistent with federal standards for internal control for information and communication, which state that management should use quality information to achieve the entity's objectives. Specifically, VHA distributes the CBOC Report to the Veterans Integrated Service Networks (VISN) and Veterans Integrated Service Centers (VAMC) on a quarterly and year-end basis, which compiles CBOC quality of care performance results based on the Healthcare Effectiveness Data and Information Set (HEDIS), an industry standard set of quality measures. VISNs and VAMCs have access to other types of CBOC performance data, such as patient satisfaction data and wait time data, but these data are not used to assess clinical quality of care and cannot be used to examine performance across all CBOCs or stratified by VHA-operated versus contracted CBOCs. In contrast, the CBOC Report allows for the comparison of clinical quality of care data across all CBOCs, which can be stratified according to whether the clinic is VHA-operated or contracted. However, GAO found that the CBOC Report, which is VHA's only report that allows for comparing clinical quality of care data across both VHA-operated and contracted clinics, lacks accurate and complete information. This is inconsistent with federal standards for internal control related to the control environment, which state that management should, among other things, develop personnel to achieve the entity's objectives. gao_GAO-18-28: Why GAO Did This Study NASA is responsible for integrating and assessing the programmatic and technical readiness of the three programs—SLS, Orion, and EGS—to support the agency's long-term goal of sending humans to distant destinations, including Mars. NASA's approach for integrating and assessing the programmatic and technical readiness of these programs differs from prior NASA human spaceflight programs. GAO was asked to review NASA's approach for integrating and assessing the programmatic and technical readiness of the three programs. This report assesses (1) the benefits and challenges of NASA's approach for integrating and assessing the programmatic and technical readiness of Orion, SLS, and EGS; and (2) the extent to which the Exploration Systems Development (ESD) organization is managing cross-program risks that could affect launch readiness. GAO reviewed NASA policies and procedures, interviewed NASA officials, and analyzed ESD's integration plans. What GAO Found NASA's approach for integrating and assessing the programmatic and technical readiness of its current human spaceflight programs differs from prior NASA human spaceflight programs. This new approach offers some cost and potential efficiency benefits. However, it also brings challenges specific to its structure. In particular, there are oversight challenges because only one of the three programs, Orion, has a cost and schedule estimate for Exploration Mission-2. NASA is already contractually obligating money on SLS and EGS for EM-2, but the lack of cost and schedule baselines for these programs will make it difficult to assess progress over time. Additionally, the approach creates an environment of competing interests because it relies on dual-hatd staff to manage technical and safety aspects on behalf of ESD while also serving as independent oversight of those same areas. Despite the development and integration challenges associated with a new human spaceflight capability, ESD has improved its overall cross-program risk posture over the past 2 years. Nonetheless, it still faces key integration risk areas within software development and verification and validation (V&V). Both are critical to readiness for EM-1 because software acts as the "brain" that ties SLS, Orion, and EGS together in a functioning body, while V&V ensures the integrated body works as expected. The success of these efforts forms the foundation for a launch, no matter the date of EM-1. What GAO Recommends GAO recommends that NASA establish separate cost and schedule baselines for work required to support SLS and EGS for EM-2 and establish separate cost and schedule baselines for each additional capability that encompass all life cycle costs, to include operations and sustainment. NASA partially concurred with GAO's recommendations.
gao_GAO-17-773: Why GAO Did This Study DNN manages a broad range of programs that address the security of nuclear materials worldwide. DNN's programs include removing and disposing of excess nuclear material from civilian sites worldwide, converting civilian research reactors to the use of non-weapons-useable nuclear fuel, and improving the security of weapons-useable nuclear material in key countries. GAO was asked to review DNN's schedule and cost management. This report examines the extent to which (1) selected subprograms within DNN use program management leading practices to manage schedule and cost, and (2) DNN has incorporated program management leading practices in its revised program management policy. GAO reviewed DNN's program management policies and interviewed DNN officials. GAO also reviewed DNN's revised program management policy. What GAO Found The four selected subprograms within the National Nuclear Security Administration's (NNSA) Office of Defense Nuclear Nonproliferation (DNN) generally do not use selected leading program management practices to manage schedule and cost. Specifically, at the time of GAO's review, none of the subprograms had schedule and cost estimates that encompassed its entire life cycle, although one subprogram planned to develop such estimates for its recently-extended life cycle. In addition, none of the selected subprograms measure their overall schedule and cost performance against baseline estimates. NNSA officials said that the subprograms had not developed schedule and cost estimates that cover their life cycles and did not measure the subprograms against baselines due, in part, to uncertainty in planning scope and schedules that rely on the cooperation of other countries. DNN also does not require subprograms to have such estimates or to measure performance against schedule and cost baselines. Following these practices, however, would provide NNSA managers and other stakeholders more complete information to evaluate how much the subprograms may cost to achieve their goals, the amount of time they may need to achieve these goals, and their actual versus planned performance. DNN's 2017 revised program management policy includes some leading practices, but does not address life-cycle schedule and cost management for DNN programs or subprograms. Specifically, the revised policy does not outline requirements for programs or subprograms to establish life-cycle cost estimates or measure performance against schedule or cost baselines. Instead, the revised policy provides requirements on schedule and cost management limited to the NNSA budgeting process covering the 5-year FYNSP. gao_GAO-18-54: Why GAO Did This Study The U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) oversees 22 commodity check-off programs that promote the sale of a commodity through generic promotion, research, and consumer and industry information. AMS is responsible for overseeing these programs. In 2012, the USDA Office of the Inspector General (OIG) found that AMS had weak oversight controls over the 22 commodity check-off programs. GAO was asked to review AMS's oversight of the 22 commodity check-off programs. This report examines (1) AMS's response to recommendations made in the OIG report and (2) the extent to which AMS conducts and evaluates independent economic evaluations of the effectiveness of the 22 commodity check-off programs. GAO reviewed AMS's guidelines and procedures, interviewed agency officials, and reviewed eight independent economic evaluations of the effectiveness of the 22 commodity check-off programs. What GAO Found The Agricultural Marketing Service (AMS) has responded to recommendations for improving its oversight of commodity check-off programs, but some oversight activities are not consistent across programs. AMS has responded to recommendations for improving oversight made in the OIG's 2012 report, particularly by developing and implementing standard operating procedures and conducting internal reviews of AMS check-off program oversight. However, AMS does not provide consistent oversight across check-off programs in some areas; specifically, it does not routinely review check-off program subcontracts during its management reviews, conduct follow-up on management review recommendations, ensure that financial assurances are included in annual audits, or ensure that check-off boards share information with assessment payers on program websites. In conducting their oversight of the check-off programs, senior agency officials and marketing specialists said they face challenges because of increased use of social media, the absence of an information system for tracking approvals, and complex Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) requests for some programs, which may delay the completion of some oversight priorities. AMS has conducted and evaluated independent economic evaluations of the effectiveness of the 22 commodity check-off programs, which have generally shown a positive benefit to those who pay assessments. The evaluations GAO reviewed varied both in the methods used to conduct the analysis and how information was reported and revealed certain methodological limitations. According to agency officials as well as the economists who conducted the evaluations, the variations are in part due to the differences in check-off board resources. GAO found that AMS does not consistently document its review of independent economic evaluations and has no criteria established for determining what makes for a credible methodology and results. Without developing criteria by which AMS can assess the methodology and results of independent evaluations and document those assessments, the assessments may be inconsistent across check-off programs and misleading to agency officials, check-off boards, and assessment payers. What GAO Recommends GAO recommends that AMS revise its standard operating procedures for check-off programs to recognize that management reviews should include a sample of subcontracts for review, establish a mechanism for documenting and tracking follow-up with checkoff boards on the implementation of management review recommendations, ensure that independent financial audits contain statements of assurance, and include in its guidelines and standard operating procedures that key check-off board documents, such as bylaws and policy statements, annual reports, and independent economic evaluations of economic effectiveness are posted on the check-off programs' websites. AMS generally agreed with GAO's findings and recommendations.
gao_GAO-18-474: Why GAO Did This Study VAMCs use reusable medical equipment (RME) to perform medical procedures. RME is a complex and time-consuming process that requires a corresponding increase in the skills and time required to safely reprocess them. VHA has developed policies that VAMCs are required to follow to help ensure that RME is reprocessed correctly. GAO was asked to review VAMCs' reprocessing of RME. This report examines (1) the extent to which VHA oversees VAMCs' adherence to RME policies and (2) the challenges VAMCs face in operating their SPS programs. GAO reviewed VHA policies and inspections, interviewed VHA officials, and reviewed relevant reports. GAO also interviewed officials from all 18 VISNs and selected VAMCs selected based on geographic dispersion and other factors. What GAO Found The Veterans Health Administration (VHA) has not ensured that it has complete information from the annual inspections of VAMCs to have reasonable assurance that VAMCs are following reusable medical equipment (RME) policies intended to ensure veterans are receiving safe care. For fiscal year 2017, GAO determined that VHA should have had records of 144 VISN Sterile Processing System (SPS) inspection reports to have assurance that all required VISN SPS inspections had been conducted. However, GAO found that as of February 2018, VHA had 105 VISN SPS inspection reports and was missing 39, or more than one quarter of the required inspection reports. GAO also found that variation in SPS Inspection Tools and related guidance from VHA resulted in incomplete inspection results for the gastroenterology and dental areas. GAO also found that VHA does not consistently share information, particularly inspection results, with VISNs and VAMCs, and that VISNs and VAMCs would like more of this information. Until this sharing becomes a regular practice, VHA is missing an opportunity to help ensure adherence to its RME policies, which are intended to ensure that veterans are receiving safe care. VAMCs report facing challenges related to RME policies and workforce needs, but VHA has not sufficiently addressed these challenges. According to officials from all of the 18 VISNs and selected VAMCs, the top five challenges VAMCs face in operating their SPS programs are related to meeting certain RME policies and challenges addressing SPS workforce needs. In particular, officials reported experiencing challenges related to lengthy hiring timeframes, need for consistent overtime, and limited pay and professional growth. For example, officials from one VISN estimated that on average it can take 3 to 4 months for a person to be hired. Officials from a few other VISNs noted that not only does the lengthy hiring process create challenges in recruiting qualified candidates (because they accept other positions where they can be more quickly employed), but that it also results in long periods of time when SPS programs are short-staffed. Further, some VISN and VAMC officials told GAO that difficulties maintaining sufficient SPS staff levels have in some instances adversely affected patients' access to care and increased the potential for reprocessing errors that could affect patient safety. What GAO Recommends GAO recommends that VHA (1) ensure all RME inspections are being conducted and reported as required and that the inspection results VHA has are complete; (2) analyze and share top common RME inspection findings and possible solutions with VISNs and VAMCs; and (3) examine the SPS workforce needs and take action based on this assessment, as appropriate. VA concurred with GAO's recommendations.
gao_GAO-19-63: Why GAO Did This Study The federal government obligates tens of billions annually on IT. In fiscal year 2017, the federal government obligated more than $15 billion on IT products and services. GAO was asked to review the use of noncompetitive contracts for IT. This report examines (1) the extent to which agencies used noncompetitive contracts to procure IT products and services for fiscal years 2013 through 2017; (2) the reasons for using noncompetitive contracts for selected IT procurements; (3) the extent to which IT procurements at selected agencies were bridge contracts; and (4) the extent to which noncompetitive IT procurements at selected agencies were in support of legacy systems. GAO analyzed government-wide data on IT obligations from fiscal years 2013 through 2017 and a generalizable sample of 142 contracts and orders from a generalizable sample of 142 contracts and orders. GAO also interviewed agency officials. What GAO Found Federal agencies reported annually obligating between $53 billion in fiscal year 2013 to $59 billion in fiscal year 2017 on information technology (IT)-related products and services. Of that amount, agencies reported that more than $15 billion each year—or about 30 percent of all obligations for IT products and services—were awarded noncompetitively. However, in a generalizable sample of contracts and orders, GAO found significant errors in certain types of orders, which call into question the reliability of competition data associated with roughly $3 billion per year in obligations. As a result, the actual amount agencies obligated on noncompetitive contract awards for IT products and services is unknown. GAO estimates that about 8 percent of fiscal year 2016 IT noncompetitive contracts and orders above $150,000 were bridge contracts. Bridge contracts can be a useful tool in certain circumstances to avoid a gap in providing products and services, but they are typically envisioned to be used for short periods of time. GAO found that in 9 of the 15 cases, bridge contracts were associated with additional bridges not apparent in the documentation related to the contract and order GAO reviewed, such as a joint and agreement (J&A). Agency officials cited a variety of reasons for needing bridge contracts, including acquisition planning challenges, source selection challenges, and bid protests. GAO found that about 7 percent of IT noncompetitive contracts and orders over $150,000 in fiscal year 2016 at selected agencies were in support of legacy IT systems as newly defined in statute, which is considerably fewer than GAO found when using the previous definition of legacy IT. Using this definition, GAO estimated that about 80 percent of IT noncompetitive contracts and orders over $150,000 in fiscal year 2016 at selected agencies were awarded in support of legacy IT systems. In December 2017, Congress enacted the Modernizing Government Technology Act (MGT) as part of the National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2018. This act defined a legacy IT system as an “outdated or obsolete system of information technology.” Using this new definition, GAO estimated that about 7 percent of IT noncompetitive contracts and orders over $150,000 in fiscal year 2016 at selected agencies were awarded in support of legacy IT systems. What GAO Recommends GAO recommends that the Secretary of Defense identify the reasons behind the high rate of miscoding for orders awarded under multiple award contracts and use this information to identify and take action to improve the reliability of the competition data entered into the Federal Procurement Data System-Next Generation (FPDS-NG). DOD and HHS concurred with the recommendations.
gao_GAO-18-295: Why GAO Did This Study The federal government spends billions of dollars annually to acquire heavy equipment, including equipment such as cranes, backhoes, and road maintenance equipment. The Federal Acquisition Regulation (FAR) requires agencies to conduct a lease-versus-purchase analysis before acquiring heavy equipment. GAO was asked to review the acquisition process for heavy equipment. This report addresses: (1) the number, type, and cost of heavy equipment items that are owned by the 24 CFO Act agencies; (2) the heavy equipment items selected agencies have recently acquired and how selected agencies decided to purchase or lease this equipment; and (3) how selected agencies manage the utilization of their heavy equipment. GAO analyzed data from the 24 CFO Act agencies on their heavy equipment, reviewed agency documents, and interviewed officials from the three selected agencies. What GAO Found Twenty agencies reported owning over 136,000 pieces of heavy equipment, at an acquisition cost of over $7.4 billion. The Department of Defense (DOD) reported owning most of this heavy equipment—over 100,000 items, about 74 percent. The Department of Agriculture reported owning the second highest number of heavy equipment items—almost 9,000 items, about 6 percent. Four agencies—the Nuclear Regulatory Commission, the Department of Housing and Urban Development, the Office of Personnel Management, and the Agency for International Development—reported owning five or fewer heavy equipment items each. The 20 agencies reported spending over $7.4 billion in 2016 dollars to acquire the heavy equipment they own. However, actual spending was higher because this inflation-adjusted figure excludes over 37,000 heavy equipment items for which the agencies did not report acquisition cost or acquisition year, or both. Without this information, GAO could not determine the inflation-adjusted cost and therefore did not include the cost of these items in GAO's calculation. The three selected agencies purchased almost 3,500 pieces of heavy equipment in calendar years 2012 through 2016, but did not consistently document lease-versus-purchase analyses. The Air Force spent over $300 million to purchase over 2,600 heavy equipment assets in calendar years 2012 through 2016. The Fish and Wildlife Service spent over $32 million to purchase 348 heavy equipment assets from calendar years 2012 through 2016. The National Park Service spent over $27 million to purchase 471 heavy equipment assets from calendar years 2012 through 2016. The Air Force did not document lease-versus-purchase analyses for six of the eight acquisitions GAO reviewed. For example, Air Force officials were unable to provide documentation of a lease-versus-purchase analysis for six of the eight acquisitions GAO reviewed. Air Force officials said that they did not believe a lease-versus-purchase analysis was required because the new equipment was either replacing old equipment that was previously approved or could be deployed. However, the Air Force does not have guidance that describes the circumstances that require either a lease-versus-purchase analysis or documentation of the rationale for not completing such analysis. Air Force officials said that they consider mission needs and equipment availability, among other factors when making these decisions. Without greater clarity regarding when to conduct or document lease-versus-purchase analyses, officials at the three selected agencies may not be conducting such analyses when appropriate and may not always make the best acquisition decisions. What GAO Recommends GAO recommends that the Secretary of the Air Force develop guidance to clarify the circumstances in which lease-versus-purchase analyses for heavy equipment acquisitions are to be conducted and documented. The Department of the Interior concurred with GAO's recommendation.
gao_GAO-18-221: Why GAO Did This Study DOD spends billions of dollars each year to purchase goods and services overseas and pay service-members stationed abroad. DOD uses its budget rates to liquidate its overseas operations and maintenance (O&M) and Military Personnel (MILPERS) appropriations. In fiscal year 2012, Congress appropriated $970 million to the FCFD account to cover losses that the services experienced due to foreign currency fluctuations. GAO was asked to review DOD's management of its FCFD account. This report examines (1) the extent to which DOD revised its budget rates in fiscal years 2014 through 2016, (2) the extent to which DOD has taken steps to reduce costs in selecting foreign currency rates at which to make disbursements and determine whether opportunities exist to achieve additional savings, and (3) the extent to which DOD has effectively managed the FCFD account to cover losses and maintained quality information to manage these funds. GAO analyzed DOD budget rates and foreign currency disbursements for fiscal years 2009 through 2016, reviewed DOD financial reports, and interviewed DOD and service officials. What GAO Found The Department of Defense (DOD) revised its foreign currency budget rates in fiscal years 2014 through 2016, which resulted in budget rates in these years that were more closely aligned with rates published by the U.S. Treasury Department (Treasury). The revised budget rates decreased DOD's projected O&M and MILPERS funding needs and any potential gains and losses that would have occurred due to foreign currency fluctuations. DOD's use of revised budget rates decreased DOD's projected O&M and MILPERS funding needs and any potential gains and losses that would have occurred due to foreign currency fluctuations. DOD has taken some steps to reduce costs in selecting foreign currency rates to liquidate its obligations through disbursements, but has not fully explored additional opportunities to achieve savings. For example, DOD has not fully determined whether additional cost-saving opportunities exist because the services have not reviewed the rates used for foreign currency disbursements. DOD has used the FCFD account to cover losses that the services experienced due to foreign currency fluctuations in 6 of the 8 years GAO reviewed. However, DOD does not effectively manage the FCFD account balance based on projected losses or quality data. Transfers of unobligated balances from MILPERS and O&M accounts into the FCFD account have been made to replenish the account balance to the statutory limit of $970 million, without consideration of projected losses due to foreign currency fluctuations. Furthermore, DOD's financial reporting on foreign currency fluctuations for fiscal years 2009 through 2016 contains incomplete and inaccurate information. Without analyzing any realized or projected losses to determine what balance may be needed to meet the FCFD account's intended purpose, the account balance may be kept at a higher level than is necessary. What GAO Recommends GAO recommends that DOD conduct a review of the foreign currency rates used at disbursement to determine whether cost-saving opportunities exist by more consistently selecting cost-effective rates at disbursement. DOD partially concurred with GAO's recommendations, stating that it would benefit from guidance in the Financial Management Regulation that establishes the steps that should be taken for making such corrections. GAO continues to believe that DOD should take steps to improve the quality of the data.
gao_GAO-19-125: Why GAO Did This Study VA operates one of the largest health care delivery systems in the United States. In fiscal year 2018, the department spent about $1.1 billion to modernize its existing system, which is to replace the existing system with a new system, Cerner. GAO was asked to review VA's efforts to modernize its system. This report examines (1) the extent to which VA has defined VistA, (2) the costs to develop and sustain VistA, and (3) the actions VA has taken to transition from VistA to the Cerner system. GAO reviewed documents and interviewed VA officials. GAO also reviewed program documentation related to the Cerner system. What GAO Found The Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) has taken a number of actions to define the Veterans Health Information Systems and Technology Architecture (VistA), but additional work remains. Specifically, VA has documented descriptions of the system, including the components that comprise it. However, despite these existing sources, VA officials acknowledged that there is no comprehensive definition of the VistA system. Consequently, VA has completed a number of efforts to better define VistA and understand the environment in which it operates. For example, VA has conducted analyses to better understand the scope of VistA and identify capabilities that can be provided by the Cerner system. However, VA has not yet fully defined VistA, including, for example, identifying performance characteristics of the system and describing the environment in which it operates. VA identified total VistA costs of about $2.3 billion between 2015 and 2017, but could not sufficiently demonstrate the reliability of all data and omitted other costs from the total. The lack of sufficiently reliable and comprehensive costs indicates that the department is not positioned to accurately report the annual costs to develop and sustain VistA. VA has initiated a number of actions to prepare for the transition from VistA to the Cerner system. These actions include (1) taking steps to establish a program office reporting to senior agency management, (2) forming a governance structure, (3) conducting assessments at initial system deployment sites, (4) preparing program plans, and (5) setting an initial program baseline. These actions represent important initial steps to prepare for the transition to the new system. The program office is working to hire staff and establish a joint governance structure to coordinate with DOD on the departments' efforts to implement the Cerner system. What GAO Recommends GAO recommends that VA develop and implement a methodology for reliably identifying and reporting the total costs of VistA. VA concurred with GAO's recommendation.
gao_GAO-18-62: Why GAO Did This Study DHS is responsible for coordinating the nation's CI security and resilience. DHS is also responsible for coordinating the nation's CI security and resilience efforts. GAO was asked to review DHS's efforts to protect critical infrastructure. This report examines (1) DHS's efforts to assess risks to critical infrastructure and (2) how DHS uses CI risk information to inform strategic planning and guide outreach to owners and operators. GAO reviewed DHS documents and interviewed DHS officials and representatives from selected sectors. GAO also interviewed DHS officials and representatives from selected sector coordinating councils. What GAO Found The Department of Homeland Security (DHS) primarily assesses the three elements of risk—threat, vulnerability, and consequence—separately for individual critical infrastructure (CI) assets and sectors. According to DHS officials, these assessments help critical infrastructure owners and operators take actions to improve security and mitigate risks. However, according to selected sector coordinating council representatives from three selected sectors, timely and actionable threat assessment data is the most useful type of risk information. In limited circumstances, DHS generates risk assessments that collectively incorporate all three elements of risk which selected SCC representatives found of limited use for their sectors' infrastructure protection efforts due to the amount of time it takes to finalize the assessment data, the inclusion of risk scenarios that are not likely to occur, and the results not being applicable to individual assets. DHS uses CI risk information in multiple ways, including informing strategic planning and developing analytic products, and at the component level to guide its day-to-day owner and operator outreach and incident response. DHS is also facilitating risk-based cross-sector planning and information sharing through sector coordinating councils. What GAO Recommends GAO is not making any recommendations in this report. DHS provided technical comments, which GAO incorporated as appropriate.
gao_GAO-18-460T: Why GAO Did This Study The federal government plans to invest more than $96 billion for IT in fiscal year 2018. However, as GAO has previously reported, investments in federal IT too often result in failed projects that incur cost overruns and schedule slippages, while contributing little to the desired mission-related outcomes. In February 2015, GAO reported that, while progress had been made in improving the management of IT acquisitions and operations, significant work still remained to be completed. GAO was asked to testify on the status of federal IT acquisitions and operations. This statement addresses (1) the extent to which federal agencies have taken steps to improve the management of IT acquisitions and operations, and (2) the extent to which agencies have implemented key IT workforce planning activities. This statement is based on GAO's prior reports and testimonies on federal IT acquisitions and operations. GAO reviewed relevant laws and guidance, and interviewed officials from OMB and agencies. What GAO Found The federal government has taken steps to improve the management of information technology (IT) acquisitions and operations. However, agencies would be better positioned to realize billions in cost savings and additional management improvements, if they addressed the numerous recommendations GAO has made aimed at improving data center consolidation, increasing transparency via OMB's IT Dashboard, implementing incremental development, managing software licenses, reviewing IT acquisitions, implementing key IT workforce activities, and addressing aging legacy systems. Specifically, GAO reported that agencies have made progress in consolidating data centers, but need to take action to achieve planned cost savings. For example, as of August 2016, 24 agencies had closed 4,388, and had plans to close a total of 5,597 data centers through fiscal year 2019. Further, 23 agencies reported about $656 million collectively in planned savings for fiscal years 2016 through 2018. This is about $3.3 billion less than the estimated $4.0 billion in planned savings for fiscal years 2016 through 2018. To facilitate transparency across the government in acquiring and managing IT investments, OMB established a public website—the IT Dashboard—to provide detailed information on major investments at 26 agencies, including ratings of their performance against cost and schedule targets. GAO has made 47 recommendations to OMB and federal agencies to help improve the accuracy and reliability of the information on the Dashboard and to increase its availability. Most agencies agreed with GAO's recommendations or had no comments. As of March 2018, 19 recommendations remained open. GAO also reported that agencies needed to increase their use of incremental development practices. For example, GAO reported that agencies needed to improve their certification of incremental development. GAO recommended that OMB clarify its guidance on incremental development and that the selected agencies update their associated policies to comply with OMB's revised guidance (once made available), and consider the factors identified in GAO's report when doing so. GAO also reported that agencies needed to improve their management of software licenses. GAO recommended that OMB clarify its guidance on incremental development and that the selected agencies update their associated policies to comply with OMB's revised guidance (once made available), and consider the factors identified in GAO's report when doing so. As of March 2018, 34 of the recommendations remained open. GAO also reported that most of the Chief Information Officers (CIO) at 22 selected agencies were not adequately involved in reviewing billions of dollars of IT acquisitions. For example, most of the 22 selected agencies did not identify all of their IT contracts. Further, 14 of the 22 selected agencies did not fully satisfy OMB's requirement that the CIO review and approve IT acquisition plans or strategies. Further, only 11 of 96 randomly selected IT contracts at 10 agencies that GAO evaluated were CIO-reviewed and approved as required by OMB's guidance. The 85 IT contracts not reviewed had a total possible value of approximately $23.8 billion. Until agencies ensure that CIOs are able to review and approve all IT acquisitions, CIOs will continue to have limited visibility and input into their agencies' planned IT expenditures and will not be able to use the increased authority that FITARA's contract approval provision is intended to provide. What GAO Recommends GAO has made numerous recommendations to OMB and federal agencies to improve the management of IT acquisitions and operations. Most agencies agreed with GAO's recommendations or had no comments. As of March 2018, 19 recommendations remained open.
gao_GAO-18-69: Why GAO Did This Study The technology sector is a growing segment of the U.S. economy. In 2015, the estimated number of workers in the technology workforce—people who worked in mathematics, computing, or engineering occupations—increased at a higher rate (24 percent) than the estimated number of workers in the general workforce (9 percent). GAO was asked to review the representation of women and certain minority groups in the technology workforce. This report examines (1) the demographic trends in the technology workforce over the past 10 years, and (2) the efforts by the U.S. Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) and the Department of Labor's Office of Federal Contract Compliance Programs (OFCCP) to oversee technology companies and technology contractors' compliance with equal employment opportunity and affirmative action requirements. GAO analyzed data from EEOC and OFCCP, and interviewed EEOC and OFCCP officials. GAO also reviewed relevant federal laws and regulations, EEOC and OFCCP policies, and OFCCP data. What GAO Found From 2005 to 2015, the estimated number of workers in the technology workforce—people who worked in mathematics, computing, or engineering occupations—increased at a higher rate (24 percent) than the estimated number of workers in the general workforce (9 percent). In 2015, the technology workforce comprised an estimated 7.5 million workers, an increase of slightly over 1.4 million workers since 2005. Women and certain minority groups continued to be less represented in the technology workforce and at companies in the technology sector than outside it. Several factors may contribute to the lower representation of women and certain minority groups in the technology workforce and at companies in the technology sector, based on research and interviews with researchers and representatives from workforce and industry organizations and technology companies. These include the lower diversity of degree earners in technology-related fields, and company-based factors such as hiring practices and retention of women and underrepresented minorities. EEOC and OFCCP have taken steps to oversee equal employment opportunity and affirmative action requirements, but face limitations. EEOC primarily oversees compliance with equal employment opportunity requirements by investigating workers' individual charges of employment discrimination filed against companies. EEOC has publicly acknowledged the low levels of diversity in the technology sector. However, GAO was unable to identify a specific number of charges received by EEOC against companies in industries that are part of this sector because EEOC does not require investigators to record the industry of the charged company. EEOC officials said they believe they have received far fewer charges against technology companies than they would have expected given the public attention to the issue of diversity in the technology sector. EEOC has taken some steps to address diversity in the technology sector, including research and outreach efforts. However, GAO found that EEOC cannot analyze charge data by industry to help identify investigation and outreach priorities, in contradiction to EEOC strategic planning documents and EEOC Inspector General reports, which have emphasized the importance of doing so. By not requiring an industry code in its investigations data, EEOC cannot analyze charge data by industry to help identify investigation and outreach priorities, in contradiction to EEOC strategic planning documents and EEOC Inspector General reports, which have emphasized the importance of doing so. Without analyzing its data on charges across industries, EEOC's ability to proactively identify priorities for its outreach and enforcement resource use is limited. OFCCP faces challenges that may hinder the agency's oversight of technology companies. Specifically, OFCCP reported facing delays in receiving information from federal contractors, including technology companies, but has not yet evaluated whether its own policies and practices also impede its efforts to hold federal technology contractors responsible for the legal requirements to take affirmative action and not discriminate against protected groups. In addition, OFCCP regulations do not require contractors to disaggregate demographic data for the purpose of establishing placement goals for hiring, which may hinder contractors' efforts to implement effective affirmative action programs. Without assessing its current approach to its establishment-based reviews and identifying all relevant subcontractors, OFCCP does not have reasonable assurance that its approach can identify discrimination occurring within the companies it oversees and may be missing opportunities to identify more effective practices or adjust its methods to external changes. What GAO Recommends GAO recommends that EEOC develop a timeline to complete its planned effort to clean the EEOC's data for a one-year period and add missing industry code data. EEOC neither agreed nor disagreed with GAO's recommendations, but stated that it was taking some actions to enhance these data.
gao_GAO-18-534: Why GAO Did This Study The Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS) has implemented several antifraud efforts that affect durable medical equipment (DME) suppliers. CMS began phasing in the competitive bidding program (CBP) in 2008, and the agency began phasing in the non-bid areas in 2016. GAO was asked to review the implementation of adjusted rates in non-bid areas. This report examines (1) the extent to which payment rate reductions have affected beneficiary access to DME items and (2) the extent to which CMS has monitored beneficiary access to DME items since the implementation of adjusted rates. GAO reviewed CMS data on DME suppliers and beneficiary utilization of rate-adjusted items, and interviewed CMS officials and representatives from DME industry trade organizations. What GAO Found The payment rate reductions for durable medical equipment (DME) items in non-bid areas were generally significant. The average unweighted percentage reduction across the top product category items combined—measured by calculating the percentage change between the 2015 non-adjusted and the 2017 fully adjusted rates—was 46 percent. However, payment rate reductions varied by DME product category and by individual item within product categories. For example, the average payment rate reduction for the top items in the oxygen product category—the category that accounted for the highest percentage of total expenditures in 2016—was 39 percent. The number of suppliers furnishing any of the 393 rate-adjusted items to beneficiaries in non-bid areas in 2016—the first year that CMS adjusted payment rates in non-bid areas—decreased 8 percent compared to 2015. This continued a trend of annual decreases going back to at least 2011—the first year CMS began implementing the CBP in nine areas. The largest percentage decrease in suppliers, 13 percent, occurred in 2014 (the year after the CBP was expanded to an additional 100 areas), followed by 9 and 8 percent decreases in 2015 and 2016, respectively. Because 2016 was the most recent year of complete Medicare claims data available at the time of GAO's study, GAO could only review data for the first year that adjusted rates were in effect in non-bid areas and could not determine if these trends continued in 2017. Available evidence indicates no widespread access issues in the first year of reduced Medicare payment rates in non-bid areas. CMS has reported that data from its health status monitoring tool indicate the reduced payment rates have not resulted in changes in access to DME items or health outcomes in non-bid areas in 2016 as compared to 2015. CMS officials told GAO they have not made significant revisions to the tool's underlying methodologies but did create a separate workbook specially tailored to the implementation of the adjusted rates in non-bid areas that includes additional capabilities, such as review of assignment rates. GAO previously conducted an analysis of CMS's methodologies and scoring algorithm that focused on evaluating health outcome trends in CBP areas and found them to be generally sound. CMS officials told GAO they have not made significant revisions to the tool's underlying methodologies but did create a separate workbook specially tailored to the implementation of the adjusted rates in non-bid areas that includes additional capabilities, such as review of assignment rates. GAO interviewed officials from three of CMS's regional offices, who also reported there has not been an increase in the number of DME-related inquiries since adjusted rates went into effect. GAO interviewed representatives from one state hospital association, three beneficiary advocacy groups, and four DME industry trade organizations who provided anecdotal examples of varying degrees of beneficiary access issues in non-bid areas. For example, representatives from one state hospital association told GAO some hospital case managers in non-bid areas have reported difficulty in locating suppliers to provide DME items such as wheelchairs or walkers, but these issues are not widespread. A representative of another beneficiary advocacy group that focuses on a condition in which beneficiaries would typically use oxygen items with adjusted rates told GAO that without a real research instrument, it is difficult to determine if the increase in complaints that her group began receiving in 2016 from beneficiaries in non-bid areas is directly related to the adjusted rates, but she said such reports are anecdotal and she does not think that issues reported are widespread or have created significant hardship. GAO also reviewed several publicly released studies that assessed the effect of the implementation of adjusted rates on beneficiaries, DME suppliers, and others. GAO found these studies did not provide persuasive evidence of substantial effects, primarily because of methodological issues with how the participants in the studies were recruited. Because there is only limited experience on changes in the number of DME suppliers and utilization of DME based on the first year that adjusted rates have been in effect, some effects may take longer to appear, and it is possible that trends could differ in 2017
gao_GAO-18-564: Why GAO Did This Study The Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS) oversees the expenditures reported by states on the CMS-64, which captures expenditure data for different aspects of states' Medicaid programs. CMS is required to review these expenditures quarterly. GAO was asked to review CMS's oversight of state-reported expenditures. This report examines (1) how CMS ensures that state-reported expenditures are supported and allowable and (2) the financial impact of CMS's expenditure reviews. GAO reviewed CMS documents and interviewed CMS officials. GAO also reviewed CMS's procedures for reviewing state-reported expenditures. GAO also interviewed CMS officials in headquarters and 10 regional offices selected based on the number of Medicaid expenditures reported by states. What GAO Found CMS uses a variety of processes to assure that state-reported expenditures are supported and allowable, but weaknesses limit its ability to effectively target risk. CMS uses a variety of processes to review state-reported expenditures, including quarterly reviews and financial management reviews. GAO found that CMS was identifying errors and compliance issues using both review methods, but weaknesses in how CMS targets its oversight resources to address risks. For example, GAO found that CMS has allocated similar staff resources to states with differing levels of risk. For example, the staff resources dedicated to reviewing California's expenditures—ranking first nationally in expenditures and constituting 15 percent of all federal Medicaid expenditures—are comparable to significantly smaller states in other regions, despite California's history of reporting challenges and its inability to provide electronic records, which requires on-site review. GAO also found that CMS cancelled the financial management review (FMR) requirement for regional offices in 17 out of 51 instances in the last 5 years when faced with resource constraints. GAO also found that CMS's reviewers in the selected regional offices did not consistently perform variance analyses—which compare changes in expenditures from the quarter under review to the previous quarter—of higher matched expenditures during quarterly reviews. Further, the sampling procedures used to examine Medicaid expansion expenditures did not account for varying risks across states. For example, GAO found that the sampling methodology did not account for risk factors like program size or vulnerabilities in state eligibility-determination processes and systems. As a result of the inconsistency in reviews and a sampling methodology that does not consider program risk, errors may be going undetected, resulting in CMS providing federal funds at higher federal matching rates than is allowable. In addition, CMS could be missing opportunities to identify any systemic issues that may contribute to such errors. What GAO Recommends GAO recommends that CMS complete a comprehensive, national risk assessment and take steps, as needed, to assure that resources are adequate and allocated commensurate with risk. HHS concurred with all three recommendations.

gao_GAO-18-386: Why GAO Did This Study HIPAA requires that patients have the right to access their medical records. HIPAA also requires that HIPAA-covered entities provide individuals with access to their medical records. GAO was asked to review HIPAA's implementation. This report examines (1) the fees for accessing medical records for patients and third parties, (2) the challenges patients face accessing medical records, and (3) the extent to which HHS enforces patients' right of access to their medical records. GAO reviewed HIPAA and HHS guidance, and interviewed stakeholders from ROI vendors, provider representatives, and patient advocates. GAO also interviewed HHS officials and other stakeholders. What GAO Found Available information suggests that the allowable fees for accessing medical records vary by type of request—that is, whether a patient or third party is making the request—and by state. Federal laws establish limits on the fees that may be charged for two of the three types of requests for medical records: (1) patient requests, when patients request access to their medical records, and (2) patient-directed requests, when patients request that their records be sent to another person or entity, such as another provider. HIPAA does not establish limits on fees for third-party requests. For patient and patient-directed requests, providers may charge a “reasonable, cost-based fee” under HIPAA's implementing regulations. In contrast with patient and patient-directed requests, the fees for third-party requests are not limited by HIPAA's reasonable, cost-based standard for access requests and are instead governed by state laws, regulations, or other requirements. For example, states can vary as to whether they establish per-page copy fees, allow providers to charge a flat fee, or charge different fees based on the type of media requested (e.g., electronic copies, X-rays, microfilm, paper, etc.). ROI vendors and other stakeholders GAO interviewed identified challenges patients face accessing medical records, such as high fees. Provider representatives described challenges providers face, including allocating staff time and other resources to respond to requests for medical records. To enforce patients' right of access under HIPAA's Privacy Rule, the HHS Office of Compliance Review (OCR) undertakes four types of efforts. OCR (1) investigates complaints it receives from patients and others regarding access to patient medical records, (2) audits a sample of providers to determine the extent to which their policies and procedures are compliant with HIPAA, (3) reports to Congress on compliance with HIPAA, and (4) educates patients and providers about patients' rights to access their medical records. gao_GAO-18-30: Why GAO Did This Study FEMA's Public Assistance (PA) program provides funds to states and localities to rebuild and restore damaged public infrastructure. FEMA's new delivery model for PA grants is designed to address persistent workforce management challenges, such as identifying the number of staff needed to support the new delivery model. GAO was asked to review FEMA's new delivery model. This report examines (1) the extent to which FEMA designed the new delivery model to address workforce management challenges, and (2) the extent to which FEMA implemented key IT management controls for its new information system. GAO reviewed FEMA's new delivery model and other documents, and interviewed FEMA officials and stakeholders. What GAO Found The Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) designed the new Public Assistance (PA) delivery model to address persistent workforce management challenges related to identifying the required number of staff and needed skills and training, among other things, to improve the efficiency and effectiveness of the PA preaward process. gao_GAO-18-409: Why GAO Did This Study The U.S. energy industry relies on pipelines to transport natural gas from production to end users. These pipelines transport natural gas from wells to processing facilities, which in turn refine it and send it to transmission pipelines. The Pipeline Safety -Safety of Gas Gathering Pipelines rulemaking, if approved, will provide PHMSA with more data on gas gathering pipeline infrastructure and incident data. GAO was asked to review the need to odorize gas in pipelines. This report examines (1) the advantages and disadvantages of odorizing gas in pipelines, (2) the views of federal and state pipeline safety officials and industry stakeholders on the need to modify federal regulations for odorizing gas in pipelines, and (3) the views of state pipeline safety officials and industry stakeholders on the need to odorize gas in transmission pipelines. GAO reviewed federal regulations and interviewed federal and state pipeline safety officials and industry stakeholders. GAO also surveyed state pipeline safety officials and a nongeneralizable sample of 49 state pipeline safety officials. What GAO Found Officials and stakeholders GAO interviewed and the state pipeline safety officials GAO surveyed said that the advantage of using sulfur-based odorants to odorize combustible gas transported by pipeline is public safety. Sulfur-based odorants have a low-odor threshold, so are easily detected at low concentrations. With a smell similar to that of rotten eggs, this odor is particularly advantageous when used in distribution pipelines that are located in areas where people congregate (e.g., homes, businesses and hospitals). If individuals smell an odorant, they can call emergency services and alert those nearby of a potential gas leak, possibly helping to prevent an explosion that could result in the loss of life and property. The most common disadvantage of sulfur-based odorants cited by officials and stakeholders GAO contacted is the need to remove the odorant for some industrial processes. Officials from both federal safety regulatory agencies GAO interviewed and approximately half of state pipeline safety officials surveyed said that sulfur-based odorants can cause an adverse chemical reaction during processing for some industries. However, because most transmission pipelines are in less populated areas and not odorized, many manufacturers currently receive unodorized gas from transmission pipelines and do not need to remove odorant. Officials and stakeholders GAO interviewed had mixed views on the need to modify federal regulations for odorizing gas in distribution pipelines. Many officials and stakeholders said that federal requirements to odorize all gas in distribution pipelines are sufficient as written and do not need to be modified. However, requiring all pipelines to be odorized at the federal level would have to be consistent with federal pipeline safety regulations. According to the safety regulations, a risk assessment, including an assessment of the benefits and costs of proposed regulatory standards, is required to be considered in any decision on whether to impose a new safety standard. According to PHMSA officials, they do not have the data to report on any incidents on gathering pipelines where odorant may have made a difference. Moreover, PHMSA officials stated that they do not have the data to formulate an educated opinion or viewpoint as to the need to odorize gathering pipelines. To address this lack of data, the Pipeline Safety -Safety of Gas Gathering Pipelines rulemaking, if approved, will provide PHMSA with more data on gas gathering pipeline infrastructure and incident data. According to PHMSA officials, the data collected will inform PHMSA on the best path forward regarding further regulation of gas gathering pipelines, including the need for odorization. Officials, stakeholders and survey respondents generally disagreed about the need to odorize all transmission pipelines. Officials from the National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB) as well as about half of the stakeholders GAO contacted said the current regulations for odorizing gas in certain transmission pipelines in populated areas were sufficient. Additionally, NTSB officials said they were not aware of incidents where odorants in a transmission pipeline would have alerted the public in time to prevent the incident. These officials and stakeholders generally said that odorizing gas in transmission pipelines is not an effective means of reducing the risk of an incident. For example, one stakeholder said that at the typically high pressure at which most transmission pipelines operate, even a relatively small hole in the pipeline would cause a rupture that would excavate the earth around it so people would hear and see the evidence of the leak. Some experts also said that odorizing all gas transported in the transmission pipeline system would require tens of thousands of odorization facilities.
