gao_GAO-18-20: Why GAO Did This Study IRS has a role in preventing and detecting identity theft refund fraud. IRS's ISAC is intended to improve collaboration and information sharing among IRS, states, and industry partners. GAO was asked to review IRS's efforts to prevent and detect identity theft refund fraud. This report (1) describes actions Security Summit partners are taking to implement an ISAC and a Rapid Response Team (RRT); (2) evaluates the extent to which the ISAC pilot design aligns with leading practices; and (3) identifies actions, if any, that IRS could take to improve the ISAC pilot. GAO reviewed IRS documents and interviewed IRS, state, and industry officials. What GAO Found The Internal Revenue Service (IRS) implemented the Information Sharing and Analysis Center (ISAC) in 2017 to facilitate information sharing among IRS, state, and industry partners—subject to disclosure prohibitions—by launching an online platform, establishing a governance structure, and recruiting members. IRS and state officials and industry representatives attributed increased trust and improved relationships to IRS's efforts in recent years. Additionally, IRS coordinated with state and industry partners to establish the RRT in 2016, which has been initiated once thus far in 2017. IRS has taken actions that partially align with five leading practices for effective pilot design. For example, IRS has taken steps to communicate with stakeholders before, during, and after forming the ISAC. However, IRS has not translated its objectives into specific, researchable questions that articulate what will be assessed. IRS has not developed criteria for assessing whether the ISAC objectives have been met. Without a measurable evaluation criteria that provide evidence that the ISAC objectives have been met, IRS, its partners, and Congress will have difficulty determining the ISAC's effectiveness and whether to proceed with full-scale implementation. IRS took actions to improve the ISAC pilot, including waiving the requirement for states to contribute data. However, IRS does not have an outreach plan to increase membership or inform states about the ISAC's benefits. IRS waived the data contribution requirement for the first year and one state contributed data to the ISAC in the 2017 filing season. However, as of October 2017, 5 states had contributed data and 8 states had submitted 29 alerts. IRS officials said the agency is considering options to allow it to participate more fully in the ISAC. IRS has not developed an outreach plan to expand membership to additional states, non-Security Summit members of industry, and financial institutions. What GAO Recommends GAO recommends that IRS (1) establish criteria for assessing whether the ISAC objectives have been met before making decisions about its scalability and whether, how, and when to proceed to full implementation; and (2) develop a data analysis plan that identifies data sources and criteria necessary for effectively evaluating the ISAC. IRS agreed with both recommendations.
gao_GAO-18-693T: Why GAO Did This Study The federal government is responsible for approving permits to construct and operate oil and gas infrastructure. Permitting is a key component of the permitting process. The Department of the Interior (Interior) is responsible for approving permits to construct and operate oil and gas infrastructure. The Department of Energy (DOE) is responsible for approving permits to construct and operate offshore oil and gas drilling facilities. This testimony discusses factors that affect the timeliness and efficiencies of federal permitting reviews. This statement is based on GAO's past reports on federal energy infrastructure permitting. For the purposes of this statement, GAO has categorized the factors into five broad categories: 1) coordination and communication, 2) human capital, 3) collecting and analyzing accurate milestone information, 4) incomplete applications, and 5) significant policy changes. This statement is based on GAO's prior work on federal energy infrastructure permitting. For the purposes of this statement, GAO has categorized the factors into five broad categories: 1) coordination and communication, 2) human capital, 3) collecting and analyzing accurate milestone information, 4) incomplete applications, and 5) significant policy changes. What GAO Found GAO's past reports have identified a range of factors that can affect permitting timeliness and efficiency. For example, effective coordination and communication between agencies and applicants is a critical factor in an efficient and timely permitting process. Standards for internal control in the federal government call for management to externally communicate the necessary quality information to achieve the entity's objectives, including by communicating with and obtaining quality information from external parties. GAO found that better coordination between agencies and applicants could result in more efficient permitting. For example, in GAO's February 2013 review of natural gas pipeline permitting, GAO reported that virtually all applications for pipeline projects require some level of coordination with one or more federal agencies, as well as others, to satisfy requirements for environmental review. GAO has reported on coordination practices that agencies use to streamline the permitting process, including the following. Designating a lead coordinating agency. Establishing coordinating agreements among agencies can streamline the permitting process and reduce time required by routine processes. Using mechanisms to expedite routine or less environmentally risky reviews. Human capital. Agency and industry representatives cited human capital factors as affecting the length of permitting reviews. Such factors include having a sufficient number of experts to review applications. For example, in June 2015 and in November 2016, GAO reported concerns associated with the Bureau of Indian Affairs' long-standing workforce challenges, such as inadequate staff resources and staff at some offices without the skills needed to effectively review energy-related documents. In November 2016, GAO recommended that Interior direct BIA to incorporate effective workforce planning standards by assessing critical skills and competencies needed to fulfill BIA's responsibilities related to energy development. Collecting and analyzing accurate milestone information. Agencies often do not track when permitting milestones are achieved, such as the date a project application is submitted or receives final agency approval to determine if they are achieving planned or expected results. In addition, GAO's work has shown that agencies often do not collect accurate information, which prevents them from analyzing their processes in order to improve and streamline them. Incomplete applications. In a 2014 budget document, BLM reported that—due to personnel turnover in the oil and gas industry—operators were submitting inconsistent and incomplete applications for permits to drill, which was delaying the approval of permits. In a February 2013 report, officials from Army Corps of Engineers district offices said that incomplete applications may delay their review because applicants are given time to revise their application information. Deficiencies within agency IT systems may also result in incomplete applications. Changes in U.S. policy unrelated to permitting are a factor that can also affect the duration of federal permitting reviews. For example, in September 2014, GAO reported that the Department of Energy did not approve liquefied natural gas exports to countries without free-trade agreements with the United States for a period of 16 months. GAO found that the Department stopped approving applications while it conducted a study of the effect of liquefied natural gas exports on the U.S. economy and the national interest. In a July 2012 report, GAO found that after the new safety requirements went into effect, review times for offshore oil and gas drilling permits increased, as did the number of times that Interior returned a permit to an operator. What GAO Recommends GAO has made recommendations to improve the timeliness and efficiency of federal energy infrastructure permitting reviews. GAO has made recommendations to improve the timeliness and efficiency of federal energy infrastructure permitting reviews.
gao_GAO-19-90: Why GAO Did This Study The Energy Employees Occupational Illness Compensation Program Act of 2000 (EEOICPA) provides compensation to employees of Energy under Part B and Part E, and provides for the establishment of a Advisory Board on Toxic Substances and Worker Health. The Advisory Board is tasked with providing technical advice to the Secretary of Labor regarding Part E. GAO was asked to review the reopening process. This report examines (1) the number of compensation claims for illnesses resulting from exposure to toxins that were reopened by DOL and their final outcome; (2) the extent to which an advisory board on toxic substances and worker health reviewed and advised DOL on the scientific soundness of DOL's database on toxins and their potential links to occupational diseases; and (3) DOL's response. GAO reviewed relevant federal laws, regulations, and guidance; analyzed DOL data on reopened claims from 2012 through 2017; reviewed DOL program documents; and interviewed DOL officials. What GAO Found The Department of Labor (DOL) reopened more than 7,000 claims filed by contracted Energy employees for exposure to toxins at Energy worksites and approved 69 percent of them. The remaining claims were denied (13 percent), still awaiting a final decision (2 percent), closed (2 percent), deferred (less than 1 percent) or had some other outcome (15 percent). Regardless of a claim's previous status of approved or denied, outcomes after reopening varied by who initiated the reopening. DOL initiated most of the reopenings (80 percent) itself, with fewer reopenings initiated by claimants. Regardless of a claim's previous status of approved or denied, outcomes after reopening varied by who initiated the reopening. DOL officials provided data showing that most of the claims reopened from 2012 through 2017 that were subsequently denied compensation had common reasons, including insufficient medical evidence, ineligible survivors, or maximum benefits already met. DOL officials said that some claimants may have been denied as a result of claimants not understanding the evidence required for a reopening. These officials also said that claimants experience ongoing challenges at different stages of the adjudication process, including reopening, with regard to evidence required to support their claim. In its 2016 annual report to Congress, the Office of the Ombudsman found that DOL's written communication with claimants requesting additional evidence or informing them of the final decision did not clearly explain what specific evidence was needed or why previously submitted evidence was deemed insufficient. In its 2016 annual report, while the Office of the Ombudsman acknowledged DOL's efforts to ensure that decisions on claims are adequately reasoned and documented, and found that some recently issued decisions show improvement, it also found some variation in decision quality among claims examiners. Furthermore, consistent with its 2015 report, it also found that some claimants encounter challenges during the reopening process with written communication that is not clear on the evidence needed to reopen a claim. DOL officials said they have taken a number of steps to assist claimants and improve communication with them, including conducting workshops for claimants' Authorized Representatives covering such topics as the evidence needed to support a claim and how to request a reopening. DOL officials said they recently hired a training analyst to update claimant resources posted to the website and to develop additional training for claims examiners. An assessment of DOL's training which considers claimant concerns could help DOL better understand why some claimants remain confused about the reopening process and do not submit evidence key to supporting their claim. Until then, the agency will be unable to determine whether its training has resulted in improving communication with claimants and to target future training resources effectively. The Advisory Board in 2016 and 2018 recommended DOL incorporate additional, peer-reviewed data sources on the links between toxic substances and illnesses catalogued in the Site Exposure Matrices (SEM), but while DOL previously agreed that doing so would be useful, it has not yet added all the sources recommended by the Advisory Board. According to Advisory Board members, incorporating these additional sources would enhance the SEM by making it more comprehensive and scientifically sound. gao_GAO-19-116: Why GAO Did This Study The United States has made a commitment to building Afghanistan's security and governance in order to prevent the country from once again becoming a sanctuary for terrorists. To achieve its security objectives, the United States currently has two missions in Afghanistan: a counterterrorism mission that it leads and the NATO-led Resolute Support train, advise, and assist mission, which it participates in with other coalition nations. The objective of Resolute Support is to establish self-sustaining Afghan security ministries and forces that work together to maintain security in Afghanistan. The National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2017 included a provision for GAO to review the ANDSF. This report examines (1) the extent to which DOD considers and meets their needs when identifying equipment requirements, (2) what has been reported about and the extent to which DOD has information about the ANDSF's ability to operate and maintain U.S.-purchased equipment, and (3) the extent to which DOD has information about the ANDSF's ability to operate and maintain U.S.-purchased equipment. GAO reviewed DOD and NATO reports and documents, and interviewed DOD and NATO officials. What GAO Found The Department of Defense (DOD) has reported that the Afghan National Defense and Security Forces (ANDSF) have improved some capabilities related to the functional areas and capability pillars described above, but face several capability gaps that leave them reliant on coalition assistance, according to publicly available DOD reporting. DOD has reported that the Afghan ministries have improved in operational planning, strategic communications, and coordination between the Ministry of Interior and Ministry of Defense at the national level. However, DOD has reported that the ANDSF continues to need support in several key areas, such as force management; logistics; and analyzing and integrating intelligence, surveillance, and reconnaissance information. DOD and the ANDSF have begun implementing plans and initiatives that aim to strengthen and increase the size of the specialized forces. DOD collects some reliable information about the operation and maintenance abilities of ANDSF specialized forces, in part because advisors are embedded at the tactical level with the specialized forces, according to DOD officials. Specifically, U.S. and coalition forces advise specialized forces at the tactical level under Resolute Support because building ANDSF aviation and special operations abilities are considered particularly important, according to DOD reporting. DOD officials told GAO that since U.S. and coalition forces are embedded at the tactical level for specialized forces, they can monitor, assess, and report on tactical abilities, including the ability to operate and maintain equipment. GAO's analysis of information provided by DOD about the ANDSF's ability to operate and maintain MD-530 helicopters illustrates that DOD has some detailed information about specialized forces. However, DOD has limited reliable information on the conventional forces' ability to operate and maintain equipment. For example, DOD officials could not say how well ANDSF personnel on the front lines operate radios in the field and had only limited information on the ANDSF's ability to maintain radios. Federal internal control standards state that U.S. agencies should obtain and process reliable information to evaluate performance in achieving key objectives and assessing risks. Without reliable information on the conventional forces' ability to operate and maintain U.S.-purchased equipment, DOD may be unable to fully evaluate the success of its train, advise, assist, and equip efforts in Afghanistan. What GAO Recommends GAO recommends that DOD develop and, as appropriate, implement options for collecting reliable information on the ANDSF conventional forces' ability to operate and maintain U.S.-purchased equipment. DOD concurred with the recommendation.
gao_GAO-18-11: Why GAO Did This Study Border Patrol uses a network of roads to conduct its operations, including a network of roads owned by states, counties, cities, and tribal entities. GAO reviewed relevant laws, regulations, and policies; analyzed CBP documents; and interviewed CBP and Border Patrol officials. gao_GAO-19-201: Why GAO Did This Study CBSI was created in 2010 to increase citizen safety and security in the Caribbean region. CBSI aims to reduce illicit trafficking, improve public safety and security, and promote social justice. GAO was asked to review CBSI. This report (1) provides information on U.S. funding for CBSI activities, (2) examines the extent to which State and USAID have implemented a planning and reporting process for CBSI, and (3) examines the extent to which State and USAID have established objectives and performance indicators to measure the progress of CBSI activities. GAO analyzed U.S. funding data for fiscal years 2010 through 2018, reviewed relevant planning and reporting documents, and interviewed State and USAID officials in Washington, D.C. and in Barbados, the Dominican Republic, and Jamaica. What GAO Found From fiscal years 2010 through 2018, U.S. agencies have allocated more than $560 million in funding for the Caribbean Basin Security Initiative (CBSI). Since fiscal year 2012, annual allocations have remained relatively constant, ranging between $56.6 million and $63.5 million. Of the 13 CBSI partner countries, U.S. agencies have provided the most CBSI funding to the Dominican Republic, Jamaica, and the countries covered by the Eastern Caribbean embassy. State and USAID disbursed funds to support activities in partner countries that improve law enforcement and maritime interdiction capabilities, support activities to train and otherwise improve the capabilities of national security institutions, prevent crime and violence, and deter and detect border criminal activity. These activities are generally aligned with the three pillars of CBSI. The United States and Caribbean countries meet periodically to set strategic goals and to designate high-level priorities for the subsequent year, and U.S. agencies individually plan and report on CBSI activities on a country-specific basis through a variety of reporting mechanisms. However, State has not established an initiative-wide mechanism for planning and reporting on CBSI activities and the U.S. government cannot assess initiative-wide progress. State and USAID set strategic goals and priorities with CBSI partner countries and plan for and report on CBSI activities within each agency or bureau. However, State has not established a CBSI-wide planning and reporting mechanism that links CBSI activities to overall goals or specifies a means for assessing initiative-wide progress through articulation of desired results, performance indicators, and a monitoring and evaluation plan. Without such a mechanism, the ability to demonstrate the efficacy of the initiative, and to emphasize positive results that have been achieved, is limited. State and USAID have established objectives and performance indicators for selected CBSI activities that GAO reviewed and have been measuring and reporting on progress for those activities. Within State, INL and implementing partners have established objectives and performance indicators for all of the activities that GAO reviewed, and INL and the Department of Defense (DOD) receive quarterly monitoring reports containing performance information on the Technical Assistance Field Team program. In response to identified weaknesses in its program monitoring, INL is taking steps to improve program monitoring for its Western Hemisphere programs, which include CBSI activities. What GAO Recommends GAO recommends that State, in consultation with USAID and other stakeholders as appropriate, create an initiative-wide planning and reporting mechanism for CBSI that includes the ability to monitor, evaluate, and report the results of their collaborative efforts. State concurred with GAO's recommendations.
gao_GAO-18-64: Why GAO Did This Study The financial services industry includes a variety of industries, including credit, financial services, and insurance. GAO has previously reported on the challenges faced by the financial services industry in promoting and retaining a diverse workforce. GAO was asked to examine (1) trends in management-level diversity in the financial services industry, (2) trends in diversity among potential talent pools, and (3) challenges financial services firms identified in trying to increase workforce diversity and practices firms used to increase workforce diversity. GAO analyzed 2007–2015 workforce data from the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) and compared the representation of racial/ethnic minorities and women in management positions across all three sectors from 2007 through 2015. GAO also interviewed representatives from 13 financial services firms that were actively involved in workforce diversity efforts, representatives of 11 organizations that advocate for the financial services industry, and representatives of 4 individuals who formerly worked for large financial services firms. What GAO Found Representation of minorities at the overall management level increased by 3.7 percentage points from 2007 through 2015 and their representation among senior-level managers increased by 1.7 percentage points during this time. Women's representation at the overall management level has remained at about 45 percent from 2007 through 2015. Among the various sectors of the financial services industry, the insurance sector has consistently had the highest proportion of women in management positions while the banks and other credit institutions sector has consistently had the highest proportion of racial/ethnic minorities in management. As the size of financial services firms increase (by number of employees), the representation of minorities in overall management increased and the representation of women in overall management was generally the same. Additionally, management-level diversity in the financial services sector has similarities and differences compared to other sectors. Representatives from financial services firms and other stakeholders described many of the same challenges in recruiting and retaining women and racial/ethnic minorities as GAO has previously reported, including negative perceptions of the financial services industry that might discourage potential candidates. Practices that financial services firms use to address these challenges include broadening recruitment efforts, establishing relationships with student groups and professional organizations, and providing training on unconscious bias. Representatives from all of the financial services firms GAO met with agreed on the importance of analyzing employee data to assess diversity of their workforce and identify trends that may need to be addressed. However, representatives and other stakeholders differed on the benefits of making firm-level information on employee diversity publicly available.
gao_GAO-19-221: Why GAO Did This Study The federal government collects hundreds of billions of dollars from fees, fines, and penalties each year that fund a wide variety of programs, but Congress and the American public do not have government-wide data on these collections that would provide increased transparency and facilitate oversight. GAO was asked to review government-wide reporting of fees, fines, and penalties. This report examines (1) the extent to which government-wide data on collections of fees, fines, and penalties are publicly available and useful for the purpose of congressional oversight, and (2) the benefits and challenges to government-wide reporting of specific fees, fines, and penalties including data elements that facilitate congressional oversight. GAO reviewed government-wide data on collections of fees, fines, and penalties, and interviewed officials from OMB, Treasury, and external organizations with expertise in federal budget issues and data transparency. What GAO Found The Office of Management and Budget (OMB), the Department of the Treasury (Treasury), and agencies publicly report some data on collections of fees, fines, and penalties, but the data have significant limitations. OMB reports budgetary and financial data in various parts of the Budget of the U.S. Government, including Analytical Perspectives, the Budget Appendix, and the Public Budget Database. Treasury reports financial data in the Combined Statement. Each source provides information for a broader purpose than reporting on collections of fees, fines, and penalties. OMB staff said that OMB does not publicly report these data because the purpose of Analytical Perspectives is to develop or support the President's policies and more detailed tables may not be included if they are not considered necessary for that purpose. However, Analytical Perspectives also serves to provide other significant data that place the President's Budget in context and assist the public and policymakers in better understanding the budget proposals. Until OMB makes more disaggregated data on fees, fines, and penalties maintained in its OMB MAX database—such as collections by agency—publicly available, Congress has limited information on such collections to inform oversight and decision-making. OMB and Treasury do not consistently report data that would facilitate congressional oversight of fees, fines, and penalties. For example, OMB does not consistently report data on the amount collected annually, account balances, and whether the collection is a fee, fine, or penalty. According to OMB staff and officials from Treasury, the Congressional Research Service, and external organizations with expertise in federal budget issues and data transparency, there are two primary benefits to government-wide reporting of fee, fine, and penalty data: increased transparency and better information for congressional oversight and decision-making. Generally, all congressional staff GAO spoke with said making additional government-wide data on fees, fines, and penalties, such as those data elements described previously, without additional outreach to agencies, would be useful and increase transparency. While some congressional staff said such data elements are available through direct outreach to agencies, other congressional staff said they could not always obtain the information they wanted. For example, staff from a congressional committee said that one of the most critical data elements for the purpose of congressional oversight is information on agency reporting of obligations and expenditures because, in their view, currently many agencies do not adequately report this information and some agencies do not report this information at all. These data would provide Congress a more complete picture of individual agencies' activities and any potential overlap or duplication in multiple agencies' activities. Finally, publicly available government-wide data on collections could inform the public, specifically payers of fees, fines, and penalties, and facilitate their participation in public comment opportunities. For example, OMB staff said government-wide data could provide the public with clear, transparent information across agencies on fee collections and allow the public to analyze differences in fee programs among agencies. What GAO Recommends GAO recommends that OMB (1) make more disaggregated data on fees, fines, and penalties maintained in its OMB MAX database, (2) regularly review and update implementation of its criteria for designating accounts with fees, and (3) describe in the Public Budget Database User's Guide that budget authority is reported net of any offsetting collections, such as collections of fees, fines, and penalties. OMB and Treasury neither agreed nor disagreed with the recommendations.
gao_GAO-18-518: Why GAO Did This Study FSA administers the federal student aid program, which provides loans, grants, and work-study funds to students attending college or career school. FSA shares personally identifiable information (PII) with its non-school partners, such as loan servicers, guaranty agencies, and private collection agencies. GAO was asked to review FSA's oversight of the protection of PII. This report (1) describes the roles of FSA's non-school partners in the federal student financial aid program, including the types of personally identifiable information shared with them; and (2) assesses the extent to which FSA's policies and procedures for overseeing non-school partners' protection of federal student aid data align with federal requirements, federal guidance, and best practices. GAO reviewed FSA documents and interviewed FSA officials. What GAO Found The Office of Federal Student Aid (FSA) shares PII with its non-school partners to assist them in carrying out key aspects of the federal student financial aid program. These partners include FFEL lenders, Title IV loan servicers, guaranty agencies, and private collection agencies. FSA shares a large amount of PII that it collects from students and parents with its non-school partners. This is particularly significant in that FSA directly manages or oversees more than 203 million student loans made to approximately 43 million borrowers. FSA has established policies and procedures for overseeing its non-school partners' protection of the PII that it shares with the partners. These policies and procedures vary in the extent to which they address the key practices for overseeing the protection of PII. For example, FSA's policies and procedures for Title IV loan servicers and private collection agencies fully address three of the four key practices. For guaranty agencies, FSA's procedures require onsite assessments but do not require monitoring controls on an ongoing basis. Finally, for FFEL lenders, FSA has minimal oversight procedures. FSA established high-level requirements for FFEL lenders to protect student aid data, but it exercises minimal oversight to ensure implementation of security and privacy protections for these data. FSA did not fully specify risk-based security and privacy controls for FFEL lenders. Specifically, FSA's application for access to FSA data does not require lenders to implement a baseline set of risk-based security and privacy controls based on the impact level of the affected information and systems. FSA officials stated that they plan to add security and privacy requirements to the FFEL lender participation agreements as part of their next update during the 2018 revision cycle, but they did not specify what requirements would be included in these revised agreements. Until FSA establishes specific requirements for lenders' protection of data, it will lack assurance that information it shares is being protected in a manner consistent with FSA's determination of its sensitivity. What GAO Recommends GAO recommends that FSA (1) enroll loan servicers in FSA's continuous monitoring program and (2) modify FSA's agreements with guaranty agencies to specify a required baseline of security controls based on the impact level of the information shared with these agencies, as determined by FSA. FSA generally concurred with GAO's recommendations.
gao_GAO-18-394: Why GAO Did This Study HUD is responsible for addressing lead paint hazards in housing. HUD's lead hazard control grant programs and its two largest rental assistance programs serve the most families with children: the Housing Choice Voucher and public housing programs. HUD's lead hazard control grant programs are administered by HUD's Lead Office and the Office of Public and Indian Housing (PIH). GAO was asked to review HUD's lead hazard control grant programs. This report examines (1) HUD's efforts to (1) incorporate statutory requirements and other relevant federal standards in its lead grant programs; (2) monitor and enforce compliance with lead paint regulations for its rental assistance programs; (3) adopt federal health guidelines and environmental standards for lead hazards in its lead grant and rental assistance programs; and (4) measure and report on its performance related to making housing lead-safe. GAO reviewed relevant laws, HUD's lead grant programs, and HUD's lead hazard control grant programs; analyzed HUD's grant data from 2013 through 2017; and interviewed HUD staff. What GAO Found The Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD) has incorporated relevant requirements for awarding recent lead grants, but could better document and evaluate its grant processes. HUD's lead grant programs have incorporated Title X of the Housing and Community Development Act of 1992 (Title X) statutory requirements through recent annual funding notices and their grant processes. HUD has established processes for reviewing and scoring grant applications using these evaluative criteria, and selects grant recipients based on the review scores. HUD has also developed a framework to assess the risk posed by applicants for competitive grants. However, HUD has not fully documented or evaluated its lead grant processes in reviewing and scoring the grants and making award decisions. For example, HUD's application review guide describes its grant application review and award processes at a high level but does not provide detailed guidance for staff as to how tasks should be performed. HUD has begun to develop analyses and tools to inform its efforts to target outreach and ensure that grant awards go to areas of the country that are at risk for lead paint hazards. However, HUD has not developed time frames for incorporating the results of the analyses into its lead grant programs' processes. Federal internal control standards state that agencies should identify objectives clearly to enable the identification of risks. Setting specific time frames could help to ensure that HUD operationalizes this model in a timely manner. HUD could take additional steps to monitor compliance with lead paint regulations for nearly 4,000 PHAs. HUD's compliance monitoring processes rely in part on PHA self-certifications that they are in compliance with lead paint regulations, but recent investigations have found that some PHAs may have falsely certified that they were in compliance. HUD's new compliance monitoring approach has some limitations that create risks. By adopting procedures that clearly describe when lead paint hazard compliance efforts are no longer sufficient and enforcement decisions are needed, HUD can better keep PHAs accountable in a consistent and timely manner. HUD's lead dust standards align with the Environmental Protection Agency's (EPA) standards for its rental assistance programs and exceed EPA standards for the lead grant programs. HUD's lead dust standards align with EPA standards for its rental assistance programs and exceed EPA standards for the lead grant programs. HUD has taken limited steps to measure, evaluate, and report on the performance of its programmatic efforts to ensure that housing is lead-safe. First, HUD has tracked one performance measure for its lead grant programs but lacks comprehensive performance goals and measures. Second, while HUD has evaluated the effectiveness of its Lead-Based Paint Hazard Control grant program, it has not formalized plans and does not have a time frame for evaluating its lead paint regulations. Third, HUD has not issued an annual report on the results of its lead efforts since 1997. By incorporating key elements of performance assessment--by developing comprehensive goals, improving performance measures, and adhering to reporting requirements--could better enable HUD to assess its own progress and target its resources toward lead efforts that maximize impact. What GAO Recommends GAO recommends that HUD (1) more fully document its processes for scoring and awarding lead grants and (2) set time frames for incorporating relevant data on lead paint hazard risks into its lead grant programs' processes. HUD disagreed with one of GAO's recommendations and generally agreed with the remaining eight.
gao_GAO-18-349T: Why GAO Did This Study The 2017 Act requires VA to develop a comprehensive plan for implementing and administering the new appeals process. The Act also requires GAO to assess VA's plan against the Act's requirements. This testimony addresses (1) the extent to which VA's plan addresses the Act's requirements, (2) the extent to which VA's plan reflects sound planning practices, and (3) the extent to which VA's plan addresses the Act's requirements. To address these objectives, GAO analyzed VA's plan against the Act's requirements, interviewed VA officials, and reviewed VA's plan and supplemental materials. What GAO Found The Department of Veterans Affairs' (VA) appeals plan addresses 17 of the 22 required elements in the Veterans Appeals Improvement and Modernization Act of 2017 (the Act). VA's plan addresses the required elements related to, among others, identifying legal authorities for hiring and removing employees, estimating timeliness for hiring and training employees, and outlining the outreach VA expects to conduct. VA's plan reflects certain sound planning practices, such as convening a working group on performance tracking; however, the plan could improve its planning practices related to monitoring and assessing performance on a range of key dimensions of success. For example, VA's plan does not articulate a set of goals and measures that cover all aspects of its new appeals process, such as accuracy of decisions and cost. VA's plan also does not provide details on the metrics the agency will develop, how it will assess if the new appeals process is an improvement over the legacy process, and how it will monitor the allocation of resources between legacy and new appeals claims. VA's plan reflects certain aspects of sound planning practices related to managing the implementation of process change; however, other key components are not addressed. For example, VA's appeals plan includes an assessment of risks associated with implementing the new appeals process, but could more comprehensively reflect key risks posed by such a significant reform effort. For example, VA's plan does not clearly define success criteria for the Rapid Appeals Modernization Program (RAMP), which is intended to reduce veterans' legacy appeals by providing them with a chance for early resolution of their claims within the Veterans Benefits Administration (VBA) while the Board focuses on reducing its inventory of legacy appeals. However, VA's plan does not clearly define success criteria for RAMP, and VA's plan does not articulate how it will assess RAMP before proceeding with full implementation. Without fully articulating its plan for deciding how and when to roll out changes more broadly, it is not clear whether VA would be prepared to fully implement a new appeals process that achieves its aim of better serving veterans. What GAO Recommends GAO is making recommendations to address the Act's requirements. VA agreed with GAO's assessment and provided technical comments, which GAO incorporated as appropriate.
